   B.   Event based charges for cable service or video service, including, but
not limited to, pay per view and video on demand charges.
   C.   Rental of set top boxes and other cable service or video service
equipment.
   D.   Service charges related to the provision of cable service or video
service, including, but not limited to, activation, installation, and repair
charges.
   E.   Administrative charges related to the provision of cable service or
video service, including, but not limited to, service order and service
termination charges.
   F.   Late payment fees or charges, insufficient funds check charges, and
other charges assessed to recover the costs of collecting delinquent payments.
   G.   A pro rata portion of all revenue derived by the grantee or the holder
or its affiliates pursuant to compensation arrangements for advertising or for
promotion or exhibition of any products or services derived from the operation
of the grantee's or the holder's network to provide cable service or video
service within the county. The allocation shall be based on the number of
subscribers in the county divided by the total number of subscribers in
relation to the relevant regional or national compensation arrangement.
   H.   Compensation received by the grantee or the holder that is derived from
the operation of the grantee's or the holder's network to provide cable service
or video service with respect to commissions that are received by the holder as
compensation for promotion or exhibition of any products or services on the
holder's network, such as a "home shopping" or similar channel, subject to
subsection I of this definition.
   I.   In the case of a cable service or video service that is bundled or
integrated functionally with other services, capabilities, or applications, the
portion of the grantee's or the holder's revenue attributable to the other
services, capabilities, or applications shall be included in gross revenue
unless the grantee or the holder can reasonably identify the division or
exclusion of the revenue from its books and records that are kept in the
regular course of business.
   J.   The franchise fee or service provider fee permitted under this article.
Gross revenues do not include any of the following:
   A.   Revenues not actually received, even if billed, such as bad debt.
   B.   Refunds, discounts, or other price adjustments that reduce the amount
of gross revenues received by the grantee or the holder to the extent the
refund, rebate, credit, or discount is attributable to cable service or video
service.
   C.   Regardless of whether the services are bundled, packaged, or
functionally integrated with cable service or video service, any revenues
received from services not classified as cable service or video service,
including, without limitation, revenue received from telecommunications
services, information services, or the provision of directory or internet
advertising, including yellow pages, white pages, banner advertisement, and
electronic publishing or any other revenues attributed by the grantee or the
holder to noncable service or nonvideo service in accordance with the grantee's
or the holder's books and records and records kept in the regular course of
business and any applicable laws, rules, regulations, standards, or orders.
   D.   The sale of cable service or video services for resale in which the
purchaser is required to collect the franchise fee or service provider fee from
the purchaser's subscribers to the extent the purchaser certifies in writing
that it will resell the service within the county and pay the franchise fee or
service provider fee with respect to the service.
   E.   Any tax or fee of general applicability imposed upon the subscribers or
the transaction by the county, a city, state, federal, or any other
governmental entity and collected by the grantee or the holder and required to
be remitted to the taxing entity, including sales and use taxes.
   F.   Security deposits collected from subscribers.
   G.   Amounts paid by subscribers to "home shopping" or similar vendors for
merchandise sold through any home shopping channel offered as part of the cable
service or video service. Revenue of an affiliate of a grantee or a holder
shall be included in the calculation of gross revenues to the extent the
treatment of the revenue as revenue of the affiliate rather than the grantee or
the holder has the effect of evading the payment of the fee permitted by this
article which would otherwise be paid by the cable service or video service
provider.
As used herein, "annual gross revenues" shall mean gross revenues attributable
to a twelve (12) month accounting period, or portion thereof. This definition
of gross revenues shall be the basis for computing the franchise fees imposed
pursuant to section 10.5-61 of this chapter.
Gross revenues shall be calculated in accordance with generally accepted
accounting principles ("GAAP"), to the extent not in conflict with this
chapter; provided however, that if GAAP, as of the effective date hereof, would
exclude a category of gross revenues which is specifically enumerated above,
then such category shall be included in gross revenues notwithstanding the
application of GAAP to the calculation.
HEADEND: The control center of a CATV system, where incoming signals are
amplified, converted, processed and combined into a common cable along with any
origination cablecasting, for transmission to subscribers. The headend by
illustration and not by limitation, may include antennas, preamplifiers,
frequency converters, demodulators, modulators, processors, and other related
equipment.
HOLDER: A person or entity that has received authorization to offer or provide
cable or video service from the commission pursuant to 220 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 5/21-401.
ICC OR COMMISSION: The Illinois commerce commission.
INSTALLATION: The connection of the cable system from subscriber drop cables to
subscribers' terminals.
JULIE: The joint utility locating information for excavators utility
notification program.
LEASED ACCESS: The use of the system by any business enterprise or other entity
(whether profit, nonprofit or governmental) to render services to the citizens
of the county, and shall include, without limitation, all use pursuant to
section 532 of the act.
LOCAL UNIT OF GOVERNMENT: A city, village, incorporated town, or a county.
MUNICIPALITY: A county, village, or incorporated town as defined under Illinois
state statutes, which is located within or adjacent to Kane County. Unless
otherwise provided by the context of this chapter, "municipal" or
"municipality" does not include a township, town when used as the equivalent of
a township, incorporated town which has superseded a civil township, county,
district, sanitary district, or any other similar governmental district.
NORMAL BUSINESS HOURS: Those hours during which most similar businesses in the
geographic area of the local unit of government are open to serve customers. In
all cases, must include some evening hours at least one night per week or some
weekend hours.
NORMAL OPERATING CONDITIONS: Those service conditions that are within the
control of cable or video providers. Those conditions that are not within the
control of cable or video providers include, but are not limited to, natural
disasters, civil disturbances, power outages, telephone network outages, and
severe or unusual weather conditions. Those conditions that are ordinarily
within the control of cable or video providers include, but are not limited to,
special promotions, pay per view events, rate increases, regular peak or
seasonal demand periods, and maintenance or upgrade of the cable service or
video service network.
ORDINANCE: The Kane County community antenna television ordinance, as may be
amended from time to time.
PEG: Public, educational, and governmental.
PEG ACCESS SUPPORT FEE: The amount paid under this article and 220 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 5/21-801(d) by a holder to the county for the service areas
within its territorial jurisdiction.
PERSON: Individuals, corporations, partnerships, limited liability companies,
and any other form of legal entity.
PUBLIC ACCESS CHANNEL: A cable television channel or channels specifically
designated as a channel or channels available to the public for the production
of noncommercial programming as subject to applicable law.
RIGHT OF WAY: Any street, alley, other land or waterway, dedicated or commonly
used for pedestrian or vehicular traffic or other similar purposes, including
utility easements, and air rights in which the county has the right and
authority to authorize, regulate, or permit the location of facilities other
than those of the county. "Right of way" or "rights of way" shall not include
any real or personal county property that is not specifically described in the
previous sentence and shall not include county buildings, fixtures, and other
structures or improvements regardless of whether they are situated in the right
of way.
SCHOOL: Any public or private elementary school, secondary school, community
college or junior college, four (4) year college or university which conducts
classes or provides instructional services and which has been granted a
certificate of recognition by the state of Illinois.
SERVICE: The provision of "cable service" or "video service" to subscribers and
the interaction of subscribers with the person or entity that has received
authorization to offer or provide cable or video service from the commission
pursuant to 220 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/21-401.
SERVICE CALL: Grantee's on site visits to a subscriber's residence regarding
cable service.
SERVICE INTERRUPTION: The loss of either picture or sound or both for any
channel for single or multiple subscriber(s).
SERVICE LINE DROP: The point of connection between a premises and the cable or
video network that enables the premises to receive cable service or video
service.
SERVICE PROVIDER FEE: The amount paid by a holder to the county for service
areas within its territorial jurisdiction, but under no circumstances shall the
service provider fee be paid to the county and more than one local unit of
government for the same portion of the holder's service area.
SHALL: As used herein is mandatory and not merely directory.
SNOW DROP: The temporary drop to the subscriber's house that is placed
aboveground during the winter months.
SUBSCRIBER: Any person who legally receives any one or more of the services
provided by the system.
SUBSCRIBER DROP: A cable which connects the tap of a feeder cable to a ground
block at the subscriber's premises.
USER: A party utilizing a cable system channel for purposes of production or
transmission of material to subscribers, as contrasted with receipt thereof in
a subscriber capacity.
VIDEO PROGRAMMING: Programming provided by, or generally considered comparable
to programming provided by a television broadcast station, notwithstanding the
means for delivery or transmission of the programming.
VIDEO SERVICE: Video programming and subscriber interaction, if any, that is
required for the selection or use of such video programming services, and which
is provided through wireline facilities located at least in part in the public
right of way without regard to delivery technology, including internet protocol
technology. This definition does not include any video programming provided by
a commercial mobile service provider as defined in 47 USC section 332(d) or any
video programming provided solely as part of, and via, service that enables
users to access content, information, electronic mail, or other services
offered over the public internet. (Ord. 08-252, 8-12-2008, eff. 9-1-2008)
DIVISION 3. FRANCHISE REQUIRED; PROMPT ACTION
10.5-32: FRANCHISE REQUIRED; PROMPT ACTION:
   A.   No person may construct or otherwise obtain a permit to construct a
CATV system in the county to provide cable service without first obtaining from
the county a franchise authorizing the construction of such a system.
   B.   No person operating a CATV system may provide cable service to any
person in the unincorporated areas of the county unless a franchise from the
county authorizing same is in full force and effect at all times while cable
service is being provided.
   C.   Other than an incumbent provider of cable service on the effective date
hereof, any person required to obtain a CATV system franchise pursuant to this
chapter shall first submit a written application for a CATV system franchise to
the county demonstrating the applicant's financial, legal, and technical
qualifications to construct, maintain, and operate a CATV system to meet the
county's needs. Application requirements shall be specifically stated in
section
10.5-41 of this chapter.
   D.   Upon receipt of a complete application from the proposed grantee, the
county shall promptly consider and take such actions as may be necessary to
review and consider such application, including compliance with the written
notice and public hearing requirements of 55 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/5-
1095(e), if applicable. The county shall grant or deny the application for a
CATV system franchise within ninety (90) days after completion of the public
hearing or the receipt of a complete agreement, whichever is later; provided
however, that if an applicant does not have existing authority to access the
county rights of way in the geographic area that the applicant proposes to
serve, the county shall grant or deny the application for a CATV system
franchise within one hundred eighty (180) days of the date the application is
received by the franchising authority. The county and an initial franchise
applicant or a competitive franchise applicant may mutually agree in writing to
extend the ninety (90) or one hundred eighty (180) day time lines, whichever is
applicable.
   E.   In acting upon a CATV system franchise application, the county may
assess fees that do not exceed the reasonable, actual administrative costs
incurred by the county in processing the CATV system franchise application,
including costs incurred by the county in managing the public rights of way,
public highways, and other public places that are directly attributable to
reviewing the CATV system franchise application, approving and administering
the CATV system franchise application, and inspecting the CATV system
operator's plans, specifications, maps, and construction. The fee assessed to
each CATV system franchise applicant shall be competitively neutral and
nondiscriminatory.
   F.   Any franchise for a CATV system issued by the county shall contain
provisions which address at least the following issues:
      1.   Standards for construction in the right of way;
      2.   Construction schedule;
      3.   Permit requirements;
      4.   Uniform customer service and subscriber privacy standards as
established by 220 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/22-501;
      5.   Public, educational, and governmental programming and access
channels;
      6.   Term;
      7.   Payments based on gross revenues;
      8.   Indemnity and insurance;
      9.   Type of service offered;
      10.   Emergency alert system;
      11.   Backup power, system testing and monitoring;
      12.   Free services to public buildings;
      13.   Transfer of ownership and control of the grantee and transfer of
the franchise;
      14.   Procedures for violations, including suspension, liquidated
damages, revocation, and termination;
      15.   Security fund;
      16.   Acquisition or removal of system;
      17.   Access to books and records, including audit;
      18.   Nondiscrimination; and
      19.   Any such other terms, conditions, and provisions that the county
deems to be in the public interest.
   G.   Any franchise granted pursuant to this chapter shall contain an
acknowledgment and agreement by the grantee: 1) that all notices, meetings and
hearings have been properly given and held by the county with respect to the
approval of the franchise agreement and 2) not to challenge such approval on
the grounds of any procedural infirmity or of any denial of any procedural
right. The grantee shall also agree to hold harmless and indemnify the county,
its corporate authorities, and all county elected or appointed officials,
officers, employees, agents, representatives, engineers, and attorneys, from
any and all claims that may be asserted at any time against any of such parties
in connection with the county's review and approval of the franchise and the
franchise agreement and to pay all expenses, including legal fees and
administrative expenses, incurred by the county in defending itself with regard
to any and all such claims. (Ord. 08-252, 8-12-2008, eff. 9-1-2008)
10.5-33 - 10.5-40: RESERVED:
DIVISION 4. ISSUANCE OF A CERTIFICATE OF FRANCHISE
10.5-41: CONTENTS OF FRANCHISE APPLICATION:
   A.   Applications for a franchise by an initial franchise applicant or by a
competitive franchise applicant shall be provided on a form issued by the
county under this article and shall include at a minimum:
      1.   The applicant's name;
      2.   The names of the applicant's officers and directors, or in the case
of a partnership, any general or limited partners;
      3.   The business address of the applicant;
      4.   The name and contact information of a designated contact for the
applicant;
      5.   A description of the geographic area that the applicant proposes to
serve, including a map or maps;
      6.   The PEG channel capacity and capital support proposed by the
applicant;
      7.   The term of the agreement proposed by the applicant;
      8.   Whether the applicant holds an existing authorization to access the
public rights of way in the subject franchise area as described in subsection
A5 of this section;
      9.   The amount of the franchise fee that the applicant offers to pay
based on the definition of "gross revenues";
      10.   The expected date that cable service will be initially offered in
the area identified in the proposed franchise area. In the event that an
applicant does not offer cable services within three (3) months after the
expected date, it shall amend its application and update the expected date
service will be offered and explain the delay in offering cable services;
      11.   Plans and specifications relating to all aspects of the applicant's
proposed system as are applicable to the building and zoning laws of the
county, including a layout of proposed construction on the maps required under
subsection A5 of this section and a tentative construction progression
schedule;
      12.   Projected financial information in a pro forma format covering a
period of no less than five (5) years for system revenue and operation, and
evidence of financial responsibility;
      13.   The application shall include the applicant's general standards
related to customer service required by division 8 of this article, which shall
include, but not be limited to, installation, disconnection, service and repair
obligations; appointment hours, employee ID requirements; customer service
telephone numbers and hours; procedures for billing, charges, deposits,
refunds, and credits; procedures for termination of service; notice of deletion
of programming service, changes related to transmission of programming or
changes or increases in rates; use and availability of parental control or
lockout devices; complaint procedures and procedures for bill dispute
resolution, and a description of the rights and remedies available to consumers
if the holder does not materially meet their customer service standards; and
special services for customers with visual, hearing or mobility disabilities;
      14.   Additional information as may be required by applicable laws of the
county and the state of Illinois.
   B.   For the purposes of this article, the term "principal of any partner"
shall mean any limited partner owning directly or indirectly five percent (5%)
or more interest in the partnership; or if a partner is a corporation, each and
every director, officer, and shareholder owning directly or indirectly five
percent (5%) or more of the stock of such corporation. For purposes of this
division, the term "principal stockholder" shall mean each and every one of the
directors, officers, and shareholders owning directly or indirectly, five
percent (5%) or more of the stock of the grantee of a corporation. Except for
circumstances which have been disclosed by the grantee in writing to the county
prior to the adoption of this article, on accepting the franchise, the grantee
shall represent and warrant with respect to the grantee the following:
      1.   No general partner, any principal of any partner, or principal
stockholder has ever been convicted of a crime involving moral turpitude or is
presently under indictment charging such a crime.
      2.   No general partner, any principal of any partner, or principal
stockholder has ever been punished or censured in any jurisdiction by a court
or administrative agency for any violation or attempted violation of any law,
rule, or order relating to CATV system operation.
      3.   No general partner, any principal of any partner, or principal
stockholder has ever filed for or been principal or officer of any company,
business, partnership, or corporation which has filed for bankruptcy.
      4.   Representations made by the grantee in its documents submitted to
the county required in this article are true, correct, and complete in all
material respects.
      5.   The grantee is not a party to any pending or threatened litigation
in any court of law or proceeding by the securities and exchange commission,
the FCC, or any other governmental body in which any franchise held by the
grantee is being challenged.
      6.   The grantee has never held a franchise which has been revoked.
      7.   The grantee has never been held by a court of law to be in breach of
any contract in connection with a cable television franchise held by the
grantee.
      8.   The grantee is in compliance with all applicable laws and
regulations concerning the offer and sale of its respective securities.
      9.   The grantee shall disclose to the county in writing, any
circumstances which may render any of the representations made herein untrue in
any material respect. In the event of transfer or sale of the franchise, this
requirement shall be applicable to the successor grantee or its assigns.
      10.   The grantee and its principal officers shall submit and file a
statement of economic interest pursuant to the Illinois governmental ethics
act.
   C.   Administrative processes regarding the issuance of a franchise to an
initial franchise applicant or a competitive franchise applicant shall not
begin until the applicant has filed its application with the county.
   D.   The applicant may designate information that it submits in its
application or subsequent reports as confidential or proprietary, provided that
the applicant states the reasons the confidential designation is necessary. The
county shall provide adequate protection for such information. If the county,
or any other party seeks public disclosure of information designated as
confidential, the county shall consider the confidential designation in
accordance with the Illinois freedom of information act, and the burden of
proof to demonstrate that the designated information is confidential shall be
upon the applicant.
Designated information shall remain confidential pending the county's
determination of whether the information is entitled to confidential treatment.
Information designated as confidential under this section or determined to be
confidential upon review by the Kane County state's attorney's office shall
only be disclosed pursuant to a valid and enforceable subpoena or court order
or as required by the freedom of information act. Nothing herein shall delay
the application approval time frames set forth in this article. Information
regarding the location of cable services that have been or are being offered to
the public shall not be designated or treated as confidential.
   E.   In the event that the county is unable to grant or deny an application
within the time limits identified in subsection
10.5-32D of this chapter to a competitive franchise applicant, a competitive
franchise applicant will be authorized to offer service pursuant to an interim
franchise in accordance with the terms of its application submitted under
subsection A of this section. If, after the ninety (90) day or one hundred
eighty (180) day period for review and approval of the applicant's franchise
application, the county denies the application, the applicant must discontinue
operating under the interim franchise unless the county provides consent for
the interim franchise to continue for a limited period of time. The applicant
may seek judicial review of the denial in accordance with 47 USC section 555.
   F.   If, after expiration of the time limit specified in subsection
10.5-32D of this chapter, the county and an initial franchise applicant or a
competitive franchise applicant agree on the terms of a franchise, upon the
effective date of that franchise, the interim franchise shall end, and the new
franchise shall govern. (Ord. 08-252, 8-12-2008, eff. 9-1-2008)
10.5-42: REVIEW OF FRANCHISE APPLICATION:
   A.   Review of franchise applications shall be conducted pursuant to rules,
regulations, and procedures consistent with applicable state and federal law,
as adopted by the Kane County development department. The department shall:
      1.   Review the application and all information submitted therewith, as
to both completeness and competency thereof.
      2.   Request and evaluate supplemental documentation which may be
required as a function of the thorough review of the application and plans and
specifications submitted therewith.
      3.   Request and review all documentation necessary for verification of
the applicant's compliance with all appropriate laws and county codes and
regulations.
      4.   Give prompt public notice of said applications as requested pursuant
to the cable act and state statutes and may seek such public comment as
necessary to determine whether granting the application is in the public
interest.
      5.   Require any supporting documentation or studies to augment or
clarify information required under subsection
10.5-41A1 through A14 of this chapter, particularly with regard to CATV system
technology and performance, programming and services offered, customer service
and service provision policies, and financial responsibility. This section
should not be construed as a condition by the county on any particular
technology or technological format provided by an applicant.
      6.   Collect from the applicant a fee for all incidental expenses arising
from the review and evaluation of the application as such are described under
47 USC section 542.
   B.   After the department's review of the application and all further
materials under this section, the application shall be referred to the county
board no later than sixty (60) days from the date of submission of the
application, with an appropriate recommendation thereon to the county board for
action with this article. In no event shall an application be approved or
denied by the county board more than ninety (90) days after the date of
submission, or, in the event that the county and the applicant have agreed to
an extension of time for review, the county board shall either approve or deny
the application no later than one hundred eighty (180) days after the date of
submission.
   C.   A decision shall be made by the county after the filing of a franchise
application based upon the evaluation. The county may grant one or more
franchises, or may decline to grant any franchise. (Ord. 08-252, 8-12-2008,
eff. 9-1-2008)
10.5-43: GRANT OF FRANCHISE:
   A.   The county may grant a franchise for all or any defined portion of the
county; provided, however, that where a second CATV franchise is granted, the
boundaries of the second CATV franchise shall be the same as those of an
incumbent.
   B.   An incumbent CATV grantee may, upon demonstrated good cause based upon
commercial impracticability, and provided in writing to the county board, may
decline to serve a portion of its franchise area. In order to serve those areas
of the county not served by the incumbent CATV grantee, the county may grant a
franchise to a different incumbent CATV grantee serving areas adjacent to the
unserved area in question, or it may also grant a franchise to a competitive
franchise applicant seeking to serve the unserved area.
   C.   The franchise area shall be the entire area defined in the franchise
agreement. The development department shall define a particular geographic area
in which an individual franchise is to be exercised. Such geographical area
shall be within a county unincorporated franchise area. In the event of an
annexation of all or part of a particular county unincorporated franchise area,
the provisions of 55 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/5-1095, as amended, shall
apply.
   D.   A grant of franchise shall require an affirmative vote of a majority of
all members of the county board then holding office on a resolution authorizing
execution of the franchise agreement.
   E.   In the event that the county shall grant a nonexclusive, revocable
franchise to construct, operate, maintain, and reconstruct a CATV system within
the franchise area, said franchise shall constitute both a right and obligation
to provide the services of a CATV system as required by the provisions of this
article and the franchise agreement. Any franchise granted under the provisions
hereof shall be consistent with state and federal laws and regulations to the
extent constitutionally required, and shall be consistent with local ordinances
and regulations from time to time enacted and amended.
   F.   In the event of a conflict between the terms and conditions of the
franchise agreement and the statutes of the county applicable to the granting
of a franchise, then the statutory requirements shall, without exception,
control interpretation, amplification, and clarification of statutory
requirements found in the franchise agreement and shall not be considered a
conflict.
   G.   No CATV system shall be allowed to occupy or use the rights of way
located in the franchise area other than in accordance with this article and a
franchise granted pursuant hereto. A CATV system shall, at all times, be in
compliance with the policies for use of the rights of way as such policies are
promulgated by the Kane County department of transportation (KDOT).
   H.   The requirements for the granting of franchises established by this
article may be modified from time to time to reflect changes in law,
regulation, or technology. Such requirements shall be applied to franchises
then in effect at the time such modified requirements are enacted pursuant to
police powers or as permitted by the franchise agreement. Any modified
requirements shall be applicable to any renewed franchise agreement. Any CATV
franchise shall be nonexclusive. The county specifically reserves the right to
grant, at any time, and in a manner consistent with then applicable law, such
additional franchises in the same geographical area granted to an incumbent
grantee in accordance with the provisions of 55 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/5-
1095(e)(1-5), or for any other geographical area within unincorporated Kane
County. (Ord. 08-252, 8-12-2008, eff. 9-1-2008)
10.5-44: TERM OF THE FRANCHISE:
   A.   The term of any new or renewed franchise and all rights, privileges,
obligations, and reservations pertaining thereto shall be as established in the
franchise agreement, unless terminated sooner as hereafter provided.
   B.   A franchise shall take effect and be in full effect from and after
acceptance by the grantee, and the same shall continue in full force and effect
for the term specified in the franchise agreement unless otherwise terminated
or revoked as allowed pursuant to the provisions of this article. (Ord. 08-252,
8-12-2008, eff. 9-1-2008)
10.5-45: PERFORMANCE EVALUATION SESSION:
   A.   The county and grantee may hold performance evaluation sessions at any
time during the term of the franchise agreement. All such evaluation sessions
shall be open to the public. At such time that the county seeks to hold a
performance evaluation session, it shall notify the grantee in writing at least
sixty (60) days in advance of each of the specified performance evaluation
meetings. In the event that any such performance evaluation session is not
held, for any reason, as scheduled, it may be held at such a later date as the
county shall select, after thirty (30) days' written notice to grantee.
   B.   Special evaluation sessions may be held from time to time during the
term of the franchise for just cause, at the request of the county or the
grantee.
   C.   All evaluations shall be open to the public and announced in a
newspaper of general circulation at least once ten (10) days prior to said
session. Where possible, the county shall notify subscribers of all evaluation
sessions, by announcements on local government access channels on the system
that serve the unincorporated areas of the county for five (5) consecutive days
immediately preceding each meeting.
   D.   Topics to be addressed may include issues related to the grantee's CATV
system performance and franchise requirements. A grantee may request a copy of
the agenda for any such session to the extent that said agenda is available to
the public. In addition, the county may provide to the grantee, in advance of
the publication of the agenda, a review of topics or a listing of questions in
order to solicit specific questions from the grantee and enable the grantee to
provide more complete answers than would have been possible without advance
prompting.
   E.   During a review and evaluation by the county, the grantee shall
cooperate with the county and shall provide such information and documents as
the county deems necessary to reasonably perform its review.
   F.   If at any time during its review, or within thirty (30) days of a
scheduled review, the county determines that reasonable evidence exists of
inadequate CATV system performance, it may require the grantee to perform tests
and analyses directed toward the suspected inadequacies in accordance with the
standards set forth in section
10.5-140 of this chapter.
   G.   If, at the conclusion of the performance evaluation, the county makes
specific, written findings of fact that show that the grantee has not fully
complied with the requirements of this chapter, or a franchise agreement, and
has failed to correct such violation after a written notice and opportunity to
cure has been provided, the county may assess penalties under this chapter for
such violation or violations of this chapter so identified by the performance
evaluation. Such penalties shall be assessed in accordance with the procedure
for ordinance violations established in section
10.5-123 of this chapter. In the event that a violation or violations of a
franchise agreement have been identified, any sanctions or liquidated damages
shall be assessed in accordance with the procedures for franchise violations as
described in the franchise agreement.
   H.   The county and the grantee may jointly discuss the cost of performance
sessions. The parties may split the cost of such performance sessions equally.
Costs may include, but are not limited to, legal fees, publication costs, costs
for financial review of the grantee's books and records, system technical
analysis, subscriber surveys, and other costs directly attributable to the
performance sessions. (Ord. 08-252, 8-12-2008, eff. 9-1-2008)
10.5-46: AREA OF JURISDICTION; NEW MUNICIPALITIES:
   A.   This article shall apply to all areas of the county which are
unincorporated at the time of enactment or which may become unincorporated
thereafter and to all unincorporated areas of any territory that hereafter may
be annexed to the county.
   B.   In the event that the residents of a specifically defined section of
the unincorporated area of the county determine through a valid referendum
election to incorporate a municipality under the laws of the state of Illinois,
this article shall continue to apply to such newly created municipality until
the governing body of the newly created municipality has adopted the following:
      1.   An ordinance providing the municipality the authority to franchise a
CATV system and grant authority to a cable provider or video provider for the
use of the municipality's rights of way, and
      2.   An ordinance governing the activities of cable providers and video
providers in the municipality to the extent that such ordinances take the place
of this article if enacted.
A single ordinance embodying the requirements of subsections B1 and B2 of this
section may comply with the conditions of this section. This article shall be
considered to remain in effect in the municipality until the effective date of
the ordinance or ordinances enacted by the governing body of the municipality.
(Ord. 08-252, 8-12-2008, eff. 9-1-2008)
10.5-47: CONTINUING REGULATORY JURISDICTION:
The county shall have continuing regulatory jurisdiction and supervision over
any franchise agreement granted hereunder and may from time to time adopt such
reasonable rules and regulations as it may deem necessary for the conduct of
the business contemplated hereunder, provided, however, that such rules and
regulations do not affect the material provisions of a franchise agreement
after such has been adopted. (Ord. 08-252, 8-12-2008, eff. 9-1-2008)
10.5-48: DEVELOPMENT DEPARTMENT JURISDICTION:
The county hereby confers and delegates the regulatory functions referred to in
section
10.5-47, "Continuing Regulatory Jurisdiction", of this chapter upon the Kane
County development department, or its successor. (Ord. 08-252, 8-12-2008, eff.
9-1-2008)
10.5-49: RESERVED:
DIVISION 5. AREAWIDE INTERCONNECTION OF CATV SYSTEM
10.5-50: INTERCONNECTION WITH OTHER FRANCHISES OR VIDEO PROVIDERS:
Subject to the applicable rules and regulations of the state of Illinois and
the FCC, in the event that two (2) different incumbent cable providers serve
contiguous franchise areas within the county, an incumbent cable provider and a
competitive cable provider serve the same franchise area, or a holder and an
incumbent cable provider serve the same territory of the county, then the
affected parties shall negotiate in good faith to interconnect their networks,
if needed, for the purpose of providing public, education, and government
programming. Interconnection may be accomplished by direct cable, microwave
link, satellite, or other reasonable method of connection. The affected parties
shall provide interconnection of the public, education, and government channels
on reasonable terms and conditions and may not withhold the interconnection.
If the affected parties cannot reach a mutually acceptable interconnection
agreement, the county may require the incumbent grantee to allow the other
grantee or the holder to interconnect its network with the incumbent grantee's
network at a technically feasible point on their networks. If no technically
feasible point for interconnection is available, the other grantee or the
holder and an incumbent grantee shall each make an interconnection available to
the public, education, and government channel originators at their local
origination points and shall provide the facilities necessary for the
interconnection. The cost of any interconnection shall be borne by the other
grantee or a holder unless otherwise agreed to by the parties. The
interconnection required by this section shall be completed within ninety (90)
days from the receipt of written notice from the county that the systems of
both grantees or the incumbent grantee and the holder must be interconnected.
(Ord. 08-252, 8-12-2008, eff. 9-1-2008)
10.5-51: INTERCONNECTION TO NEW MUNICIPALITIES:
The requirements of section
10.5-50 of this chapter shall apply to the interconnection of public,
education, and government channels and emergency communications serving a newly
created municipality.
Such requirements shall be effective until such time as the municipality enters
into a franchise agreement with a cable provider and such agreement contains
conditions regarding interconnection that are not consistent with the
provisions of section
10.5-50 of this chapter. (Ord. 08-252, 8-12-2008, eff. 9-1-2008)
10.5-52 - 10.5-60: RESERVED:
DIVISION 6. FEES/SERVICE PROVIDER FEES
10.5-61: FRANCHISE FEES/SERVICE PROVIDER FEES:
As compensation for the use of the county's rights of way in its unincorporated
areas, and for the franchise granted herein, a grantee shall be liable for and
pay the franchise fee and a holder shall be liable and pay for the service
provider fee to the county. This chapter shall comply with a county ordinance,
or any applicable federal or state law requiring the adoption of this fee.
Other than an incumbent cable provider, a holder's liability for the fee shall
commence on the first day of the calendar month that is at least thirty (30)
days after the grantee receives the ordinance codified herein. The county shall
notify the grantee by U.S. mail, return receipt requested, of the existence of
the ordinance codified herein, and a copy of the ordinance codified herein
shall be enclosed. The fee authorized by this division shall be five percent
(5%) of gross revenues or the same as the fee paid to the county by any
incumbent cable operator providing cable service. The payment of the franchise
fee or service provider fee shall be due on a quarterly basis, forty five (45)
days after the close of the calendar quarter. If mailed, the fee is considered
paid on the date it is postmarked. Except as provided in this chapter, or a
franchise agreement, the county may not demand any additional fees or charges
from the grantee and may not demand the use of any other calculation method
other than allowed under this division. (Ord. 08-252, 8-12-2008, eff. 9-1-2008)
10.5-62: QUARTERLY AND ANNUAL REPORTS:
The grantee or a holder shall file with the county within forty five (45) days
after the expiration of each of the grantee's or holder's fiscal quarters, a
financial statement clearly showing in detail the gross revenues by category
received by the grantee or holder during the preceding quarter, and shall
simultaneously tender payment of the quarterly portion of the franchise fee or
service provider fee. The grantee shall also file, within one hundred twenty
(120) days following the conclusion of the grantee's fiscal year, a financial
report prepared and audited annually by a certified public accounting firm
acceptable to the county, clearly showing the yearly accumulated total gross
revenues and amount of franchise fees or service provider fees paid to the
county during the prior fiscal year. The statement of revenue shall be
accompanied by a statement from an authorized financial officer of the grantee
or the holder certifying that the statement is true, complete, and correct.
(Ord. 08-252, 8-12-2008, eff. 9-1-2008)
10.5-63: AUDIT OF FRANCHISE FEE/SERVICE PROVIDER FEE:
   A.   Audit Procedures: Upon reasonable prior written notice, during normal
business hours, at grantee's or holder's principal business office in the
county, the county or its designee shall have the right to inspect and audit in
accordance with generally accepted auditing standards (GAAS), the grantee's
financial records used to calculate the grantee's franchise fees or a holder's
service provider fees; provided, however, that any such inspection or audit
shall take place within five (5) years from the date the county receives such
payment, after which period any such payment shall be considered final.
Information on individual subscribers necessary for the conducting of franchise
fee audits shall not be subject to the disclosure limitations of 47 USC section
551.
   B.   Audit Report: Upon completion of any such audit by the county or its
designee, the county shall provide to the grantee or the holder a final report
setting forth the county's findings in detail, including any and all
substantiating documentation. In the event of an alleged underpayment, the
grantee shall have thirty (30) days from the receipt of the report to provide
the county with a written response agreeing to or refuting the results of the
audit, including any substantiating documentation. Based on these reports and
responses, the parties shall agree upon a "finally settled amount".
   C.   Finally Settled Amount(s): For purposes of this section, the term
"finally settled amount(s)" shall mean the agreed upon underpayment or
overpayment, if any, to the county by the grantee or the holder as a result of
any such audit. If the parties cannot agree on a "finally settled amount",
either party may bring an action to have the disputed amount determined by a
court of law. The grantee, the holder, or the county shall pay any "finally
settled amount(s)" as a result of such audit within thirty (30) days from the
date the parties agree upon the "finally settled amount". Once the parties
agree upon a "finally settled amount" and the grantee, the holder, or the
county pays such amount, the parties shall have no further rights to audit or
challenge the payment for that period.
   D.   Time Of Availability; Expense Of Audit: The audit of books and records
must be available for audit within thirty (30) days of the grantee or the
holder receiving notice of the audit by the county. The county shall bear the
expense of its audit of the grantee's or the holder's books and records,
however if the amount due by grantee is greater than five percent (5%) then
grantee or holder shall pay the expense of the audit.
   E.   Payment: No acceptance of any payment shall be construed as an accord
that the amount paid is, in fact, the correct amount, nor shall such acceptance
of payment be construed as a release of any claim which the county may have for
further or additional sums payable under the provisions of this section. (Ord.
08-252, 8-12-2008, eff. 9-1-2008)
10.5-64: LATE OR DELINQUENT PAYMENTS:
Any franchise fee, service provider fee, or other fee which remains unpaid in
whole or in part after the date specified herein shall be delinquent. For any
franchise fee or service provider fee payments, owed by the grantee or the
holder, respectively which are not made on or before the due dates, the grantee
shall make such payments including interest at an annual rate of twelve percent
(12%) or two percent (2%) over prime lending rates as quoted by the "Wall
Street Journal" (currently in the "Money Rates" column) as of the last day of
each month, whichever is higher, computed daily from time due until paid.
If an additional amount is due as a result of the recomputation, the county
shall send grantee or holder a written notice and an opportunity to cure in
accordance with the provisions included in this chapter. Any overpayments made
by the grantee or holder to the county shall be returned or credited upon
discovery of such overpayment and shall be payable within thirty (30) days of
the receipt of written notice from the grantee or the holder. (Ord. 08-252, 8-
12-2008, eff. 9-1-2008)
10.5-65: STATEMENTS AND CERTIFICATIONS UPON TERMINATION:
Upon termination of a franchise at the expiration of its term provided thereof
or otherwise, the grantee shall continue to make the quarterly/yearly
statements and certifications and the annual reports as provided under this
article until such time as all payments due the county under this article have
been paid and accounted for to the reasonable satisfaction of the county. (Ord.
08-252, 8-12-2008, eff. 9-1-2008)
10.5-66: FEES FOR COUNTY RIGHTS OF WAY IN MUNICIPALITIES:
In those cases where the county rights of way are fully or partially located in
municipalities and such rights of way are not maintained by the municipality,
but are instead maintained by the county, the grantee or the holder shall pay a
franchise fee or a service provider fee based upon the following schedule:
   A.   Right of way is located one hundred percent (100%) within the
boundaries of a municipality: One thousand dollars ($1,000.00) per right of way
per year.
   B.   Right of way is located seventy five (75) to ninety nine percent (99%)
within the boundaries of a municipality: Seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00)
per right of way per year.
   C.   Right of way is located fifty (50) to seventy four percent (74%) within
the boundaries of a municipality: Five hundred dollars ($500.00) per right of
way per year.
   D.   Right of way is located twenty five (25) to forty nine percent (49%)
within the boundaries of a municipality: Two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00)
per right of way per year.
   E.   Right of way is located twenty four percent (24%) or less within the
boundaries of a municipality: One hundred dollars ($100.00) per right of way
per year.
The Kane County development department shall identify those rights of way that
are fully or partially located within the boundaries of a municipality, develop
a map of those rights of way that distinguishes those rights of way levels
based upon the percentages expressed in subsections A through E of this
section, and notify the grantee and the holder in writing no less than one
hundred twenty (120) days prior to the start of the grantee's or the holder's
next fiscal year of the county's policy of collection of franchise fees or
service provider fees within municipalities. Such notification shall include
the map of rights of way as stated herein. (Ord. 08-252, 8-12-2008, eff. 9-1-
2008)
10.5-67 - 10.5-70: RESERVED:
DIVISION 7. PROGRAM SERVICES
10.5-71: ESTABLISHED:
   A.   Standard Of Allocation: A grantee shall provide, at a minimum, cable
programming in the following broad categories: children, general entertainment,
family oriented, ethnic/minority, arts, culture, sports, weather, educational
and performing arts, news and information. Except as expressly permitted by
law, the grantee shall not exercise any editorial control over the content of
programming on the access channels.
   B.   Universal Subscriber Service: Unless otherwise required by applicable
law, or a franchise agreement, a grantee shall make cable service available
throughout unincorporated Kane County in accordance with section
10.5-142, "Line Extension", of this chapter. Where density and proximity
requirements provided in section
10.5-142 of this chapter have been met and applicable right of entry agreements
have been received, a grantee shall not exclude any multiple dwelling unit
facilities located in unincorporated Kane County from having the ability to
receive cable services, including, but not limited to, apartment buildings,
mobile home parks, condominium complexes (including duplexes, townhouses and
row houses), co-ops, and senior citizen congregate housing. Nothing prevents a
grantee from recouping from a property management firm the reasonable expenses
necessary to serve the facility. The county acknowledges that a grantee cannot
control the dissemination of particular cable services beyond the point of
demarcation for a multiple dwelling unit. Notwithstanding the foregoing,
grantee may introduce new or expanded cable services on a geographically phased
basis, where such services require a change in technology of the cable system.
   C.   Access Programming: Use of channel capacity for access programming
shall be provided on the most basic tier of service offered by grantee in
accordance with section 611 of the cable act (47 USC section 531), or on a
mutually agreed upon tier of service. A grantee shall designate one channel on
its CATV system for the use of the county for the purpose of providing
government access programming if the county requests a channel during the term
of a franchise agreement. In the event that the county ceases programming on
the government access channel in its entirety, the county shall recognize a
grantee's proprietary interest in and control of the channel, and shall, at the
written request of a grantee, relinquish the use of the channel to the grantee
in accordance with section 612 of the cable act (47 USC section 532(b)(4))
within sixty (60) calendar days of the receipt of such notice by the county.
   D.   Educational Access: An "educational access channel" is a channel
designated for noncommercial use by schools. In the event a grantee is
cablecasting educational access programming to subscribers in unincorporated
Kane County, the grantee shall continue to cablecast such programming
throughout the term of a franchise agreement or until such programming ceases.
   E.   Public Access: A "public access channel" is a channel designated for
noncommercial use by the residents of Kane County or by not for profit
organizations serving the residents of Kane County. In the event a grantee is
cablecasting public access programming to subscribers in unincorporated Kane
County, the grantee shall continue to cablecast such programming throughout the
term of a franchise agreement or until such programming ceases.
   F.   Government Access: A "government access channel" is a channel
designated for noncommercial use by the grantor.
   G.   Subscriber Survey: The county may, at any time, conduct a subscriber
survey to determine the cable related needs and interests of county residents
regarding the programming offered. The results of the survey may not be binding
upon the grantee, but shall serve as a reflection of the county's needs and
interests. A copy of such survey shall be made available to the grantee. (Ord.
08-252, 8-12-2008, eff. 9-1-2008)
10.5-72 - 10.5-79: RESERVED:
DIVISION 8. CABLE AND VIDEO CUSTOMER PROTECTION LAW
10.5-80: CUSTOMER SERVICE AND PRIVACY PROTECTION:
This division and section are adopted pursuant to the cable and video customer
protection law 1  authorizing a county to enforce all of the customer service
and privacy protection standards of this law. The county shall enforce the
customer service and privacy protections with respect to complaints received
from residents as provided by the cable and video customer protection law.
Any amendment to the cable and video customer protection law that becomes
effective after the effective date of this division and section shall be
incorporated into this division and chapter by reference and shall be
applicable to cable or video providers offering services within the boundaries
of the unincorporated area of Kane County. However, any amendment that makes
its provisions optional for adoption by the county shall not be incorporated
into this division and section by reference without formal action by the county
board.
The county does hereby pursuant to law declare its intent to enforce all of the
customer service and privacy protections of the cable and video customer
protection law as set forth below with respect to complaints received from
residents within the unincorporated areas of Kane County. (Ord. 08-252, 8-12-
2008, eff. 9-1-2008)
 
Notes
1 1. 220 ILCS 5/22-501.
10.5-81: APPLICABILITY TO ALL CABLE AND VIDEO PROVIDERS:
This section applies to all cable and video providers in the county, including,
but not limited to, those operating under a franchise as that term is used in
47 USC section 522(9), and those operating under authorization pursuant to
section 5-1095 of the Illinois statutes. (Ord. 08-252, 8-12-2008, eff. 9-1-
2008)
10.5-82 - 10.5-109: RESERVED:
DIVISION 9. RATES
10.5-110: NONDISCRIMINATION:
The grantee shall not, in its rates, fees or other charges, or in the
availability of the services or facilities of its CATV system, or in any other
respect, discriminate against any persons or group of persons protected by any
applicable nondiscrimination laws. (Ord. 08-252, 8-12-2008, eff. 9-1-2008)
10.5-111 - 10.5-119: RESERVED:
DIVISION 10. REVOCATION OF FRANCHISE; MATERIAL BREACHES AND OTHER PENALTIES
10.5-120: REVOCATION PROCEDURE:
   A.   The franchise granted to a grantee pursuant to a franchise agreement is
subject to revocation in the event of any breach of a franchise agreement or
violation of this chapter. The following events, acts or omissions on the part
of the grantee are a substantial breach and may be considered cause for
revocation of the franchise and termination of a franchise agreement and
include, but are not limited to:
      1.   The grantee repeatedly violates any covenant, agreement, or
condition of its grant, and such violation shall not have been cured within
such reasonable period of time after written notice has been given by the
county authorities pursuant to the provisions of this article.
      2.   Material fraud or misrepresentation in obtaining a franchise.
      3.   Repeated failure to pay taxes, franchise fees, costs or penalties
when and as due the county after failure to respond after repeated notice and
opportunity to cure.
      4.   Failure to provide or maintain in full force and effect required
insurance coverage or required security instruments, including a surety bond or
a letter of credit, or to provide required indemnification to the county as
required by this chapter or a franchise agreement.
      5.   Failure to restore systemwide service in the franchise area after
seventy two (72) consecutive hours provided the grantee's failure to restore
systemwide service is not caused by circumstances or events beyond the
grantee's reasonable control.
      6.   Transfer of the franchise without county approval pursuant to
division 17, "Assignment Or Transfer", of this article.
      7.   Any order is entered in any proceeding against the grantee decreeing
the dissolution or split up of the grantee and such order remains in effect for
sixty (60) days or more.
      8.   The grantee fails to establish, construct, or operate a CATV system
substantially in compliance with the terms of a franchise agreement, with due
consideration given to the nature and cause of any delays.
      9.   The grantee abandons the franchise. The grantee shall be deemed to
have abandoned its franchise if it wilfully refuses or is unable to operate the
cable system as granted by a franchise agreement, when there is no event beyond
the grantee's control that prevents the operation of the CATV system, and where
operation would not endanger the health or safety of the public or property.
      10.   Any other material breach of this article or any violation of an
applicable franchise agreement.
   B.   "Repeated failure" shall mean failure of a material breach or violation
that occurs more than twice a calendar year.
   C.   In the event of a breach of a franchise agreement or violation of this
chapter, the county shall give written notice to the grantee setting forth:
      1.   The nature of the breach or violation by the grantee;
      2.   A written demand that the grantee correct the breach or violation;
      3.   Notice that any failure to correct the breach or violation within
thirty (30) days, or as the parties may agree in a franchise agreement, or by
other mutual agreement, may be cause for revocation of the franchise.
   D.   The grantee shall respond within thirty (30) days in writing to the
county after receipt of a notice of breach or violation and shall provide any
and all information and documentation in support of its response. The grantee's
response may include a statement:
      1.   That it contests the county's notice of breach or violation and
requests an opportunity to be heard as provided herein.
      2.   That corrective action has been implemented by the grantee and the
breach or violation has been cured.
      3.   That corrective action has been implemented by the grantee and is
being actively and diligently pursued, accompanied with a written corrective
action plan that includes the estimated time period in which the breach or
violation will be cured.
      4.   If requested by the grantee, or if the county is not satisfied that
sufficient corrective action is being actively and diligently pursued by the
grantee to remedy the breach or violation, the county shall schedule a public
hearing to hear and determine the issues and to consider whether sufficient
cause exists to revoke the franchise. The county shall give the grantee not
less than fourteen (14) days' written notice specifying the county's intent to
consider the revocation of the grantee's franchise, and the date, time and
place of the public hearing to be held before the county board or a hearing
officer appointed by the county board.
If a hearing officer has been designated, the hearing officer shall hear the
relevant evidence, preserve a record and submit written findings and a
recommendation to the county board for the board to make the appropriate
determination.
      5.   If the hearing is conducted by a hearing officer, the grantee shall
be entitled an opportunity to present to the county board a summary, orally or
in writing, of its position in response to the hearing officer's findings and
recommendations, but the grantee shall not have further opportunity to present
facts or evidence in support of its position. The county board shall receive
and consider the record and the hearing officer's findings and recommendations,
and shall consider the grantee's summary of its position, and shall determine
whether or not a breach or violation by the grantee has occurred, whether it
has been cured or a satisfactory corrective action plan has been submitted and
is being actively and diligently pursued and whether cause exists to initiate
revocation of the franchise or to impose some lesser sanction. The county board
may continue the hearing in order to allow the grantee to comply with any
lesser penalty imposed by the county board in order to correct any breaches or
violations.
In the event that the county board determines that cause exists to revoke the
franchise, it shall send notice of revocation within a reasonable time after
said determination.
      6.   If the county board determines that cause exists to revoke the
franchise, it may, by ordinance, declare a grantee's franchise to be terminated
and revoked consistent with applicable law, provided that the county may grant
a grantee an additional period of time to remedy the substantial breach or
violation before such ordinance becomes effective or grant a time period in
which the grantee may reinstate the revoked franchise.
      7.   No provision of this section shall be deemed to bar or otherwise
limit the right of the county to seek or obtain judicial relief to enforce the
provisions of this chapter or a franchise agreement.
      8.   In the event that a franchise has been revoked by the county and the
county acquires ownership of the CATV system, or effects a transfer of
ownership of a grantee's CATV system to another person, any such acquisition or
transfer shall be governed under section 627 of the cable act (47 USC section
547) or its successor provision.
      9.   Failure by a grantee to comply with a timetable for corrective
action as required by the county board pursuant to the requirements of this
section shall be considered to be a breach of this chapter and may result in a
cause for revocation of the franchise.
      10.   The county board may, upon good cause shown, and upon its own
motion, impose any lesser sanction permitted by this chapter, a franchise
agreement, or as such lesser sanction is permitted at law or in equity.
      11.   If the county board adopts an ordinance under this section which
terminates the franchise, grantee shall have all further legal remedies
available to it by law. (Ord. 08-252, 8-12-2008, eff. 9-1-2008)
10.5-121: CONTINUITY OF OPERATIONS:
In the event of revocation of the franchise, expiration of the franchise, or
transfer of the franchise between the existing grantee and a successor grantee,
the existing grantee (prior to the revocation, transfer or expiration) shall
continue to provide cable service to its subscribers for a period of time until
a successor cable operator operates the cable system in the same manner and
with the same types of programming, customer service, and repair capabilities
and under the same terms and conditions as provided by a franchise agreement
and this chapter prior to the change in status of the franchise. (Ord. 08-252,
8-12-2008, eff. 9-1-2008)
10.5-122: REMOVAL:
   A.   Upon expiration or termination of a franchise, if the franchise is not
renewed, the cable operator is not using the cable for telecommunications
services as defined by the telecommunications act of 1996, and/or for
information services as defined by the telecommunications act of 1996, and if
neither the county nor an assignee purchases the CATV system, the grantee may
remove any underground cable from the rights of way which has been installed in
such a manner that it can be removed without trenching or other openings of the
rights of way along the extension of cable to be removed. The grantee shall not
remove any underground cable or conduit which requires trenching or other
opening of the rights of way along the extension of cable to be removed, except
as hereinafter provided.
   B.   Any order by the county engineer to remove cable or conduit shall be
mailed to the grantee not later than thirty (30) days following the date of
expiration or termination of the franchise. A grantee shall file written notice
with the county engineer not later than thirty (30) days following the date of
expiration or termination of the franchise of its intention to remove cable
intended to be removed and a schedule for removal by location.
   C.   A grantee shall file written notice with the development department not
later than thirty (30) days following the date of expiration or termination of
the franchise of its intention to remove cable intended to be removed and a
schedule of removal by location. The schedule and timing of removal shall be
subject to approval and regulation by the county engineer.
   D.   Removal shall be completed not less than twelve (12) months following
the date of expiration or termination of the franchise. Underground cable and
conduit in the rights of way which is not so removed shall be deemed abandoned
and title thereto shall be vested in the county.
   E.   Upon expiration or termination of a franchise, if the franchise is not
renewed or transferred to a new owner or to the county, the grantee, at its
sole expense, shall, unless relieved of the obligation by the county, remove
from the rights of way all aboveground elements of the CATV system used
exclusively for video programming. The county shall not require the grantee to
remove any cabling, aboveground fixtures, or utility devices that provide
telecommunications services or information services as such are defined in the
telecommunications act of 1996; provided, however that a grantee shall
deactivate all portions of its plant and appurtenances that deliver cable
services if it is required to do so as a result of expiration or termination of
a franchise.
   F.   The grantee shall apply for and obtain such encroachment permits,
licenses, authorizations, or other approvals and pay such fees and deposit such
security as required by county division of transportation permit regulations
and access control regulations.
The grantee shall conduct and complete the work of removal in compliance with
the aforementioned permit and access control regulations, and shall restore the
rights of way to the same condition they were in before the work of removal
commenced. The work of removal shall be completed not later than one year
following the date of expiration or termination of the franchise; otherwise,
the county may complete such work and charge the expense thereof against the
security and/or surety bond required to be provided by the grantee. (Ord. 08-
252, 8-12-2008, eff. 9-1-2008)
10.5-123: MATERIAL VIOLATIONS:
   A.   In the event that the county determines that a grantee has violated any
material provision of the franchise, the county may make a written demand on
grantee that it remedy such violation and provide a period in which the
violation must be cured or remedied. If the violation is not cured or remedied,
or in the process of being cured or remedied to the satisfaction of the county,
within thirty (30) days following any such demand, the county shall determine
whether or not such violation by grantee was excusable or inexcusable as
follows:
      1.   The county shall conduct an administrative hearing to review the
alleged violation, and grantee shall be provided with an opportunity to be
heard upon thirty (30) days' written notice to grantee of the time and the
place of the hearing; the allegations of franchise violations; and the remedy
sought by the county.
      2.   If, after notice is given and a hearing is held, the county
determines that such violation by grantee was excusable, the county shall
direct grantee to correct or remedy the same within such additional time, in
such manner and upon such terms and conditions as the county may reasonably
direct. If the county determines that such violation was inexcusable under a
like analysis, then it may impose a remedy in accordance with this chapter.
      3.   A hearing reviewing the administrative findings may be conducted by
a hearing officer appointed by the county board on the appeal of either the
county or the grantee. Such hearing officer shall be an attorney licensed to
practice under the laws of the state of Illinois.
      4.   The cost of either hearing, if any, shall be borne by the ultimate
nonprevailing party. The costs incurred by the parties for attorney fees,
expert witness fees and other expenses shall be borne solely by the party
incurring the costs.
      5.   In any hearing conducted by a hearing officer, the officer shall,
upon conclusion of the hearing, prepare a recommended decision which includes
findings of fact and conclusions.
The recommended decision shall be filed with the county clerk and mailed to the
parties not later than thirty (30) calendar days after the conclusion of the
hearing. Upon receipt of such a recommended decision, the county board may,
without holding a further hearing, either:
         a.   Adopt the recommended decision, including findings of fact and
conclusions submitted by the hearing officer;
         b.   Adopt the findings of fact and conclusions contained in the
recommended decision, modify the decision, and adopt the recommended decision
as so revised;
         c.   Based upon the record of the hearing, modify the findings of
fact, conclusions or decisions, and adopt the recommended decision as so
revised; or
         d.   Reject the recommended decision and order that a new hearing be
held.
      6.   In the event that the county board determines that a remedy is
warranted, the county may impose a fine not to exceed one thousand dollars
($1,000.00) per day per occurrence from the date upon which the violation or
violations were to have been cured. All fines levied are to be paid within
thirty (30) days and if not, such nonpayment after thirty (30) days could
constitute an additional breach or cause for revocation of the franchise. In
the event that there is a violation of customer service standards under the
provisions of section 10.5-80 of this chapter, the county may impose penalties
up to seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each day of the material
breach, and shall not exceed twenty five thousand dollars ($25,000.00) for each
occurrence of a material breach per customer. Monetary penalties pursuant to
this section shall apply on a competitively neutral basis to all providers of
cable service or video service within the county's jurisdiction and in no event
shall monetary penalties be assessed for a material breach if it is out of the
reasonable control of the cable or video providers or its affiliate. (Ord. 08-
252, 8-12-2008, eff. 9-1-2008)
10.5-124: ALTERNATIVE REMEDIES:
No provision of this chapter shall be deemed to bar the right of the county to
seek or obtain judicial relief from a violation of any provision of the
franchise or any rule, regulation, requirement or directive promulgated
thereunder.
Neither the existence of other remedies identified in this chapter nor the
exercise thereof shall be deemed to bar or otherwise limit the right of the
county to recover, monetary damages (except where liquidated damages are
otherwise prescribed) for such violation by the grantee, or judicial
enforcement of the grantee's obligations by means of specific performance,
injunction relief or mandate, or any other judicial remedy available at law or
in equity. (Ord. 08-252, 8-12-2008, eff. 9-1-2008)
10.5-125: NONENFORCEMENT:
Subject to the provisions of the act, a grantee shall not be relieved of any
obligation to comply with any of the provisions of the franchise or any rule,
regulation, requirement or directive promulgated thereunder by reason of any
failure of the county or its officers, agents or employees to enforce prompt
compliance nor shall such be considered a waiver thereof. (Ord. 08-252, 8-12-
2008, eff. 9-1-2008)
10.5-126 - 10.5-129: RESERVED:
DIVISION 11. RECORDS
10.5-130: MAINTENANCE OF RECORDS:
Unless otherwise provided in a franchise agreement, all records pertaining to
subscribers, cable system operations, and finances of the grantee shall be
maintained in a local office, or in a regional office in the Chicago
metropolitan area to facilitate county regulatory oversight. This section shall
not apply to records generated by a third party with respect to CATV system
programming or operations. (Ord. 08-252, 8-12-2008, eff. 9-1-2008)
10.5-131: INSPECTION RIGHTS:
Upon reasonable notice to the grantee, the county shall have the right at
reasonable times, during normal business hours, dates, and frequency, to
inspect all or any of the grantee's records, documents, and engineering records
and documents of any kind in connection with the grant of franchise, the CATV
system, the system facilities, and the grantee's undertakings with respect to
this article necessary for the enforcement of this chapter, or a franchise
agreement. The grantee shall fully cooperate in allowing the county to conduct
such inspections. Such records shall be held in an office of the grantee which
shall be located in the metropolitan Chicago area. If such records are not
located in the metropolitan Chicago area and travel to review such documents is
necessary, the county shall have the right to seek and obtain reimbursement for
all documented expenses reasonably incurred by the county or its designee for
inspection of the grantee's records. (Ord. 08-252, 8-12-2008, eff. 9-1-2008)
10.5-132: SNOW DROP AND TEMPORARY DROP REPORT:
Upon request, or as provided for in a franchise agreement, grantee will provide
a monthly report for all temporary subscriber drops installed, including "snow
drops", including location, the date of installation, and the date of burial.
(Ord. 08-252, 8-12-2008, eff. 9-1-2008)
10.5-133: CORPORATE REPORT:
Unless otherwise provided in a franchise agreement, if a grantee is a
corporation, the grantee's annual corporate report shall be filed with the
county and shall contain a listing of all grantee's directors, officers and
major shareholders. Where a grantee or its parent is a publicly traded stock
company, the filing by the grantee with the franchising authority of a copy of
the annual report to stockholders shall constitute compliance with the
provisions of this section. Where a grantee or its parent is a publicly traded
stock company subject to security and exchange commission (SEC) reporting
requirements, the availability of its SEC filings on the internet shall
constitute compliance with this section. (Ord. 08-252, 8-12-2008, eff. 9-1-
2008)
10.5-134: FILING OF GOVERNMENTAL DOCUMENTS:
Unless otherwise provided in a franchise agreement, grantee shall maintain the
following records for the amount of time as specified hereunder:
   A.   FCC form 325 or its successor, where applicable, shall be maintained
for the life of the franchise.
   B.   Public files for the time specified as required by the FCC.
   C.   FCC form 395-A, or its successor form, or any supplemental forms
related to equal opportunity or fair contracting policies.
   D.   All other reports required herein and not set forth in this section
shall be maintained for a period of no less than three (3) years.
In accordance with the ex parte rules of the FCC, the grantee shall file with
the Kane County development department a copy of all petitions, applications,
reports, or communications filed or submitted by the grantee with the FCC.
The grantee shall also file with the Kane County development department any
other petitions, applications, reports, and communications filed with the
securities and exchange commission, or any other federal or state governmental
entity having jurisdiction with respect to any matter specifically affecting
the CATV system, its facilities, or the grantee's undertakings with respect to
this section. Said document shall be filed with the Kane County development
department at the same time that they are filed with any other agency. (Ord.
08-252, 8-12-2008, eff. 9-1-2008)
10.5-135: FILING OF MAPS AND PLANS:
   A.   At least twenty one (21) days prior to construction or repair of any
part of the CATV system or system facilities upon rights of way, the grantee
shall file with the development department two (2) copies of all strand maps
which shall accurately show the nature of the proposed construction or
improvements. Within thirty (30) days of completion of such construction, the
grantee shall submit to the development department two (2) "as built" plans
which shall show cable installations, alterations, or improvements as
completed.
   B.   A grantee shall, during the term of a franchise agreement: 1) maintain
up to date "as built" plans, and 2) provide, in the event of a system upgrade,
plant extension or new development, copies of such plans to the development
department without charge.
   C.   Strand maps and "as built" maps shall be provided in a digital format
that are compatible with the county's geographic information system ("GIS").
   D.   A grantee shall acknowledge that the county's records are subject to
disclosure upon request pursuant to the Illinois freedom of information act, 5
Illinois Compiled Statutes 140/1 et seq. Therefore, if in the grantee's opinion
such plans contain information which grantee considers to be trade secrets or
otherwise confidential, grantee shall specify in writing to the county at the
time such maps are provided, the information which is so regarded. (Ord. 08-
252, 8-12-2008, eff. 9-1-2008)
10.5-136: FILING OF MONTHLY PROGRESS REPORTS:
During the initial construction of a CATV system, a grantee shall file with the
Kane County development department monthly reports on the first day of each
month until completion of construction is reached as defined in division 16 of
this article.
Thereafter, the grantee shall file with the county a semiannual report for the
period preceding January 1 and July 1 of each year until the second year after
the CATV system is fully constructed and serving subscribers, the areas of the
county in which construction is completed, the areas of the county in which
construction is under contract but is not completed, together with a projected
completion date for construction in such areas, and such other information as
