   A.   It shall be unlawful for any person to deposit any trash, garbage, or
other offensive material on the county highway rights of way.
   B.   Any person violating this section shall be fined not less than one
hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each
offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed for each location at
which a violation exists. (Ord. 08-168, 5-13-2008)
11-3-2: MISUSE OF PUBLIC TRASH RECEPTACLES:
No person shall transport by any means garbage or refuse from any dwelling,
residence, place of business, farm or other site to and deposit such materials
in or around trash barrels or other receptacles placed along public roads or
rest areas. (Ord. 08-168, 5-13-2008)
11-4: VEHICLES:
No person owning or controlling any vehicle used for the purpose of carrying,
carting, hauling, or transporting garbage, ashes, refuse, or miscellaneous
waste shall cause or permit any vehicle to be so loaded, to be in such
defective condition, so out of repair, or of such faulty construction, or so
improperly driven or managed, that any garbage, ashes, refuse, or miscellaneous
waste with which such vehicle is loaded or is being loaded, shall drop or fall
in any public way or other place. Such vehicle shall be so constructed and
covered as to prevent any part of the contents thereof from falling, leaking,
or spilling therefrom. (Ord. 08-168, 5-13-2008)
11-5: INSPECTION:
The county shall have the right to enter into or on any property to inspect any
facility or condition thereon for the purpose of determining whether these
regulations are being complied with. Refusal by said owner of right of entry
shall cause the county to seek the permission of the court for right of entry.
(Ord. 08-168, 5-13-2008)
11-5-1: VIOLATION:
   A.   Notice Of Violation: Whenever a nuisance is found to exist within the
county, any authorized representative shall give written notice to the owner
and/or occupant of the property upon which such nuisance exists or upon the
person allowing, causing or maintaining the nuisance. The notice of violation
under the provisions of this section shall contain:
      1.   The location of the violation.
      2.   A description of what constitutes the violation.
      3.   A statement of acts necessary to abate or correct the violation.
      4.   A date by which the violation must be abated or corrected to avoid
further legal action.
   B.   Complaint: In the event the owner or occupant of the property upon
which such nuisance exists has failed within the prescribed time to abate such
nuisance, then an authorized representative shall file a complaint pursuant to
the processes and methods prescribed by chapter 2, article IX, "Administrative
Adjudication", of this code. Any authorized representative may issue a
complaint against the owners, lessees and/or occupants of said property or the
persons responsible for causing the nuisance charging a violation of any
section or subsection of this chapter. Such complaint may seek any and all
applicable relief available at law or in equity including, but not limited to,
abatement of the nuisance, fines or injunctive relief. Issuance of a notice of
violation shall not be a precondition to the filing of a complaint. (Ord. 08-
168, 5-13-2008)
11-5-2: FINES:
The fine for a violation of any subsection of this chapter shall not exceed
five hundred dollars ($500.00). Each day a violation exists constitutes a
separate offense. (Ord. 08-168, 5-13-2008)
11-6 - 11-20: RESERVED:
DIVISION 2. SOLID WASTE DISPOSAL FEE
11-21: PURPOSES:
   A.   It is the purpose of this division to provide a source of revenue to
implement the solid waste management fund for Kane County as authorized by
public act 85-14. The fund will be used for solid waste management purposes,
including long term monitoring and maintenance of landfills, planning,
inspection, enforcement and all other activities consistent with the solid
waste management act of Illinois and the authorized uses of the county landfill
enterprise fund.
   B.   It is the purpose of the county board in establishing the county solid
waste disposal fee to administer said fee equitably and in a manner that will
not create economic hardship. It is the county board's intention that the fee
established hereby, although imposed on the landfill owners or operators, shall
ultimately be borne by the generators of waste being disposed of within Kane
County. (Ord. 08-168, 5-13-2008)
11-22: SOLID WASTE DISPOSAL FEE:
   A.   On or after August 1, 1988, the county shall assess and collect a fee
in the amount set forth herein from the owner or operator of each sanitary
landfill located within the county which is permitted or required to be
permitted by the Illinois EPA to dispose of solid waste, if the sanitary
landfill is located off the site where such waste was produced and if such
sanitary landfill is owned, controlled, and operated by a person other than the
generator of such waste.
   B.   The owner or operator of any sanitary landfill subject to this section
shall pay a fee of sixty cents ($0.60) per cubic yard of nonhazardous solid
waste received at a site, unless the owner or operator weighs the quantity of
the solid waste received with a device for which certification has been
obtained under the weights and measures act, in which case, the fee shall not
exceed one dollar twenty seven cents ($1.27) per ton of solid waste received.
   C.   The amount of said fee shall be determined by the quantities of solid
waste reported as received on the solid waste disposal report required by this
division.
   D.   Payment of the solid waste disposal fee shall be made on a quarterly
basis in conjunction with the solid waste disposal report required by this
division. Payment shall be in the form of a check payable to the treasurer of
Kane County, Illinois, and shall be deposited in the previously established
enterprise surcharge fund. (Ord. 08-168, 5-13-2008)
11-23: EXEMPTIONS FROM FEE:
   A.   The county shall grant exemptions from the fee requirements of this
division for receipt or transport of solid waste meeting all of the following
criteria:
      1.   Receipt of solid waste is pursuant to a written contract between the
owner or operator of the sanitary landfill and some other person, or transport
of the solid waste is pursuant to a written contract between the transporter
and some other person; and
      2.   The contract for receipt or transport of solid waste was lawfully
executed on or before August 1, 1988, and has not been amended at any time
after that date, and by its express terms continues beyond August 2, 1988; and
      3.   The contract for receipt or transport of solid waste established a
fixed fee for compensation, and by its express terms or by implication does not
allow the operator or transporter to pass the fee through to another party, and
does not allow voluntary cancellation or renegotiation of the compensation or
fee during the terms of the contract.
   B.   Exemptions granted under this section shall cause the solid waste
received by an owner or operator of a sanitary landfill to be disregarded in
calculating the volume or weight of solid waste received during a calendar year
under this division.
   C.   Applications for exemptions under this section may be granted
retroactively. Applications for retroactive or prospective exemptions must be
submitted with proof of satisfaction of all criteria necessary to grant the
exemption, and must be received by the county before October 1, 1988.
   D.   It shall be the duty of an owner or operator of a sanitary landfill to
keep accurate records and to prove to the satisfaction of the county the volume
or weight of solid waste received under an exemption during the calendar year.
   E.   Exemptions under this section shall expire upon the expiration, renewal
or amendment of the exempted control, whichever occurs first. (Ord. 08-168, 5-
13-2008)
11-24: SOLID WASTE DISPOSAL REPORT:
   A.   Every owner or operator of a sanitary landfill located within the
county which is permitted, or required to be permitted by the Illinois EPA,
shall file quarterly reports specifying the quantities of waste received and
the fee payment due to the county.
   B.   Said report shall be on the form provided by the county.
   C.   The quarterly solid waste disposal report shall be due on January 15,
April 15, July 15 and October 15 of each calendar year. (Ord. 08-168, 5-13-
2008)
11-25: TERMINATION:
Any owner or operator of a sanitary landfill subject to the provisions of this
division intending to terminate the receipt of solid waste during the calendar
year shall notify the county of such intent. Unless termination of operation is
the result of an emergency order by a regulatory agency or a court of competent
jurisdiction, the owner or operator of a sanitary landfill must notify the
county ninety (90) days in advance of any termination of operation. Such notice
must include the estimated date upon which the landfill will no longer receive
solid waste for disposal. (Ord. 08-168, 5-13-2008)
11-26: APPEALS:
   A.   Any person disputing the payment of the solid waste disposal fee
established by this division may file a protest along with his payment and
request a hearing.
   B.   A hearing shall, thereafter, be provided by the county within sixty
(60) days of said filing. (Ord. 08-168, 5-13-2008)
11-27: EFFECTIVE DATE:
The solid waste disposal fee established by this division shall become
effective on August 1, 1988. The first quarterly solid waste disposal report
shall be due, together with a fee based on that report, on October 15, 1988.
(Ord. 08-168, 5-13-2008)
11-28 - 11-40: RESERVED:
ARTICLE II. LANDFILLS
SECTION:
11-41: Short Title; Applicability
11-42 - 11-55: Reserved
11-41: SHORT TITLE; APPLICABILITY:
This article shall be known as the SANITARY LANDFILL CONTROL ORDINANCE OF KANE
COUNTY, ILLINOIS.
Any sanitary landfill as defined under section 3.41, 415 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 5/1 et seq., of the Illinois environmental protection act (the "act")
shall conform with the act, relevant regulations, and any future amendments to
the act. The act is enforced by the Illinois environmental protection agency,
the attorney general and the state's attorney. (Ord. 08-168, 5-13-2008)
11-42 - 11-55: RESERVED:
ARTICLE III. RULES OF PROCEDURE FOR NEW POLLUTION CONTROL FACILITY SITE
APPROVAL APPLICATION IN UNINCORPORATED AREAS OF KANE COUNTY
SECTION:
11-56: Applicability
11-57: Definitions
11-58: Petitions
11-59: Payment And Administration Of Costs
11-60: Request For Modification Of Specific Requirements
11-61: Participants
11-62: Public Hearing
11-63: Public Comment
11-64: Public Record
11-65: Decision By The County Board
11-66 - 11-107: Reserved
11-56: APPLICABILITY:
This article is applicable to a petition for site location approval of a new
pollution control facility. To the extent a facility, described in a petition,
proposes to manage material which is not a waste, or proposes to conduct an
activity which is excluded from the act's definition of a pollution control
facility, or proposes to conduct an activity which does not require a permit
from the Illinois environmental protection agency, this article does not govern
the petition, and authorization to locate such a facility shall be determined
by the county's other ordinances, including, but not limited to, those related
to zoning, special use, building or environmental requirements, as applicable.
(Ord. 04-393, 10-12-2004; Ord. 08-168, 5-13-2008; Ord. 21-183, 4-13-2021)
11-57: DEFINITIONS:
All words used in this article shall have the same meanings and definitions as
set forth in the environmental protection act, 415 Illinois Compiled Statutes
5/1 et seq. (hereinafter the "act") unless otherwise set forth hereinbelow.
Defined terms in this article need not be capitalized to have the meanings
prescribed to them in this section or the act.

11-58: PETITIONS:
   A.   Filing: The applicant shall file one original and ten (10) copies of
the petition with the Kane County clerk, including all site plans, exhibits,
and maps, in the form described in subsections C and D of this section.
However, only three (3) copies of large-scale engineering drawings are required
to be filed with each request, provided the applicant includes copies of the
engineering drawings reduced to eleven inche by seventeen inche (11" x 17")
paper in each submitted copy of the petition. Additional printed copies of the
application shall be provided by the applicant to the Kane County clerk upon
request for distribution to members of the county board, county staff, or
technical review staff retained by the county for review of the application.
The applicant shall also file thirty-two (32) electronic copies of the complete
petition in a text- recognized and searchable format. The applicant shall
include, with the filing of the petition, the application fee, as described in
section
11-59 of this chapter.
   B.   Procedure After Filing: The clerk, upon receiving said petition, shall
do the following:
      1.   Accept for filing and date stamp as filed any petition that is filed
with the correct number of copies as required by subsection A of this section,
in the form as required by subsection C of this section; with sections
identified as containing materials required by subsections D11.a and D11.b of
this section; and with the application fee as provided in section
11-59 of this chapter. The date on the stamp of the clerk shall be considered
the official filing date for all time limit purposes. Receipt and acceptance of
a petition by the clerk is pro forma, and does not constitute an acknowledgment
that the applicant has complied with the act or this article. Should the
petition be presented to the clerk without the correct number of copies, in the
incorrect form, or without the materials and fee described in this subsection,
the petition shall be rejected by the clerk.
      2.   Upon the filing of a petition, the clerk shall distribute the copies
of the petition to the following parties in the following numbers:
Recipient Printed Copies Electronic Copies
Recipient                      Printed Copies                 Electronic Copies
County board                   2                              25
Office of the state’s attorne1                              1
Director of the Kane County
department of environmental    1, plus 2 drawing sets         1

filing, or when retained by    1                              1

                               1 drawing set
 
      3.   The clerk shall make available a copy of the petition and public
record concerning the petition for public inspection during the normal business
hours of the clerk's office. Additionally, the clerk shall provide to any
person so requesting, copies of the petition or the public record, upon such
person's payment of the actual cost of reproduction.
   C.   Form Of Petitions:
      1.   All petitions shall be in writing on eight and one-half inch by
eleven inch (81/2" x 11"), eight and one-half inch by fourteen inch (81/2" x
14"), or eleven inch by seventeen inch (11" x 17") paper.
      2.   The pages of the application and all exhibits submitted to the
county shall be consecutively numbered.
   D.   Content Of Petitions: The determination of the quality and quantity of
information to be included in a petition is, ultimately, the applicant's to
make, as it is the applicant's burden to demonstrate that the siting criteria
set forth in section 39.2 of the act are met. However, for purposes of this
article, a petition shall contain, at a minimum, the following documents and
information. To the extent such documents and information are based on, in
whole or in part, other information or data, citations to the primary source
shall be provided, so to reasonably enable a member of the public to locate
such information. The content of petitions shall address the following minimum
elements to demonstrate compliance with each of the siting criteria. The
petition shall be organized according to the siting criteria and presented by
the applicant as outlined in this section
11-58 to facilitate review of the petition for compliance with the siting
criteria; any deviation from this organization must be clearly noted by the
applicant to identify the location of the required information within the
petition:
      1.   The facility is necessary to accommodate the waste needs of the area
it is intended to serve:
         a.   Identification of the area to be served by the proposed facility,
including a map showing the extent of the service area the facility is intended
to serve, and a statement of the need for the identified area for such a
facility. Where there is more than one waste proposed to be handled by the
facility, and the service areas are different, the service area for each waste
should be identified as set forth above.
         b.   A description of the type(s) of waste to be received.
         c.   A summary of the current and projected future demographics,
including population, of the service area.
         d.   A calculation of the capacity of the proposed facility, the
estimated daily volume of waste to be received, the sources of said waste, and
the estimated duration of operation at the proposed facility.
         e.   A calculation of the current amount of waste generated and
disposed within the service area and an estimate of the amount of waste to be
generated and disposed within the service area for the next twenty (20) years.
The impact of future recycling and waste reduction efforts on volumes disposed
should be addressed.
         f.   A calculation of the current amount of waste exported out of and
imported into the service area.
         g.   A calculation of the permitted disposal capacity available within
the service area.
         h.   A list and map showing all existing facilities and not existing,
but permitted for development, facilities which manage the same waste streams
as the proposed facility, located within or serving or capable of serving the
area proposed to be served (i.e., all facilities within or at the same distance
from the outer perimeter of the service area, as the proposed facility is from
the most distant point of its service area) and, with respect to each such
facility, the following information shall be provided on the list (not the
map): location, size, owner and operator, type of pollution control facility,
daily intake or throughput, as applicable, remaining capacity, probable life of
the facility, types of wastes received and authorized to be received, IEPA
facility number (where applicable), and sources for the information presented
concerning the facilities. The map should identify the facility by the same
name used on the list, such that the map can be cross referenced with the list.
         i.   A statement of the economic benefits of the proposed facility.
         j.   Documentation of all methods and data sources used in
calculations demonstrating need shall be presented.
      2.   The facility is so designed, located, and proposed to be operated
that the public health, safety, and welfare will be protected:
         a.   Site general information and legal description.
            (1)   The identification as well as current address of the
applicant, all landowners and the operator for the proposed facility. If the
proposed site is owned by a land trust, each beneficiary of the land trust must
be identified and their name and address listed, and the extent of their
interest must be defined. Indicate whether or not the applicant, if not the
property owner, is to purchase or lease the site. If the site is to be leased,
state the term of years of any lease for the proposed site and attach the lease
and any amendments to said lease. Also indicate whether the applicant, the
landowner and the operator is a corporation, limited liability company,
partnership, individual or unit of government. In the case of a partnership,
submit the names of all partners. In the case of a corporation, submit the
names and addresses of all officers and directors, and the names and addresses
of all shareholders owning five percent (5%) or more of the capital stock of
the corporation. In the case of a corporation, attach articles of incorporation
and a certified copy from the secretary of state, of the entity's incorporation
in the state of Illinois or, if not incorporated in the state of Illinois, its
license to do business in the state of Illinois as exhibits. In the event that
forty percent (40%) or more shares of a corporation are owned by another
corporation ("owning corporation"), all of the above listed disclosures and
requirements regarding corporations shall be applicable to the owning
corporation.
            (2)   Property title search, and identification of any covenants
recorded with the property deed.
            (3)   The legal description of the proposed site and a street
address as well as other reasonable descriptions of where the proposed site is
located. A plat of survey of the proposed facility boundary must be attached to
the petition, and a map or description stating existing zoning of the property,
as well as adjacent property zoning.
            (4)   A brief description of the proposed facility, its operation,
the expected longevity thereof and copies of any proposed or actual agreements
for host fees or incentives offered or agreed to by the applicant with the
county or any other person or entity.
            (5)   A description of the general characteristics of the site
(open field, gravel pit, quarry, strip mine, swamp, floodplain, etc.) and the
historical uses of the property.
            (6)   A detailed topographic survey of the subject site and the
surrounding area, within one thousand five hundred feet (1,500') of the
property lines of the proposed site, which indicates land use and, if
applicable, the boundary of the 100-year floodplain. Include also as an exhibit
a copy of the United States geological survey topographic quadrangle map of the
area which includes the proposed site, with an outline of the location
indicated therein.
         b.   Site plan(s) showing details of the proposed facility. Unless
stated otherwise below, the information is to be provided for the proposed site
of the facility (i.e., within the site property lines). Details to be shown
include, but are not limited to, the following information:
            (1)   The site plan shall be drawn on a topographic map to a scale
no smaller than one inch equals two hundred feet (1" = 200') with a two foot
(2') contour interval;
            (2)   Engineering cross sections;
            (3)   Fences, buildings and other structures;
            (4)   Roads, entrances and driveways;
            (5)   Existing and proposed underground or aboveground storage
tanks (identified as such), identifying, if applicable, which are known to be
out of operation or abandoned;
            (6)   Location of property lines of neighboring properties and
properties whose owners were provided notice pursuant to section 39.2(b) of the
act;
            (7)   Existing and proposed utility lines (identified as such and
identified as to type of utility), indicating which are above and which are
below the ground;
            (8)   Surface water drainageways, including, but not limited to,
drain tiles, creeks, etc.;
            (9)   Boundaries of prior waste disposal areas and any areas of
known soil, surface water or groundwater contamination;
            (10)   If the proposed facility is a landfill, soil boring
locations within the property lines of the proposed site, and within two
hundred feet (200') of the proposed site; and
            (11)   All known and proposed wells (identified as such), whether
potable, monitoring, or other, within the proposed site and, if the proposed
facility is a landfill, within one thousand five hundred feet (1,500') of the
property line of the proposed site.
         c.   Information demonstrating compliance with applicable regulatory
location standards, including (as applicable):
            (1)   Setbacks from residential properties, property lines,
roadways, and other features;
            (2)   Proximity to airports;
            (3)   Endangered species and historic preservation reviews;
            (4)   Wetlands locations, including any mitigation to be completed
if wetlands are present on the site; and
            (5)   Map identifying, within one and one-half (1.5) miles of the
proposed facility, any surface or subsurface mining activities in the area,
residential (single-family or multiple-family) housing areas, schools,
hospitals, nursing or extended care facilities, daycare or other childcare
facilities, historic or architectural or archaeological resources identified by
the Illinois historic preservation agency, threatened or endangered species
habitats, parks, recreational areas, nature preserves, and airports.
            (6)   Any additional information to demonstrate that the proposed
facility is so located in such a manner that the public health, safety and
welfare will be protected, in addition to that which is required herein.
         d.   Site design information providing description of the design
criteria and design features of the facility, including (as applicable):
            (1)   Site roadway and vehicle maneuvering features including
entrance(s) and exit(s), access roads, interior traffic circulation areas,
parking, and vehicle stacking / queuing;
            (2)   Weigh station location and design;
            (3)   Proposed structure(s) and detailed floor plan(s);
            (4)   Office, maintenance, and other supporting structures;
            (5)   Security features and measures to be implemented;
            (6)   Utilities to be utilized for facility operations and whether
they are currently present onsite or proposed to be located onsite;
            (7)   Water supply and capacity requirements;
            (8)   Surface water control;
            (9)   Documentation detailing stormwater management measures,
including:
               (A)   Design based on requirements of the 100-year, 24-hour
storm;
               (B)   Basin design(s) and release rate(s);
               (C)   Sediment control measures, both during and after
construction;
               (D)   Erosion control measures, both during and after
construction;
               (E)   Drainage flow on-site and off-site; and
               (F)   Demonstration of compliance with the Kane County soil
erosion and sediment control ordinance, the Kane County stormwater ordinance
(ordinance 19-151, as amended), and the technical policy statements associated
therewith;
            (10)   Liner design, including proposed soil and/or geomembrane
specifications;
            (11)   Leachate collection system, including:
               (A)   Type, location and construction of the subsurface
collection system;
               (B)   Written narrative describing methods and processes of the
collection, management and treatment of the leachate;
               (C)   Program for monitoring effectiveness of the collection,
management and treatment of the leachate; and
               (D)   Discharge points of effluent;
            (12)   Final cover system, including proposed soil and/or
geomembrane specifications;
            (13)   All monitoring systems, which may include but not be limited
to, stormwater, security, vector control, noise, litter, odor, groundwater,
surface water, and air, including:
               (A)   Techniques, location and construction;
               (B)   Frequency of sampling and analysis; and
               (C)   Future corrective action program;
            (14)   Gas control system;
            (15)   Air emissions control;
            (16)   Facility construction quality assurance and quality control
program; and
            (17)   If the proposed facility is a landfill, a description of the
proposed site geology and hydrogeology, including:
               (A)   A detailed description of each geologic unit found within
the site including geologic, seismic, geotechnical, and hydrologic properties;
               (B)   A description of all water bearing strata within the site
including potentiometric maps, groundwater flow velocities, gradients and
directions;
               (C)   Geologic cross sections of the site illustrating all water
bearing strata, water elevations, confining units and all discernable geologic
units;
               (D)   Complete subsurface investigation results including
borings below the site and the following information as a result of these
borings:
                  i.   Types and thicknesses of soil units encountered and the
depth of and the type of bedrock encountered;
                  ii.   As to each boring sample taken, provide at a minimum
the following information:
                     (a)   Unified soil classification;
                     (b)   Index and engineering properties test results for
representative samples;
                     (c)   Standard Procter moisture-density tests for any soil
material proposed to be used for liner and cover construction;
                     (d)   Hydraulic conductivity based on field and/or
laboratory determinations, including a determination of the soil proposed for
liner and cover using the proposed soil liner and cover construction
specifications; and
                     (e)   Ion exchange capacity and ability to absorb and
"fix" heavy metal ions;
                  iii.   Geological and geotechnical engineering evaluation;
               (E)   Background analysis for groundwater, surface water and
air, or a statement as to why such analysis is not needed or appropriate for
the county's review of the proposed site. Where background analysis is
provided, identify the locations and dates of the background samples, the types
of media sampled (e.g., groundwater, surface water, soil, air), and the depth
at which the sample was taken; and
            (18)   Any additional information to demonstrate that the proposed
facility is so designed in such a manner that the public health, safety and
welfare will be protected, in addition to that which is required herein.
         e.   A statement of the plan of operation for the proposed facility,
including (as applicable):
            (1)   Type of facility including method of landfilling,
incineration, resource recovery, recycling, transfer, or other proposed
storage, process, treatment or management, including identification of any
proposed process flows, storage, treatment, disposal, consolidation, or other
waste management activity.
            (2)   Hours of operation.
            (3)   A description of the types of wastes or other materials
proposed to be received or produced at the facility (including any the
applicant claims are not subject to the requirement for site location approval
under the act, and a notation next to any such wastes or materials identified
as such) and, if applicable, identification of the time frame when such waste
or materials are proposed to be received or produced.
            (4)   For each type of waste or material proposed to be received or
produced at the facility, provide:
               (A)   The maximum daily receipt and throughput;
               (B)   Process capacity, including a materials flow analysis and
capacity analysis to demonstrate the facility can safely and adequately manage
the maximum daily receipts and throughput (in weight/volume and vehicles); and
               (C)   Production.
            (5)   Proposed life of the facility.
            (6)   Traffic patterns and flows onsite.
            (7)   Description of any overnight storage of waste or materials
onsite.
            (8)   Identification of disposal or processing sites for any
materials not disposed or used onsite.
            (9)   Identification of proposed railroad activities.
            (10)   Waste screening procedures, including:
               (A)   Plans for identification and verification of waste
received;
               (B)   Plans for identification of unacceptable waste, soils or
other material and removal of same;
               (C)   Plans for chemical analysis of waste, if applicable; and
               (D)   Load checking program and procedures.
            (11)   Leachate collection, management and treatment system or
plan.
            (12)   Landfill gas collection, management, and treatment system or
plan.
            (13)   Personnel requirements, including number of full and part
time employees, which personnel positions and in what numbers are considered
minimally necessary for facility operation.
            (14)   Equipment requirements.
            (15)   Fueling procedures for all onsite equipment and vehicles.
            (16)   Facility cleaning and maintenance.
            (17)   Litter, vector, dust, odor and noise control procedures.
            (18)   Indoor and outdoor air quality procedures and air emission
monitoring system(s).
            (19)   Fire and emergency management control procedures.
            (20)   Corrective actions for spills and other operational
accidents.
            (21)   Lockout / tagout procedures.
            (22)   Wastewater generation and handling, including:
               (A)   Wastewater generation calculations;
               (B)   Wastewater storage procedures; and
               (C)   Wastewater disposal / treatment procedures.
            (23)   Operational contingency plans, including:
               (A)   Equipment failure;
               (B)   Interruption of utility service; and
               (C)   Inclement weather.
            (24)   Record-keeping procedures, including:
               (A)   Daily tonnage receipts by waste type;
               (B)   In-county daily tonnage receipts;
               (C)   All regulatory correspondence;
               (D)   All environmental and regulatory inspections;
               (E)   Wastewater generation and disposal records;
               (F)   Load inspection and load discrepancy records; and
               (G)   Accident records.
            (25)   The stages of development or use.
            (26)   A closure plan including:
               (A)   Equipment cleaning and removal procedures;
               (B)   Cost estimate for closure;
               (C)   Schedule for closure;
               (D)   Required post-closure care responsibilities and
procedures; and
               (E)   Demonstration of financial assurance measure(s) to be
utilized.
            (27)   An end use plan describing the future use(s) of the property
following closure and completion of any post-closure care obligations. The end
use plan should include:
               (A)   Identification of the planned or potential use of the
property;
               (B)   Additional activities that would be required to prepare
the property for the proposed use following completion of closure and post-
closure care as applicable; and
               (C)   Identification of the parties to be responsible for
coordination, approval, and development of the use (e.g., applicant, local
government(s) including the county and/or nearby municipalities, other private
entities, etc.).
            (28)   Any additional information to demonstrate that the proposed
facility is proposed to be operated in such a manner that the public health,
safety and welfare will be protected, in addition to that which is required
herein.
      3.   The facility is located so as to minimize the incompatibility with
the character of the surrounding area and to minimize the effect on the value
of the surrounding property:
         a.   Adjacent and surrounding zoning and land uses within one and one-
half (1.5) miles of the property line of the site.
         b.   Appearance of proposed final development and/or final design
grades relative to surrounding properties.
         c.   Proposed use after operation (i.e., end use) including changes in
topography and all new surface features.
         d.   A description of how the applicant will minimize the effect of
traffic flow to and from the proposed facility on the character of the area
through which the traffic is proposed to pass and property values.
         e.   A description of the external materials to be used in
construction of the proposed facility.
         f.   A description of any proposed landscaping or facility screening.
         g.   Property values of surrounding property, and a property value
impact analysis conducted by a certified real estate appraiser demonstrating
the proposed facility will minimize the impact on the value of the surrounding
property.
      4.   The facility is located outside the boundary of the 100-year
floodplain or the site is flood-proofed:
         a.   Location of the 100-year floodplain;
         b.   A statement as to whether the facility is located outside the
boundary of the 100-year floodplain or the site is floodproofed; and
         c.   Documentation supporting such statement.
      5.   The plan of operations for the facility is designed to minimize the
danger to the surrounding area from fire, spills or other operational
accidents:
         a.   Provide documentation detailing, at a minimum:
            (1)   Accident prevention plan, including plans for spill control
and containment;
            (2)   Fire prevention plan;
            (3)   Proposed responses to spills and other operational accidents;
            (4)   An emergency response plan for the proposed site, including,
but not limited to, documentation detailing procedures to be used in case of a
release or spill, as to:
               (A)   Notification of appropriate agencies and personnel;
               (B)   Containment procedures; and
               (C)   Evacuation procedures for the facility and the surrounding
area.
      6.   The traffic patterns to or from the facility are so designed as to
minimize the impact on existing traffic flows:
         a.   Provide a traffic study regarding the proposed site including:
            (1)   Methodology used to identify the traffic characteristics of
the facility, perform traffic assignment and analysis, and evaluate roadway and
site access requirements;
            (2)   Evaluation of site accessibility, including site location,
area roadways, proposed roadway improvements, and existing traffic volumes;
            (3)   The anticipated number and type of vehicles, their size,
weight, and directional distribution indicating where vehicles are traveling
from and to as they enter and exit the facility;
            (4)   The number of each type of vehicle expected or intended to
enter or exit the facility, broken down by each hour of the day. If the number
of vehicles is expected or intended to be greater or less on particular days of
the week, identify those days, the numbers of vehicles, and where it includes
vehicles other than passenger automobiles, include the hourly analysis for each
day of the week;
            (5)   Proposed traffic route(s) or plan for vehicles entering and
exiting the facility, from the point where the vehicles enter or exit the
county to the point where the vehicles enter or exit the proposed facility,
including, but not limited to identification of all roadways within the county
which the vehicles will utilize for access to the site and the anticipated
primary routing to disposal facilities when exiting the site where applicable.
Where it is expected that passenger automobiles will be utilized only to bring
passengers to and from the site and the automobile traffic is not the majority
of traffic to or from the site, then such automobile traffic may be excluded
from the traffic routes described;
            (6)   Accident history of key intersections to and from the
facility; and
            (7)   Gap study for key intersections to and from the facility and
the facility entrance and exit.
      7.   If the facility will be treating, storing, or disposing of hazardous
waste, an emergency response plan exists for the facility which includes
notification, containment, and evacuation procedures to be used in case of an
accidental release:
         a.   If the site is a proposed hazardous waste facility, provide a
copy of the resource conservation recovery act contingency plan. Hazardous
waste treatment and/or disposal facilities warrant an increased level of
scrutiny that will require documentation beyond the scope of this article.
      8.   If the facility is to be located in a county where the county board
has adopted a solid waste management plan consistent with the planning
requirements of the local solid waste disposal act or the solid waste planning
and recycling act, the facility is consistent with that plan:
         a.   A statement by the applicant demonstrating that the proposed
facility is consistent with the county's solid waste management plan, including
any updates of that plan (e.g., five (5) year update).
      9.   If the facility will be located within a regulated recharge area,
any applicable requirements specified by the Illinois pollution control board
for such areas have been met:
         a.   The applicant shall provide documentation detailing compliance
with any and all applicable requirements specified by the Illinois pollution
control board should the facility be located within a regulated recharge area.
      10.   Operator information and experience, including:
         a.   A statement describing the past operating experience of the
applicant (and any subsidiary, parent corporation, or subsidiary of the parent
corporation), in the field of solid waste management and identify all
experience in the state of Illinois, including, but not limited to, a list of
all existing, planned or closed facilities which manage, treat, store,
consolidate or dispose of waste; the capacity of such facility established by
operational feasibility, permit and siting condition; the date and community
which granted site location approval; the street address of the facility; any
IEPA number assigned to identify the facility; and identification over the past
ten (10) years of any notices of violation of federal, state or local
government law, ordinance, rule, regulation, permit or permit condition, or
condition on site location approval received at the facility, a description of
such notices of violation (including citation), and a description of the
resolution, if any, of such alleged violations. List all litigation in which
the applicant has been involved in the connection with the foregoing. State
also if the applicant has ever voluntarily or involuntarily closed a pollution
control facility in Illinois, and if so, the name and location of said facility
and the dates upon which said closing was commenced and completed.
         b.   Furnish a statement citing the past record of convictions or
admissions of violations of the applicant over the past ten (10) years,
including, but not limited to, any of its current officers and directors, and
any of a subsidiary, parent corporation, or subsidiary of the parent
corporation. Said statement shall include, but not be limited to, a citation of
the applicable statute or ordinance violated; a brief written summary of the
violation or conviction; and the penalty imposed. As to the past record of
convictions or admissions of violations of the applicant, its officers or
directors, or any subsidiary or parent corporation, or subsidiary of the parent
corporation, provide documentation detailing:
            (1)   A description of each conviction or admission of violations,
either criminal or civil, of any foreign, federal, state or local law, statute,
regulation, or ordinance of: 1) the applicant, 2) any subsidiary corporation of
the applicant, 3) any parent corporation of the applicant, 4) any subsidiary of
the parent corporation, or 5) the current officers and directors of the
applicant, including, but not limited to, the identification of the law,
statute, regulation or ordinance violated and the penalty imposed.
            (2)   To the extent such conviction or admission of violation
involved or was related to operation of a pollution control facility or waste
management, provide a description of the type of facility, including, but not
limited to, identification of the location of the facility.
            (3)   A description of enforcement actions or lawsuits brought, if
any, by any government entity or any person.
            (4)   Remedial action taken, if any, as a result of, in conjunction
with, or as part of a settlement of any conviction or admission of violation.
         c.   In addition to the above, the petition shall be accompanied by
all documents, if any, submitted as of the date of filing to the IEPA in
connection with the application except trade secrets as determined under 415
Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/7.1.
      11.   Additional information to be submitted with the petition:
         a.   Proof of service evidencing that copies of said petition were
served upon each municipality whose official boundaries are within one and one-
half (1.5) miles of the property line of the proposed facility.
         b.   Proof of notice, pursuant to section 39.2(b) of the act.
         c.   Provide all physical evidence, including, but not limited to,
studies; maps, reports; permits or exhibits which the applicant desires the
county board to consider at the public hearing. It is intended that the
applicant provide a full and complete disclosure of his case to facilitate
early review and analysis by all participants.
         d.   The petition shall be signed by the applicant, landowners,
operator, engineer registered in the state of Illinois under the Illinois
professional engineering practice act, land surveyor and any other technical
consultant responsible for drafting all or portions of the petition. (Ord. 04-
393, 10-12-2004; Ord. 08-168, 5-13-2008; Ord. 21-183, 4-13-2021)
11-59: PAYMENT AND ADMINISTRATION OF COSTS:
   A.   Initial Costs And Fees Deposit: At the time of filing a petition, the
applicant shall submit to the clerk a costs deposit in the form of a certified
or cashier's check made payable to "Kane County Treasurer", to defray the
reasonable and necessary fees and costs of the county in processing and
responding to the petition, and any appeal from the county's decision on the
petition, including, but not limited to, the fees and cost of: county employee
or staff review time, expert witnesses, scientific testing, records or other
investigations, data searches, notices, court reporters, transcription costs,
consultants and attorneys, the hearing officer, other expenses incurred by the
county or any county officer or official in conducting the review of the
petition, the public hearing, the county's site location decision, and any
appeal of the county's site location decision. The amount of the initial costs
and fees deposit depends on the type of facility which the applicant proposes:
 
Landfill, including expansion $250,000.00
Incinerator                   250,000.00
Transfer station              150,000.00
Storage facility              75,000.00
Other                         35,000.00
 
   B.   Additional Initial Costs And Fees Deposit For Hazardous Waste
Facilities: In addition to the initial costs and fees deposit stated in
subsection A of this section, a facility which proposes to manage hazardous
waste will be subject to an additional initial fee of one hundred fifty
thousand dollars ($150,000.00) above the amounts listed in subsection A of this
section.
   C.   Subsequent Costs And Fees Deposits: Should there be any additional
costs incurred by the county or any county officer over the amount paid by the
applicant in the initial costs and fees deposit (including, but not limited to,
fees and costs associated with any appeal of a county decision on the petition)
the applicant shall bear any and all additional costs. If at any time, the
balance of the initial costs and fees deposit is reduced to a figure less than
twenty thousand dollars ($20,000.00) at any time prior to the conclusion of the
review, hearing, decision and appeal (if any) of the petition, the applicant,
upon notice from the county, shall contribute an additional twenty five
thousand dollars ($25,000.00), unless a lesser sum is needed and the county's
notice to the applicant identifies the lesser sum. The applicant, within five
(5) business days of receiving such notice, shall pay the amount requested to
the county to supplement the initial costs and fees deposit.
   D.   Amendment Costs And Fees: In the event the applicant files an amendment
in accordance with 415 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/39.2(e), an additional
initial costs and fees deposit of fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) shall be
delivered to the clerk at the same time as the filing of the amendment, and
such deposit shall be in the same form as described in subsection A of this
section.
   E.   Fees And Expenses Incurred By County: All fees and expenses incurred by
the county as described in subsection A of this section, shall be paid from the
fees and costs deposits as provided herein:
      1.   Records of county incurred fees and costs, including, but not
limited to, relevant time records of county employees and staff and county
consultants, may be submitted by the persons creating such records to the
director of the county finance department on a no more frequent than monthly
basis.
      2.   The director of the county finance department or his/her designee,
shall organize the records and prepare and submit periodic reports to the
county board chairman, clerk and the applicant, of invoices to or expenditures
by the county. The actual invoices and bills submitted to the director of the
county finance department may be, but are not required to be, included in the
report submitted to the county board chairman, clerk and applicant only if all
privileged and confidential information has been redacted. Inadvertent
disclosure of confidential or privileged information by the director of the
county finance department is not a waiver of confidentiality or privilege.
      3.   Not earlier than ten (10) calendar days after the submittal of each
report, described in subsection E2 of this section, to the county board
chairman, clerk and applicant, and provided the county board has not instructed
the director of the county department of finance to do otherwise, the director
may draw upon the applicant's costs and fees deposits in the amount of the
reported incurred costs and fees.
      4.   In determining the fees to be paid to the county to reimburse the
county for its employees' or staff's time involved in matters concerning the
petition, hearings on the petition, or appeals (if any), the director of the
county department of finance shall determine a rate for each employee who
submits a record of his/her time to the director, including in such rate, all
costs of the county in compensating such employee or staff member, such as
salary or wage, benefits and retirement. The director shall include the rate it
calculates per employee in the report described in subsection E2 of this
section.
      5.   Any portion of the fees and costs deposits that remains unexpended
at the conclusion of the site location review process (including all appeals
and resolution of any applicant challenge to fees or costs), shall be returned
to the applicant.
      6.   An applicant may, within five (5) calendar days of its receipt of a
report under subsection E2 of this section, deliver to the director of the
county finance department a written challenge to the necessity or
reasonableness of a fee or cost set forth in the report. The challenge shall
specify all of its basis, reasons or objections, or such basis, reasons or
objections are waived. In addition, any challenge to fees or costs not timely
raised pursuant to this subsection are waived. Challenged fees or costs shall,
at the discretion of the director of the department of finance, be paid,
despite the challenge by the applicant, however, the director's utilization of
such discretion shall not be evidence of the reasonableness, unreasonableness,
necessity or nonnecessity of such fees or costs. (Ord. 04-393, 10-12-2004; Ord.
08-168, 5-13-2008; Ord. 21-183, 4-13-2021)
11-60: REQUEST FOR MODIFICATION OF SPECIFIC REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Upon receipt of a written request from a potential applicant, specific
requirements within this article may be modified by the chair of the Kane
County board, with the advice and consent of the Kane County solid waste
committee, under the following conditions:
      1.   The proposed facility's primary purpose is to accept a waste
material of no more than one thousand (1,000) tons per day and through
composting, processing or other method(s) produces a marketable product for
resale.
The chair of the Kane County board will first determine whether the request for
an amendment is warranted. If the chairman decides a revision is warranted, the
request will be presented to the solid waste committee for advice and consent.
If the chairman of the Kane County board decides the request for an amendment
is or is not warranted, after consultation with the solid waste committee, the
matter will be referred to the county board for its decision by an affirmative
vote of a majority of the members of the county board whether to approve or
deny the request.
The decision of whether a proposed facility is warranted for consideration
under this provision by the Kane County board, and the decision to modify this
article under this provision by the county board is final and cannot be
appealed. (Ord. 04-393, 10-12-2004; Ord. 08-168, 5-13-2008; Ord. 21-183, 4-13-
2021)
11-61: PARTICIPANTS:
   A.   Participant: The applicant is a participant.
   B.   Employees Participating In Public Hearings: The county, its employees
and staff, and any experts, consultants, investigators or attorneys hired by
the county to review, investigate, present at hearing, or otherwise work for
the county concerning the petition, are participants. To the extent the county
employees and staff wish to participate in the public hearings outside their
roles or employment with the county, they must submit a notice of
participation, as do other members of the public.
   C.   Notice Of Participation: Any person other than described in subsections
A and B of this section, must file a written notification of intent to
participate (notice of participation), on a form provided by the clerk, with
the clerk before the start of the first day of public hearing; or, to the
hearing officer, after the start and before the adjournment of the first day of
public hearing. Such notification shall state, at a minimum, the name, address,
daytime phone number and, if available, facsimile number and e-mail address of
the person filing the notice of participation, whether the person will be
participating on his/her own behalf or as a representative/spokesperson of
another person or entity (and if on behalf of another person or entity,
identify the name of that person or entity), whether the person (or the entity
or association he/she represents) will be represented by an attorney during the
public hearings, and whether the person intends on providing oral testimony or
comment during the public hearing.
   D.   Participant Rights: Participants have the right to present sworn
testimony and witnesses; provide unsworn, oral comment during the public
hearing (subject to the hearing officer's judgment and consistent with
fundamental fairness); if represented by an attorney, participants have the
right to have their attorney cross examine witnesses who provide sworn
testimony; if not represented by an attorney, participants have the right to
submit to the hearing officer written questions to the hearing officer to be
asked of the witnesses at the hearing officer's discretion as to whether and
how such questions are to be posed. An attorney representing a participant must
be licensed and in good standing to practice law in the state of Illinois, or
if licensed and in good standing to practice law in another state which is part
of the United States, shall be allowed to serve as an attorney for a
participant upon motion made to and acted upon by the hearing officer at the
hearing officer's discretion. (Ord. 04-393, 10-12-2004; Ord. 08-168, 5-13-2008;
Ord. 21-183, 4-13-2021)
11-62: PUBLIC HEARING:
   A.   No sooner than ninety (90) days but no later than one hundred twenty
(120) days from the date the petition was filed with the clerk, a public
hearing shall be held by the county board. One member of the county board shall
constitute a quorum for the purpose of holding such a public hearing. They will
observe the proceedings.
   B.   The chairman of the county board shall determine the date, time and
location upon which such public hearing shall be held, but in any event the
initial public hearing must be scheduled no sooner than ninety (90) days but no
later than one hundred twenty (120) days from the date the petition was filed
with the clerk.
   C.   The chairman of the county board shall notify the clerk of the date
upon which such hearing shall be held and shall request the clerk to cause
notice of such hearing to be made as follows. Upon receipt of such request, the
clerk shall cause the publication of notice pursuant to the following
requirements:
      1.   By publication of two (2) legal notices in a newspaper of general
circulation published in the county. One such notice shall be published no
later than sixty (60) days from the date the petition was filed and one such
notice shall be published no later than seventy five (75) days from the date
the petition was filed.
      2.   Such notices shall consist of the following information which,
except for subsections C2h through C2j of this section, must be disclosed by
the applicant in the petition:
         a.   The name and address of the person, partnership or corporation
requesting site location approval;
         b.   The name and address of the owner of the site, and in case
ownership is in a land trust, the names of the beneficiaries of said trust;
         c.   The legal description of the site;
         d.   The street address of the property, and if there is no street
address applicable to the property, a description of the site with reference to
location, ownership or occupancy or in some other manner that will reasonably
identify the property to residents of the neighborhood;
         e.   The nature and size of the proposed facility;
         f.   The nature of the activity proposed;
         g.   The probable life of the proposed activity and facility;
         h.   The time and date of the public hearing(s);
         i.   The location(s) of the public hearing(s);
         j.   A statement that all copies of evidence other than testimony to
be submitted at the public hearing(s) must be filed with the county clerk at
least seven (7) days before the date of the first public hearing.
      3.   A copy of the notice shall also be sent, by certified mail to:
         a.   All members of the general assembly from the district in which
the proposed facility is located;
         b.   The Illinois environmental protection agency;
         c.   All municipalities and townships within one and one-half (11/2)
miles of the property line of the proposed facility (such property line to be
determined from the petition).
      4.   AAdditional notice of the public hearing may be given by publishing
a notice in a newspaper of general circulation published as a display ad at
least once during the week preceding the public hearing. Such notice shall
consist of all items described in subsections C2a through C2j of this section
except for subsection C2c of this section.
   D.   Prior to the date of the first public hearing, the chairman of the
county board and the Kane County state's attorney shall, jointly, appoint the
hearing officer for the public hearing on the petition. The hearing officer
shall preside over the public hearing and shall make any decisions concerning
the admission of evidence and the manner in which the hearing is conducted
subject to this article. The hearing officer shall make all decisions and
rulings in accordance with the concept of fundamental fairness. The hearing
officer may exclude irrelevant, immaterial, or unduly repetitious testimony. No
ruling of the hearing officer shall be appealable to the county board. All
testimony shall be in the presence of a certified court reporter who shall
report all proceedings regarding consideration of the petition. The hearing
officer shall have the following powers or duties:
      1.   Administer oaths and affirmations.
      2.   Conduct a public meeting, prior to the start of the public hearings,
to explain the public hearing and site location review process. If the hearing
officer decides to hold such a meeting, notice shall be given in a newspaper of
general circulation one week prior to the meeting and such notice shall
expressly state that it is an informational meeting concerning the procedure to
be used at the public hearing and the site location review process, and that it
is not a public hearing at which evidence will be taken for purposes of making
a determination in accordance with the act.
      3.   Arrange for the presence of a certified court reporter to attend and
transcribe the conduct of all public hearings for the public record.
      4.   Regulate the course of the hearing, including, but not limited to,
controlling the order of proceedings, consistent with this article.
      5.   Require a witness to state his/her position either for, against, or
undecided as respects the proposed facility.
      6.   Examine a witness and direct a witness to testify.
      7.   Establish reasonable limits on the duration of public hearing
consistent with the act and this article, including, but not limited to, the
reasonable limitation of sworn testimony, unsworn oral comment, direct and
cross examination of any witnesses, and the limitation of repetitive or
cumulative testimony and questioning.
      8.   Rule upon objections and evidentiary questions, with the
understanding that such rulings must be consistent with fundamental fairness,
but need not be in strict compliance with the Illinois supreme court, Illinois
code of civil procedure, or any local rules of evidence governing a civil
judicial trial in the state of Illinois, county of Kane.
      9.   Allow the introduction of late filed evidence, be it written or
testimonial, on behalf of any participant, provided good cause is shown for the
late filing, the evidence is offered in and is relevant to the rebuttal portion
of the participant's case, and evidence was filed with the clerk at least one
day before the public hearing at which it is offered, and fundamental fairness
to all parties will be preserved.
      10.   No ruling of the hearing officer, made during the course of the
public hearing, shall be appealable to the county board.
      11.   The hearing officer may confer with the county board concerning the
petition, between the time of the filing of the petition and the county board's
decision on the petition. However, the hearing officer may not confer with the
participants (applicant and county included, but the county board members, the
director of the county department of environmental and water resources, and the
director of the county division of transportation are not included in this
restriction) concerning the petition, unless such conference takes place during
the public hearing. The only additional exception from this restriction is that
the hearing officer may confer with the clerk about the upkeep or status of the
public record, make a request to review or copy the public record, or confer
with the clerk regarding the scheduling of the hearings.
      12.   At the conclusion of the public hearing and after consideration of
all timely filed written comments, submit written findings (of law or fact) to
the county board and file a copy of such findings with the clerk. Such written
findings may be submitted to the county board jointly with the director of the
county department of environmental management and the director of the county
division of transportation.
      13.   The hearing officer does not have the right or the power to vote,
as a county board member votes, on the petition.
   E.   The chairman of the county board shall also appoint the director of the
county department of environmental and water resources and the director of the
county division of transportation, as well as any technical consultant retained
by the county to advise it with respect to review of the petition, as technical
representatives of the county board, for purposes of the public hearing. These
directors and technical consultant(s) have the following rights, obligations or
powers for purposes of the public hearing:
      1.   The directors shall attend each day of public hearing, unless
excused by the county board chairman.
      2.   The directors may ask a witness questions.
      3.   The directors and technical consultant(s) may, at the conclusion of
the public hearing and after consideration of all timely filed written
comments, submit written findings and recommendations to the county board. Such
written findings and recommendations may be submitted to the county board
jointly with the hearing officer.
      4.   The directors and technical consultant(s) do not have the right or
the power to vote, as a county board member votes, on the petition.
      5.   The directors and technical consultant(s) may not confer with the
participants (including applicant, county, county board members, and hearing
officer) concerning the petition, unless such conference takes place during the
public hearing. The only additional exception from this restriction is that the
directors may confer with the clerk about the status of the public record, the
hearing schedule, or make a request to the clerk to review or copy the public
record.
   F.   All reports, studies, exhibits or other evidence or copies thereof,
other than testimony, which any participant desires to submit for the record at
the public hearing must be filed with the clerk at least seven (7) calendar
days before the public hearing and shall be available for public inspection in
the office of the clerk. In the event that the seventh day prior to the date
set for public hearing falls on a Saturday, Sunday or holiday, the next working
day shall be considered the day that reports, studies and exhibits must be
filed.
   G.   Conduct of the public hearing shall be substantially as follows:
      1.   Call to order.
      2.   Introduction of the county board members who are present, the
hearing officer, the director of the county division of transportation, and the
director of the county department of environmental and water resources, and any
technical consultant(s) retained by the county, if present.
      3.   Recognition of the applicant and identification of the petition.
      4.   Recognition of fees, notices, and date of filing of the petition.
      5.   Recognition of the county.
      6.   Recognition of all other participants who have filed the notice of
participation, pursuant to subsection
11-61C of this chapter.
      7.   Recognition of all reports, exhibits, maps or documents of record as
filed pursuant to subsection F of this section.
      8.   The applicant, the county and participants may make an opening
statement.
      9.   The county board shall then hear testimony from the applicant and/or
any witnesses the applicant may wish to call. Upon the close of the applicant's
testimony, participants, other than the applicant or the county, may present
sworn testimony, including any witnesses and evidence they wish to present.
      10.   After the close of the applicant's and participants' cases as
described in subsection G9 of this section, the county may present any
witnesses and evidence it wishes to present.
      11.   Rebuttal testimony and evidence will be allowed at the discretion
of the hearing officer, but if it is allowed, it will be presented in the same
order as described in subsections G9 and G10 of this section.
      12.   Following rebuttal testimony, if any, any participant who wishes to
present unsworn oral comment may then present such comment to the county board.
      13.   Closing statements, if any, by participants, including the
applicant and county, who presented evidence or testimony at or questioned
witnesses during the public hearing.
      14.   Rebuttal statement, if any, by the applicant, subject to
limitations as imposed by the hearing officer.
      15.   Hearing closed.
   H.   All witnesses who testify under oath, shall be subject to reasonable
questioning as follows: direct, cross examination, redirect, recross, etc.
   I.   At any time during the public hearings, any county board member, the
hearing officer, the director of the division of transportation, or the
director of the county department of environmental and water resources may
question participants or cross examine witnesses.
   J.   Should any issues, facts, data or other evidence arise during the
course of the public hearing, which were not apparent or reasonably foreseeable
by a party from the petition as filed with the clerk, such situation may
constitute grounds for a recess in the public hearing for a period not to
exceed five (5) working days. Any decision in this regard shall be made by the
hearing officer. (Ord. 04-393, 10-12-2004; Ord. 08-168, 5-13-2008; Ord. 21-183,
4-13-2021)
11-63: PUBLIC COMMENT:
   A.   Any person has the right to file written comment concerning the
appropriateness of the proposed facility, or its compliance with the
requirements of section 39.2 of the act, with the clerk, at any time after the
filing of a petition and within the time limitation provided in subsection D of
this section.
   B.   The clerk, on behalf of the county board, shall receive written comment
from any person concerning the appropriateness of the proposed site. Upon
receipt of any such written comment the clerk shall date stamp same and shall
file written comment and the postmarked envelope in which comment is received.
   C.   Copies of such written comments shall be made available for public
inspection in the offices of the clerk, and members of the public shall be
allowed to obtain a copy of any written comment upon payment of actual cost of
reproduction.
   D.   Any written comment received by the clerk or postmarked not later than
thirty (30) days after the date of the last public hearing shall be made part
of the record at the public hearing as hereinafter described and the county
board shall consider any such timely written comments in making its final
determination concerning said petition. In the event that the thirtieth day
falls on a Sunday or a federal holiday, the next day on which mail is delivered
shall be considered the thirtieth day for purposes of this subsection. (Ord.
04-393, 10-12-2004; Ord. 08-168, 5-13-2008; Ord. 21-183, 4-13-2021)
11-64: PUBLIC RECORD:
   A.   The clerk or his/her designee shall prepare and maintain the public
record concerning the petition with a full and complete copy maintained at the
county board office, such record shall include the following documents:
      1.   The original petition and any amendments filed with the clerk.
      2.   All written comment filed with the clerk within the time frame
specified by subsections
11-63A and D of this chapter.
      3.   Notices of participation filed with the clerk, pursuant to
subsection
11-61C of this chapter.
      4.   All exhibits entered into evidence at the time of the public
hearings.
      5.   All transcripts of testimony during the public hearing.
      6.   Any motions filed during the course of the public hearing.
      7.   Any evidence filed pursuant to subsection
11-62F of this chapter.
      8.   Copies of all published or displayed notices of the public hearings
which were prepared by the county or prepared by others and filed with the
clerk.
      9.   All reports submitted to the clerk by the director of the county's
department of finance pursuant to subsection
11-59E2 of this chapter, redacted as necessary to prevent disclosure of
confidential or privileged information.
      10.   All transcripts, when available, of meetings, other than the public
hearings held pursuant to this article, at which a county board member was in
attendance. Although county board members are not encouraged to attend meetings
at which the member knows the petition may be discussed, due to the member's
continuing, regular legislative duties during the course of the county board's
consideration of a petition, attendance at such meetings is sometimes
unavoidable (e.g., attendance at a municipality's council meeting, attendance
at a local chamber of commerce meeting). As such, the member is required to
obtain and file a transcript of any meeting, where such meeting has been
transcribed or recorded, or otherwise disclose such meeting in the public
records (such as disclosing it on the record during the transcribed public
hearings or during the written comment period provided for in this article).
      11.   The hearing officer's, the director of the county division of
transportation's, and director of the county department of environmental and
water resources’ written findings and recommendations to the county board.
      12.   The resolution containing the final decision of the county board on
the petition.
   B.   The clerk or his/her designee shall, during the regular business hours
of the clerk's office, make the public record available to any person
requesting to review it.
   C.   The clerk or his/her designee shall, during the regular business hours
of the clerk's office, accept requests from persons for copies of the public
record, in whole or in part, and arrange for copying so requested upon the
requesting person's payment of the actual cost of copying. The clerk shall
respond to copying requests within a reasonable time.
   D.   The clerk shall be responsible for certifying all copies of the public
record.
   E.   Although late filed public comments are not part of the public record
pursuant to this article, they shall be retained by the clerk with any evidence
of date of filing, such as the clerk's date stamp copy of the written comment
or the postmark, if the written comment was mailed. (Ord. 04-393, 10-12-2004;
Ord. 08-168, 5-13-2008; Ord. 21-183, 4-13-2021)
11-65: DECISION BY THE COUNTY BOARD:
   A.   On or before the one hundred eightieth day following the date the
petition was filed, or on or before the two hundred seventieth day following
the date the petition was filed if the applicant filed an amendment to the
petition in compliance with the timing requirements of the act, the county
board shall, by written resolution, upon the vote of a majority of its members,
decide whether to:
      1.   Grant the petition, without any conditions; or
      2.   Grant the petition, but with conditions on such approval, provided
such conditions are reasonable and necessary to accomplish the purposes of
section 39.2 of the act and are not inconsistent with the regulations
promulgated by the Illinois pollution control board; or
      3.   Deny the petition.
   B.   The county board shall state in its decision its findings as to whether
the applicant has established, and whether the public record supports the
establishment of each of the following criteria:
      1.   The facility is necessary to accommodate the waste needs of the area
it is intended to serve;
      2.   The facility is so designed, located and proposed to be operated
that the public health, safety and welfare will be protected;
      3.   The facility is located so as to minimize the incompatibility with
the character of the surrounding area and to minimize the effect on the value
of the surrounding property;
      4.   For a facility other than a sanitary landfill or waste disposal
site, the facility is located outside the boundary of the 100-year floodplain
or the site is floodproofed; and for a facility that is a sanitary landfill or
waste disposal site, the facility is located outside the boundary of the 100-
year floodplain, or if the facility is a facility described in subsection (b)
(3) of section 22.19a of the act, the site is floodproofed;
      5.   The plan of operations for the facility is designed to minimize the
danger to the surrounding area from fire, spills, or other operational
accidents;
      6.   The traffic patterns to or from the facility are so designed as to
minimize the impact on existing traffic flows;
      7.   If the facility will be treating, storing or disposing of hazardous
waste, an emergency response plan exists for the facility which includes
notification, containment and evacuation procedures to be used in case of an
accidental release;
      8.   If the facility is to be located in a county where the county board
has adopted a solid waste management plan consistent with the planning
requirements of the local solid waste disposal act or the solid waste planning
and recycling act, the facility is consistent with that plan; for purposes of
this criterion (8), the “solid waste management plan” means the plan that is in
effect as of the date the application for siting approval is filed; and
      9.   If the facility is located in a regulated recharge area, any
applicable requirements specified by the Illinois pollution control board for
such areas have been met.
   C.   The county board shall consider as evidence the previous operating
experience and past record of convictions or admissions of violations of the
applicant (and any subsidiary, parent corporation, or subsidiary of the parent
corporation) in the field of solid waste management when considering the second
and fifth criterion of the act, and subsections B2 and B5 of this section.
   D.   In making its decision, the county board shall consider the public
record of the hearing proceedings, as defined in section
11-64 of this chapter, except that the county board shall not consider as
evidence those portions of the public record identified in subsections
11-64A3 and
11-64A8 through A10 of this chapter. The county board shall give greater
evidentiary weight to sworn testimony and evidence presented during the public
hearings than to unsworn oral or written comment.
   E.   No determination by the county board of a petition may be reconsidered,
except to the extent it is reversed and remanded on appeal and the county board
is directed by the Illinois pollution control board or Illinois appellate court
to conduct all or part of the review process again.
   F.   Any county board member may be excused from participation in the
hearing and decision upon demonstration of any disqualifying direct and
personal interest in the property or the affairs of the applicants.
Additionally, any county board member may abstain from voting on the decision,
except to the extent there are insufficient number of board members to pass a
resolution consistent with subsection A of this section. (Ord. 04-393, 10-12-
2004; Ord. 08-168, 5-13-2008; Ord. 21-183, 4-13-2021)
11-66 - 11-107: RESERVED:
