Appendix A: County Toll Bridge Rates And Charges
17-35: TITLE:
This article shall be known as the KANE COUNTY TOLL BRIDGE ORDINANCE. (Ord. 20-
52, 2-11-2020)
17-36: PURPOSE AND AUTHORITY:
   A.   The county board is empowered pursuant to the County Toll Bridges Act
(605 ILCS 5/10-301 et seq.) to borrow money, issue bonds and enact and enforce
all needful rules and regulations in connection with the acquisition,
construction, maintenance, operation, management, care or protection of a
county toll bridge.
   B.   The purpose of this article is to establish rules and regulations
including the manner in which toll rates and charges are set, collected and
enforced to ensure sufficient revenue to pay the costs of such toll bridge and
its approaches. (Ord. 20-52, 2-11-2020)
17-37: DEFINITIONS:
The following definitions shall apply to the terms as used in this article:
ELECTRONIC  A system utilizing a combination of technologies, including but not limited to,
TOLL        cameras, transponders, and mobile applications that together or individually work
COLLECTION: to determine the appropriate toll and charges for the use of the toll bridge.
DEPARTMENT: The Kane County Division of Transportation.
RESPONSIBLE The registered owner of the vehicle, or the person to whom liability for toll
PERSON:     payment is transferred pursuant to Section
            17-49  of this article.
REVENUE:    All tolls, fees, charges, interest, and monies collected or generated as related
            to the ownership, use, operations, financing or maintenance of the toll bridge.
TOLL:       A fee or charge for the use of the toll bridge as hereinafter defined.
            The Kane County Highway No. 86 (also known as Longmeadow Parkway), Bridge over
TOLL        the Fox River in Algonquin Township, County of Kane, State of Illinois including
BRIDGE:     the approaches thereto, and all necessary structures and appurtenances associated
            therewith from which a toll, fee or charge is assessed for the use of the bridge.
TOLL BRIDGE The Longmeadow Parkway toll bridge, and any improvement, extension, or expansion
PROJECT:    to that toll bridge, including:
           (1)   An improvement to relieve traffic congestion and promote safety;
           (2)   A tunnel, overpass, underpass, interchange, service road, ramp, entrance
            plaza, approach, or tollhouse;
 
            (3)   An administration, storage, or other building the county considers
             necessary to operate the toll bridge project;
             (4)   A parking area or structure, rest stop, park, and other improvement or
            amenity the county considers necessary, useful, or beneficial for the operation
             of the toll bridge; and
            (5)   Property rights, easements, and interests the county acquires to
             construct or operate the toll bridge.
TOLL         Any system or process used to assess and/or collect a toll or charge for the
COLLECTION   use of the Longmeadow Parkway Toll Bridge. Such system or process may include
SYSTEM:      cash, credit card, web-based or mobile payment applications, electronic toll
             collection, subscription-based pass systems, or invoice systems.
             A radio frequency identification unit attached to a vehicle from which the
TRANSPONDER: identification unit transmits a signal to a reader mounted to automatically
             identify the existence of a valid toll account associated with the same
             vehicle.
(Ord. 20-52, 2-11-2020)
17-38:    GENERAL AUTHORITY:
   A.    The County Board, may do all things necessary and appropriate to:
      1.   Acquire, construct, improve, operate, and maintain the toll bridge;
      2.   Issue tax bonds, revenue bonds, or combination tax and revenue bonds
to pay the cost of the construction, acquisition, or improvement of the toll
bridge;
      3.   Impose tolls or charges as otherwise authorized by this ordinance
and set and revise such toll rates and charges herein by subsequent ordinance;
      4.   Procure and contract for all services, equipment, technology and
systems necessary and appropriate to facilitate the implementation, operations
and maintenance of the toll bridge;
      5.   Employ such personnel as it deems necessary and appropriate for the
implementation, management, operations and maintenance of the toll bridge;
      6.   Enter into agreements with a private entities to design, develop,
finance, construct, maintain, repair, operate, extend, or expand the existing
toll bridge.
   B.   The county may enter into an agreement with any local, state or federal
governmental entity to implement this Article through the cooperation,
including but not limited to shared funding and resources, of the parties to
the agreement.
   C.   The county may exercise the right to acquire by purchase or otherwise,
to construct, repair, maintain and operate the toll bridge and its approaches
across, above or under any railroad or public utility right-of-way, and in,
upon, under or above any public or private road, highway, street, alley or
public ground, waterway, or upon any property owned by any municipality,
political subdivision or agency of the state of Illinois, and for the purpose
of acquiring property or easements necessary or incidental in the construction,
repair, maintenance or operation of the toll bridge and the approaches thereto,
and the County may exercise the right of eminent domain as provided by the
Illinois Eminent Domain Act. (Ord. 20-52, 2-11-2020)
17-39: TOLL COLLECTION SYSTEM:
   A.   The department shall determine the manner in which tolls may be
collected and may use whatever toll collection system, or combination thereof,
that it deems appropriate to assess and collect tolls and charges for the use
of a toll bridge.
   B.   A toll collection system(s) may be used to collect tolls, determine and
classify vehicle usage to support the management of customer toll accounts,
detect the non-payment of tolls, and to support violation enforcement and
adjudication.
   C.   Any electronic toll collection system selected by the department shall
be compatible with the electronic toll collection system used by the Illinois
State Toll Highway Authority. The county may enter into an intergovernmental
agreement with the Illinois State Toll Highway Authority to provide for such
compatibility or to provide electronic toll collection or toll violation
enforcement services. The county may enter into such other agreements that it
deems necessary or appropriate to facilitate interoperability for toll
collection on or for the utilization of the toll bridge. (Ord. 20-52, 2-11-
2020)
17-40:    TOLL RATES AND CHARGES:
   A.   The county board shall set and may revise the toll rates and charges
for the toll bridge.
   B.   Except as otherwise exempted pursuant to section:
17-44 , Toll Exemptions, the county will assess and collect a toll for the use
of the toll bridge.
   C.   Any toll rate or charges to be assessed by the county shall be set
forth in
Appendix A  to this ordinance, County Toll Bridge Rates and Charges. Upon
county board initial approval of, or any subsequent amendment to, the toll
rates or charges, the Appendix shall be published, attached and incorporated
herein. Any modifications to the toll rates or charges shall be made by
amendment of this ordinance.
   D.   Duly authorized toll and charges shall be published on the county
website and posted at and near the toll bridge.
   E.   If bonds are issued evidencing the debt incurred pursuant to the County
Toll Bridges Act for the toll bridge that are payable in whole or in part from
the revenue of the toll bridge, the county shall impose tolls and charges that
are, together with other money or revenues available for the toll bridge
sufficient to:
      1.    Pay the maintenance and operating expenses of the toll bridge
project;
      2.   Pay the principal of, premium of, if any, and interest on the bonds
when due;
      3.   Establish, as may be specified in the proceedings authorizing the
issuance of such bonds, a reserve for payment of bond principal, premium and
interest; and
      4.   Establish a fund the amount of which is adequate for toll bridge
project depreciation and replacement.
   F.   The county may establish different vehicle classifications based on
vehicle type, size, shape, weight, or any combination thereof.
   G.   The county may assess different toll rates based on vehicle
classifications; the method of payment of the toll, and/or frequency of use of
the toll bridge.
   H.   The county may assess charges related to the invoicing of individuals
who fail to timely pay a toll, for administrative costs related to toll account
management, the cost of collection thereof and for toll violation external
collection efforts as set forth in
Appendix A . (Ord. 20-52, 2-11-2020)
17-41:   REVENUES:
The county may not use revenue from the toll bridge in a manner not authorized
by this Article. Revenues generated from the toll bridge may not be applied for
a purpose or to pay a cost other than a cost or purpose that is reasonably
related to or anticipated to be for the benefit of the toll bridge. If bonds
are issued evidencing the debt incurred to pursuant to the County Toll Bridges
Act for the toll bridge are payable, in whole or in part, from the revenue of a
toll bridge project, the county shall not use such revenue in a manner not
authorized by the proceedings authorizing the issuance of such bonds. (Ord. 20-
52, 2-11-2020)
17-42:    TOLL PAYMENT REQUIRED:
   A.   The registered owner of any motor vehicle that is driven on the toll
bridge shall pay the applicable toll required to use the toll bridge, unless
otherwise exempted pursuant to Section:
17-44 , Toll Exemptions.
   B.   Toll payment shall be made at the time of use of the toll bridge
through the establishment of a pre-paid toll account, or within seven days of
using the toll bridge, or by the due date set forth in a toll invoice.
   C.   If a vehicle is not associated with a valid pre-paid toll account, the
toll shall be assessed utilizing the license plate of the vehicle using the
toll bridge (“license plate toll”) and the registered owner of the vehicle
shall thereafter have seven (7) days from the date of usage of the toll bridge
to pay the license plate toll amount online to avoid being assessed additional
charges associated with the issuance of a toll invoice.
   D.   If the license plate toll amount is not received within seven (7) days,
the registered owner of the vehicle with the unpaid toll(s) shall be
responsible for paying the license plate toll amount plus processing fees,
which shall constitute the toll invoice amount.
   E.   The county will send a toll invoice to the registered owner at the
address shown in the vehicle registration records of the Illinois Secretary of
State or similar departments of motor vehicles of any other state by first-
class mail. Toll invoices will be sent monthly and include as many of the
unpaid tolls that may have accrued prior to the monthly invoice date. If the
address to which the invoice was mailed is determined to be incorrect, upon
determination of the new address, the county may resend the invoice to the new
address of the registered owner.
   F.   The invoice may include one or more unpaid tolls. Each invoice shall
include (1) the date, time and location of the toll transaction; (2) a general
description of the nonpaying vehicle; (3) the date by which the toll(s) must be
paid; (4) how payment can be made; and (5) information regarding the
establishment of toll account. The invoice may, but is not required to, include
an image of the nonpaying vehicle.
   G.   Payment of the invoiced amount is due within 30 days after the invoice
issuance date.
   H.   The county may employ the services of a collection agency at any time,
including after a person’s failure to pay any civil penalty, to assist with
identifying individuals who fail to pay and collecting the tolls and charges
that are due. The person responsible for paying the tolls and charges may be
assessed additional fees of collection. (Ord. 20-52, 2-11-2020)
17-43: TOLL ACCOUNT:
   A.   A pre-paid toll account is required to be eligible to pay the
electronic toll rate and to obtain any discounted toll offered by the county.
   B.   In order to establish a prepaid toll account, a person must complete an
account application providing the person’s name, address, vehicle description,
license plate state, number, plate type, method of payment, and such other
information that may be required to facilitate the collection and payment of
tolls and charges.
   C.   All accountholders must comply with the conditions for establishing and
maintaining a valid toll account. A valid toll account is one that has the
correct vehicle, license plate and contact information of the accountholder and
sufficient funds on hand to pay the toll at the time the vehicle is driven on
the toll bridge.
   D.   Toll account information shall be confidential and not subject to
release to any third party, except as required by the county to collect or
enforce payment of tolls and charges or as otherwise required by statute or
court order. (Ord. 20-52, 2-11-2020)
17-44: TOLL EXEMPTIONS:
   A.   An entity that is the registered owner of an authorized emergency
vehicle, as defined by 625 ILCS 5/1 105, is eligible for exemption from the
payment of toll bridge tolls. The county may also provide toll exemption to
special vehicles such as school buses or municipal-owned vehicles. To receive a
toll exemption the entity must establish a toll exempt account with the county.
   B.   An application to establish a toll exempt account must be completed by
an authorized representative of the entity claiming an exemption. The entity
must provide information required by the county to establish a toll-exempt
account, including, but not limited to, the names of the entity and point of
contact, entity address, an email address, phone number, and the vehicle(s)
registration information, description and license plate state, number(s) and
plate type.
   C.   In order to obtain the exemption, the registered owner of the vehicle
shall obtain a toll-exempt transponder and properly affix it to the exempted
vehicle. The toll exempt transponder is not transferrable and shall not be
moved or transferred from one vehicle to another without updating the
applicable exempt account information.
   D.   An entity that improperly transfers a transponder to another vehicle
without updating the applicable account information may lose its eligibility
for the toll exemption.
   E.   The county may assess an entity processing fees for providing and
distributing the toll-exempt transponder(s) and for account management. (Ord.
20-52, 2-11-2020)
17-45:    DISCOUNTS:
   A.    The county may establish one or more toll discount programs or offer
discounts to Class 1 passenger vehicle toll bridge users in consideration of
their usage of the toll bridge, method of payment or residency
   B.    Discount Toll Pass Subscription. The county may offer local resident
and non-resident discount toll pass subscriptions that allow unlimited 12-month
or 90-day usage of the toll bridge for a lump-sum price, as set forth in
Appendix A . The discount toll pass shall only be used as payment for the use
of the toll bridge.
      1.   To subscribe to a discount toll pass, the local resident or non-
resident must complete an    application to register the person’s eligible
Class 1 passenger vehicle and establish a pre-paid discount toll account with
the deposit of the full amount set for the particular discount toll pass
program. The discount toll pass will be issued to one specific eligible Class 1
passenger vehicle and is not transferrable. A person who transfers a discount
toll pass to another vehicle without first completing an application to
register the vehicle to which the discount toll pass is to be transferred shall
lose eligibility for the discount
      2.   To receive a local resident discount toll pass, the person must also
provide proof of residency within Kane County or the Village of Algonquin which
shall be established by presenting a current and valid Illinois driver’s
license and a current valid Illinois vehicle registration, along with one of
the following: utility bill, lease or rental agreement, or property tax bill
with some reasonably certain indication of the person’s residency.
      3.   The discount toll pass shall be available for a 90-day or 12-month
subscription. Full payment is due at the time of subscribing.
      4.   The discount toll pass charge is non-refundable and shall not be
subject to proration. (Ord. 20-52, 2-11-2020)
17-46: NOTICE OF NONPAYMENT:
   A.   If the registered owner of the nonpaying vehicle fails to pay a license
plate tolls and charges included in the invoice mailed under section
17-42  by the date specified in the invoice, the county shall send a notice of
nonpayment by first class mail to the registered owner as described by
subsection
17-42 (E) Toll Payment.
   B.   The notice of nonpayment shall include (1) the date, time and location
of each unpaid toll transaction; (2) a general description of the nonpaying
vehicle; (3) the date by which the toll(s) and any charges must be paid; and
(4) how payment can be made. The notice may, but is not required to, include an
image of the nonpaying vehicle. The payment due date shall be not less than 30
days after the issuance date of the notice of nonpayment
   C.   The county may charge a late fee of not more than $50 for each notice
of nonpayment.
   D.   The registered owner of the nonpaying vehicle shall pay both the unpaid
tolls included in the invoice and any late fee(s), as set forth in
Appendix A , before the expiration of the notice due date.
   E.   The county shall send the notice of nonpayment to the registered owner
not later than 60 days after the expiration of the invoice due date. If due to
events outside of the county’s reasonable control, the county requires
additional time to issue the notice of nonpayment, the county may send the
notice not later than the 120 days after the expiration of the invoice due
date. (Ord. 20-52, 2-11-2020)
17-47: TOLL VIOLATION; CIVIL PENALTY:
   A.   No person shall evade or attempt to evade the payment of tolls or other
charges for the use of the toll bridge.
   B.   The registered owner of a vehicle for which the toll bridge toll was
not paid who is mailed a notice of nonpayment under section
17-46  and fails to pay the toll and charges within the time specified by the
notice of nonpayment commits a toll violation. The toll violator will be
assessed a toll violation penalty as listed in
Appendix A  for each notice of nonpayment that is unpaid in whole or in part.
   C.   The county shall mail a notice of the alleged toll violation by first
class U.S. mail to the registered owner of the vehicle. The notice of toll
violation shall include the amount owed and the payment due date, which shall
be no less than 30 days after the date of issuance of the notice.
   D.   The notice of toll violation shall include a statement that the person
may contest the merits of the violation by requesting an administrative hearing
and adjudication of the toll violation prior to the payment due date, and shall
provide the manner in which a contest may be made, the options to have an
administrative hearing; the location for an in-person hearing, and the
consequence for failure to submit evidence/documentation or appear for the
administrative hearing.
   E.   A toll violation under this section imposed as the result of an
administrative adjudication shall result in a civil penalty not to exceed $500.
(Ord. 20-52, 2-11-2020)
17-48: ADMINISTRATIVE HEARING AND ADJUDICATION:
   A.   A person may contest the merits of the alleged toll violation and
request an administrative hearing and adjudication of the toll violation within
30 days of the notice of toll violation issuance date.
   B.   To contest a toll violation the person must submit a request for
administrative hearing within the time and manner specified in the notice of
toll violation. A request must be made in writing by mail to the address
specified in the notice of toll violation or through the toll bridge website,
or by contacting the customer service center by phone or in person.
      1.   If the person fails to timely request an administrative hearing, as
required under subsection
17-48 (C), the person shall be determined liable for the toll violation, unpaid
tolls, and any applicable unpaid administrative fees, collection fees and
penalties.
      2.   If the person timely requests an administrative hearing, the county
shall set a date and time for the hearing and provide written notice thereof to
the person.
   C.   The person may elect a hearing by mail or in person, or any other means
made available by the county.
      1.   Hearing by Mail. To obtain a hearing by mail, the person shall
submit with a request for hearing by mail all documents the person deems
appropriate to contest liability for the toll violation and the related unpaid
tolls, unpaid fees and penalties. The administrative judge shall consider the
information provided by both the alleged violator and the county regarding the
toll violation. The administrative judge shall make a determination of
liability and if determined liable for the toll violation the person shall be
required to pay the unpaid tolls, unpaid fees and penalty, assess the
appropriate penalty, as provided in
Appendix A . If the person fails to submit any supporting evidence (i.e.
documentation), the person shall be found liable for the toll violation and
required to pay the unpaid tolls, unpaid fees and penalty, as provided in
Appendix A .
      2.   Hearing in Person. To obtain a hearing in person, the person shall
submit a request there. The county shall provide the person written notice of
the date, time and location for the administrative hearing. If the person fails
to appear at the administrative hearing, the person shall be found liable for
the toll violation and required to pay the unpaid toll, unpaid fees and
penalty, as provided in
Appendix A .
      3.   Other Means for Hearings. The county may offer other reasonable
means by which an administrative hearing may be held. The county shall provide
notice of and specify the requirements for such alternative(s) in the notice of
toll violation. Any such alternative shall allow the contesting person an
opportunity to submit supporting documentation and receive a review by an
administrative judge.
   D.   If the person requesting an administrative hearing is a minor, that
person shall be permitted to appear at an administrative hearing or admit
responsibility for a toll violation without the necessity of the appointment of
a guardian. The processing agency may proceed against that person in the same
manner as if that person were an adult.
   E.   The administrative hearing shall be conducted before an impartial
administrative judge designated by the county to conduct the hearing. The
administrative judge shall have the demonstrated qualifications, training, and
objectivity necessary and consistent with the duties and responsibilities set
forth in this article. The administrative judge’s continued employment,
performance evaluation, compensation, and benefits shall not be directly or
indirectly linked to the amount of fees or penalties collected by the
administrative judge.
   F.   The administrative judge shall determine liability for a toll violation
based on a preponderance of the evidence with proof of the following elements:
      1.   the vehicle was driven on the toll bridge;
      2.   notice was mailed to the address of the registered owner as
contained in the Illinois Secretary of State, or to an address contained in the
department of motor vehicles of any other state or other credible sources;
      3.   the amount included in the second notice of nonpayment was not paid
before the date specified in the notice; and
      4.   the alleged violator was the registered owner or the driver of the
vehicle when the unpaid toll was assessed. Such proof may be established by a
record from the Illinois Secretary of State, the department of motor vehicles
of any other state, or other credible source; or by affidavit or contract
document from the registered owner indicating that the vehicle was in the
possession of the alleged violator pursuant to a valid rental car agreement at
the time of the incurrence of the toll and the registered owner was not the
driver at the time that the unpaid toll was assessed.
   G.   Proof may be established by testimony of a peace officer or a county
employee, video surveillance records, records of the county toll bridge
customer service center or agent of the county responsible for processing toll
invoices, copies of notices of non-payment and violations, or any other
reasonable evidence, including a copy of the rental, lease, or other contract
document or the electronic data provided to the county. Nonpayment by the
registered owner of the vehicle also may be established by a copy of a written
agreement between the county and the registered owner for the payment of unpaid
tolls and administrative fees; and evidence that the registered owner is in
default under the agreement.
   H.   The administrative judge shall issue a final order of liability, if the
person responsible for paying a toll violation:
      1.   is found liable for the toll violation pursuant to Sections
17-47  and
17-48 ;
      2.   requests an administrative hearing and fails to appear or fails to
submit supporting documentation and fails to pay the fine;
      3.   fails to pay any or all of the amounts due by the toll violation due
date.
      Upon the issuance of the final order of liability, the liable person is
responsible for paying the civil penalty in addition to all of the unpaid tolls
and administrative fees.
   I.   The administrative judge may find a person not liable for
administrative fees and/or civil penalty. Notwithstanding the same, in all
cases, where the administrative judge finds that the alleged violator used the
toll bridge but did not pay, the administrative judge shall assess, at a
minimum, the applicable license plate toll(s) for the use of the toll bridge.
   J.   Judicial review of final determinations of ordinance violations are
subject to the provisions of the Administrative Hearing Law.
   K.   The county may enter into an intergovernmental agreement with the
Illinois State Toll Highway Authority under which the Authority may provide
administrative adjudication of toll violations occurring on a county toll
bridge.
   L.   Payment of toll amounts, administrative fees and civil penalties shall
be made as directed in the notice of nonpayment and notice of toll violation.
Such funds shall be promptly turned over to the county treasurer to be credited
to the toll bridge fund. (Ord. 20-52, 2-11-2020)
17-49: DEFENSE TO NONPAYMENT; AND REASSIGNMENT:
   A.   It is a defense to nonpayment under this Article if the vehicle in
question was:
      1.   stolen at the time of the incurrence of the toll and was not
recovered by the time of the failure to pay;
      2.   sold and transferred to another individual at the time of the
incurrence of the toll, provided that the owner being held liable for the
unpaid toll provides proof of sale and transfer along with an affidavit that
includes the name and address of the person to whom the vehicle was sold and
date of the transfer of possession of the vehicle;
      3.   driven by a lessee of a car whose registered owner is a rental
company, as defined in 625 ILCS 27/10, at the time of the incurrence of the
toll, and the rental company timely provided proof acceptable to the county to
transfer liability to the lessee.
   B.   Liability for an unpaid toll or toll violations may be reassigned to
another person in the event of a vehicle sale or transfer or lease pursuant to
a valid rental agreement.
      1.   In the case of a vehicle sale, to reassign a toll violation the
person who received the toll invoice or notices must comply with section
17-49 A(2).
      2.   In the case of a vehicle lease, to reassign a toll violation the
rental car company must:
         a.   Be the registered owner of the vehicle.
         b.   Have included a provision in its rental agreement advising the
renter/lessee that the renter/lessee will be responsible for payment of tolls
and any charges related to the nonpayment of tolls and violations.
         c.   Have posted a sign at the rental/leasing counter notifying the
renter/lessee of the responsibility to pay tolls and any related charges. (Ord.
20-52, 2-11-2020)
17-50:    ENFORCEMENT:
The county may pursue any and all legal means available to it to enforce the
final order and collect sums due to the county, including but not limited to
the use of a collection agency, litigation, wage garnishments, bank liens or
tax liens, and the like to the extent allowed by law. (Ord. 20-52, 2-11-2020)
17-51: PROMOTION OF TOLL BRIDGE:
The county board may promote the use of the toll bridge by appropriate means,
including advertising or marketing as the county determines appropriate. (Ord.
20-52, 2-11-2020)
17-52: EFFECTIVE DATE:
This ordinance is effective as of February 11, 2020. (Ord. 20-52, 2-11-2020)
17-53: TOLL BRIDGE FISCAL YEAR:
The fiscal year for the toll bridge shall begin on December 1st of each year.
(Ord. 20-52, 2-11-2020)

CHAPTER 18
PRIVATE SEWAGE DISPOSAL
ARTICLE I. IN GENERAL
SECTION:
18-1 - 18-24: Reserved
18-25: Definitions
18-1 - 18-24: RESERVED:
(Ord. 97-327, 11-12-1997)
18-25: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this chapter, the following definitions shall apply:
CURTAIN DRAIN: A subsurface drain installed at or above the moderately slowly
permeable subsoil with gravel to within maximum of twelve inches (12") of the
surface to intercept the movement of subsurface water from higher ground toward
the private sewage disposal system and discharging by means of a positive
outlet, to a lower area.
LIMITING LAYER: A horizon or condition in the soil profile or underlying strata
which includes:
   A.   A seasonal high water table, whether perched or regional, determined by
direct observation of the water table or indicated by soil mottling where
common mottles comprise at least two percent (2%) to twenty percent (20%) of
the soil in a progressive downward direction in the soil.
   B.   Masses of loose rock fragments, including gravel, with insufficient
fine soil to fill the voids between the fragments.
   C.   Rock formation, other stratum or soil condition which is so slowly
permeable that it effectively limits downward passage of effluent.
MAINTENANCE: Any activity that is needed to keep the private sewage disposal
system operating properly, such as, but not limited to, the following: pumping
the tank, replacement of tank lid, replacement of septic tank baffles,
replacement of drop box lids, raising inspection ports to grade, adjusting
water elevation in drop boxes, replacing sewer line between tank and seepage
field, replacing pumps, replacing the line between the tank and the seepage
field, or the elimination of depressions over lines, or the installation of
water conservation devices.
REPAIR: Any change to a private sewage disposal system beyond maintenance, such
as replacing the septic tank(s) or removing and replacing any portion of the
septic field, and does require a permit.
RESTRICTIVE LAYER: See definition of Limiting Layer.
SOIL BORING: An observation pit, dug by hand or backhoe, or an undisturbed soil
core taken intact and undisturbed by a probe. (Ord. 97-327, 11-12-1997)

18-26: ADOPTION:
In addition to the other provisions stated herein, this chapter shall adopt, by
reference, and shall be interpreted and enforced in accordance with provisions
set forth in the current, unabridged form of the licensing act, 225 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 225/1 et seq., and the "private sewage disposal code 1996",
77 Illinois administrative code 905, three (3) copies of which shall be on file
in the office of the county clerk. (Ord. 97-327, 11-12-1997)
18-27: SCOPE:
The Illinois department of public health, private sewage disposal licensing
act, 225 Illinois Compiled Statutes 225/1 et seq., and the "private sewage
disposal code 1996", 77 Illinois administrative code 905, shall apply except
for the following sections:
   A.   Section 905.30 approved private disposal systems.
   B.   Section 905.90 waste stabilization ponds.
   C.   Section 905.100 b aerobic treatment plants/class II effluent.
   D.   Section 905 appendix A illustration R exhibit A, B and C waste
stabilization pond. (Ord. 97-327, 11-12-1997)
18-28: PLAT APPROVAL:
The county health department is required by 765 Illinois Compiled Statutes 205/
2, to sign all plats within the county with respect to sewage disposal systems
if any part of the platted land will not be served by a public sewer system. In
order to accomplish this, county health department will review and evaluate all
plats by the criteria established in this chapter. (Ord. 97-327, 11-12-1997)
18-29: INTERPRETATION:
The provisions of this chapter shall be held to be the minimum requirements for
the promotion of public health, safety and general welfare. In any case where a
provision of this chapter is found to be in conflict with a provision of any
zoning, building, safety, or health ordinance, the provision which establishes
the higher standard for the promotion of the health and safety of the people
shall prevail. (Ord. 97-327, 11-12-1997)
18-30: COMPLIANCE:
All private sewage disposal systems within the limits of Kane County shall be
constructed, installed, repaired, and maintained by an individual with a valid
private sewage disposal system installation contractor's registration; and all
such systems shall be pumped, cleaned, and the contents disposed of by
individuals with a valid private sewage disposal system pumping contractor's
registration. All private sewage systems shall be cleaned, pumped, or serviced,
and the contents disposed of in accordance with the provisions of sections 18-
41 and 18-42 of this chapter. (Ord. 97-327, 11-12-1997)
18-31: REQUIRED:
All buildings or dwellings where people live, work, or assemble shall be
provided with an individual sewage treatment and disposal system, designed and
constructed to promote and safeguard the public health, or shall be connected
to a public sewer system. Each single-family residence and each unit in a
multi-family residence using an individual sewage treatment and disposal system
shall be provided with a separate individual sewage treatment and disposal
system. (Ord. 97-327, 11-12-1997)
18-32: OCCUPANCY:
No person shall occupy or permit occupancy of any building, structure, or
dwelling not in compliance with this chapter. (Ord. 97-327, 11-12-1997)
18-33: DISCHARGES OF SEWAGE; IMPROPER OPERATION OF SYSTEMS:
Every private sewage disposal system shall be maintained in a proper sanitary
condition and in a proper state of repair by the owner. It shall be unlawful
for any person to permit or cause the discharge of improperly treated sewage
directly or indirectly to any lake, stream, ditch, ground surface or abandoned
well, or to allow the contents of any privy, vault, septic tank, or private
sewage disposal system or component thereof, to emit any offensive odor, or to
become objectionable so as to be dangerous or prejudicial to the health, safety
and welfare of the public. Upon verification of such unsanitary conditions, the
county health department shall give written notice to the owner and/or legal
occupant responsible for such acts or omissions, ordering abatement of same.
Failure of any person to obey such an abatement order shall constitute a
violation of this chapter. (Ord. 97-327, 11-12-1997)
18-34: APPROVED PRIVATE SEWAGE DISPOSAL SYSTEMS:
The following systems are approved for private sewage disposal when designed,
constructed, operated, and maintained in accordance with the applicable
sections in this chapter:
   A.   Septic tank in addition to one of the following:
      1.   Subsurface seepage system.
      2.   Buried sand filter.
      3.   Recirculating sand filter.
   B.   Aquarobic raised filter bed as approved by the Illinois department of
public health (IDPH).
   C.   Aerobic treatment plants discharging to supplementary treatment as
provided in subsection A1, A2 or A3 of this section.
   D.   Alternative systems:
      1.   Privy.
      2.   Chemical toilets.
      3.   Incinerator toilets.
      4.   Compost toilets.
      5.   Recirculating toilets. (Ord. 97-327, 11-12-1997)
18-35: ALTERNATIVE SYSTEMS:
When an application for a private sewage disposal system permit on an existing
platted lot or parcel of record with residential zoning has been denied due to
the limitations of the soil, or the lot or parcel is too small to install the
required minimum size disposal system and expansion area, an application may be
submitted to the county health department for an alternative system. All other
sections of this chapter shall be met. (Ord. 97-327, 11-12-1997)
18-36: VARIANCES:
The county health department may grant a variance provided it does not conflict
with the stated purpose of this chapter. A variance may be requested by
submitting a written proposal to the county health department. Such written
request shall include pertinent data such as soil suitability, drainage
patterns, and distances to water supplies. The capability of the system to
comply with the intent of this chapter will be the basis for approval or denial
of the variance. The county health department shall respond to all variance
requests in writing within ten (10) working days. If the county health
department refuses to issue a variance, the property owner may file with the
county health department a written request for an appeal and hearing as
specified in section
18-48 of this chapter. (Ord. 97-327, 11-12-1997)
18-37: SOIL SUITABILITY:
All subsurface seepage fields and seepage beds shall be designed with primary
consideration to soil type. The county health department or contractor may
request a percolation test to provide additional information where it is needed
to assist in determining extent of compaction of soil. Upon notification
percolation tests may be submitted by the installation contractor to the county
health department in lieu of soil evaluations for repairs. Information about
the location of the seasonal high water table must be included. The method that
provides for the largest seepage field or seepage bed will be required. The
soil type shall be determined by the indication of the soil property of three
(3) or more soil borings in the private sewage disposal system area and
designed as to that which most closely compares to the typical soil profile as
described in the soil survey. Subsurface seepage systems shall have at least
two feet (2') of vertical separation distance between the bottom of the
subsurface seepage system and the top of the limiting layer. For soils which
are moderately rapid or rapidly permeable, a vertical separation of three feet
(3') between the bottom of the subsurface seepage system and the top of the
limiting layer is required. When a limiting layer has been identified by a
mottling depth of twenty four inches (24") or less, a curtain drain may be used
to intercept the movement of subsurface water from higher ground toward the
private sewage disposal system provided soils with permeabilities of 0.6 inch/
hour or greater are present, in the area and surrounding area of the subsurface
seepage system from the ground surface to the depth where the curtain drain
tile is to be placed, and a proper drain outlet exists. Full credit for two
feet (2') of vertical separation from seasonal high water table will be given
when the curtain drain is installed in topography of minimum slope of one
percent (1%), two feet (2') lower than seepage field, and soil of a minimum
permeability of 0.6 to one inch (1") per hour. The curtain drain must have a
minimum separation of ten feet (10') from the nearest seepage trench. All
systems installed or repaired in areas designed as special flood hazard areas
must be so constructed to avoid impairment to them or contamination from them
during flooding. (Ord. 97-327, 11-12-1997)
18-38: SOIL INVESTIGATION:
   A.   Determination of soil characteristics on sites proposed for development
with private sewage disposal systems shall be based on the soil data collected
by a certified soil classifier recognized by the Illinois Soils Classifiers
Association or the American Registry Of Certified Professionals In Agronomy,
Crops, And Soils. United States department of agriculture (USDA) natural
resources conservation service soil classifiers may be available for periodic
quality control sessions conducted with all scientists available for the
performance of on site soil borings. USDA natural resources conservation
service soil scientist may be available to provide needed soils expertise to
the department and other county agencies in connection with the needs of this
chapter. Soil reports shall be provided in a form uniform with county needs and
requirements.
   B.   There shall be a minimum of three (3) soil borings per private sewage
disposal system site in the area where the private sewage disposal system is
intended to be installed. Additional soil borings may be required for accurate
and appropriate evaluation of a site where there is some concern about the
consistency of the soil materials.
   C.   Soil borings shall be dug to a minimum depth of five feet (5') with a
minimum width of two feet (2'), and one end of the pit shall be stepped or
sloped to permit adequate ingress and egress.
   D.   Soil borings shall be excavated at the perimeter of the expected
private sewage disposal system area to minimize damage to the natural soil
structure and potential disruptions of the soil distribution network that may
be caused by settling after installation of the system.
   E.   Soil borings shall not be made when frost depth is ten inches (10") or
greater.
   F.   Site characteristics to be described include zones of estimated
seasonal high ground water table, observed water table, depth to bedrock, frost
depth, USDA soil textural changes, USDA soil structural features of note,
consistence, location of fill soil, compaction and depth, soil coloration,
depth of mottling (depth to low chroma equal to or less than 2 and a value of 4
or more Munsell color chart), and estimated permeability at a depth twelve
inches (12") to thirty six inches (36"). A site location map showing the
location of the soil test sites shall be included with the soil report. The
subsurface seepage system should be sized using section
18-39, table I, "Soil Suitability Chart For On Site Sewage Disposal Design", of
this chapter.
   G.   The county health department reserves the right to review site soil
characteristics with assistance from a staff or USDA natural resources
conservation service soil scientist. (Ord. 97-327, 11-12-1997)
18-39: REQUIREMENTS FOR SUBSURFACE SEEPAGE SYSTEMS UTILIZING FILL:
Subsurface seepage systems utilizing fill shall be designed with the following
criteria:
   A.   If fill is used on systems to maintain at least two feet (2')
separation between the bottom of the trench and the limiting layer, it may not
exceed eighteen inches (18") in depth. Fill soils may be used to cover a
private sewage disposal system provided no part of the system is located in the
fill and the material is at least equal to or better than the original soil or
meets the requirements in subsections B and C of this section.
   B.   Where less than twelve inches (12") of fill is to be placed over a
disposal field, the suitability of the fill materials shall be determined by a
soil classifier. Soils that are to be used for fill shall meet the following
criteria:
      1.   The fill shall conform to soils in design groups II, III, and IV as
identified in the private sewage disposal code 1996.
      2.   The fill shall be of a porous material that is not compacted or wet.
      3.   The fill shall be free of other nonsoil materials such as concrete,
brick or other extraneous material.
   C.   Where more than twelve inches (12") of fill is required, for previously
platted lots the suitability of the fill materials shall be determined by a
soil classifier.
      1.   The clay content shall be less than twenty five percent (25%).
      2.   Sand content shall be less than sixty five percent (65%).
      3.   Less than five percent (5%) of the content shall be greater than two
millimeter (2 mm) stones.
      4.   Organic matter shall be three percent (3%) or greater.
      5.   No clods greater than ten percent (10%) by volume or greater than
four inches (4") in size.
      6.   The fill shall be free of other nonsoil materials such as concrete,
brick or other extraneous material.
   D.   All of the following conditions shall be met for a private sewage
disposal system to be installed in fill:
      1.   Satisfactory original soil shall be at least four feet (4') above
bedrock.
      2.   A maximum of eighteen inches (18") of fill soil shall be used.
      3.   Fill shall not be placed on original soil with a slope greater than
ten percent (10%).
      4.   When adding fill to a depth of less than twelve inches (12"), the
fill may be added after the installation of the seepage field system. When fill
depth is from twelve (12) to eighteen inches (18"), the fill shall be placed
before installation of the seepage field.
      5.   The fill shall be placed at the site so that a minimum of compacting
occurs and the fill shall be allowed to settle undisturbed for a period of at
least twelve (12) months.
      6.   After the fill has been settled, a percolation test shall be
conducted.
   E.   Site preparation for use of fill soil:
      1.   Excess vegetation shall be cut and removed. The site shall be plowed
with a mold board plow seven (7) to eight inches (8") deep with the plowing
done parallel to the slope. Chisel plowing may be used in place of mold board.
Rototilling is prohibited.
      2.   Once the site is plowed, all vehicular traffic must be kept off the
site. The fill material can be deposited on the top with a long reach backhoe
or pushed on from the upslope side, using a track type tractor, keeping six
inches (6") of fill beneath the tracks. At no time shall ruts be made in the
plowed area. The fill shall be placed immediately after site preparation to
avoid the possibility of precipitation falling on the plowed area.
      3.   Traffic on the downslope side of the fill area shall be minimal to
reduce compaction. All work shall be performed from the ends and upslope side.
Compaction of the natural soil down slope will reduce the lateral movement of
the effluent.
      4.   The fill shall not be placed on frozen ground or when the soil is
wet. Moisture content of the soil is very important when filling. Site
preparation shall not take place when the soil is too wet and subject to
compaction. To check moisture content, take a soil sample from the plow layer
(7 to 8 inches) and roll it between the palms of the hands. If it rolls into a
ribbon, it is too wet to prepare. If it crumbles, site preparation can then
proceed.

18-40: AEROBIC TREATMENT PLANTS:
   A.   New Construction: Aerobic treatment plants approved for new
construction shall not be designed for surface discharge for lots platted after
the effective date hereof.
   B.   Existing Building: Aerobic treatment plants designed to serve an
existing building or dwelling with a malfunctioning private sewage disposal
system may use an approved surface discharge method, provided conditions for a
subsurface seepage system cannot be met.
   C.   Service And Maintenance Requirements:
      1.   Service Policy: All aerobic treatment plants, regardless of the date
of installation, shall have in force, at all times, a service policy, for that
identified product, from the private sewage disposal installation contractor
through the manufacturer or the distributor or qualified homeowner to perform
the necessary service for as long as the unit is in operation. A qualified
homeowner is one who has received on site training on his aerobic treatment
plant by the dealer of that product. The dealer will submit documentation, to
the county health department, that the homeowner has been trained to service
their aerobic treatment plant.
This service policy shall provide:
         a.   For an inspection/service call, at least once every six (6)
months, which includes inspection, adjustment, and servicing of the mechanical
and electrical component parts to ensure proper function.
         b.   For an effluent quality inspection, at least once every six (6)
months, consisting of a visual check for color, turbidity, scum overflow, and
an examination for odors and a chemical test for chlorine residual.
         c.   For improper operation which cannot be corrected at the time, to
be reported to the owner immediately. This shall be followed with a written
report which includes the date for the condition to be corrected.
         d.   For a written report describing each inspection and/or service
call for each aerobic treatment plant available to the county health department
upon request provided by the servicing agency. Such report shall include date
of inspection/service call, and a description of the inspection/service
performed.
         e.   A telephone response shall be returned to the customer within
twenty four (24) hours after the customer calls for service.
         f.   A service call to the property to physically service the aeration
unit shall be made within forty eight (48) hours after the customer calls for
service.
      2.   Standby Parts: Standby mechanical and electrical component parts
shall be stocked by the local distributor for use when an aerobic treatment
plant's mechanical or electrical components must be removed from the site for
repairs.
      3.   Guarantee Against Defects: The mechanical and electrical component
parts shall be guaranteed against any defects in materials and workmanship as
warranted.
      4.   Alarms: A clearly visible, permanently attached label or plate
giving instructions for obtaining service shall be placed at the audible and
visible alarm.
      5.   Responsibility Of The Property Owner: Property owners of aerobic
treatment plants shall be required to obtain and maintain at all times a
continuing service policy as described in this subsection C.
      6.   Responsibility Of The Servicing Agent: A copy of all service
contracts shall be submitted to the county health department within thirty (30)
days of occupancy of the premises.
      7.   Responsibility Of The Manufacturer's Representative: The aerobic
treatment plant manufacturer's representative shall submit annual lists of all
existing aerobic treatment plants and indicate if a service contract is in
effect. (Ord. 97-327, 11-12-1997)
18-41: REQUIREMENTS FOR SEPTAGE DISPOSAL:
   A.   Application To Agricultural Land: Septage may be applied to
agricultural land provided that a permit for such application has first been
approved by the county health department. Applications for permits to dispose
of septage on agricultural land shall be made on forms provided by the county
health department. All methods of disposal shall comply with the U.S.
environmental protection agency (USEPA) regulations 40 CFR part 503: "standards
for the use of disposal of sewage sludge", three (3) copies of which shall be
on file in the office of the county clerk. In addition, any application for a
permit shall meet the following criteria to be considered suitable as a septage
disposal site. Inspection and approval by the county health department shall be
conducted using the following criteria:
      1.   Any site being utilized as a septage disposal site shall be
inspected and approved by the county health department.
      2.   The depth to the seasonal high ground water table is at least four
feet (4') below the ground surface.
      3.   The depth to fractured limestone formations is at least six feet
(6') below grade.
      4.   It originates from private sewage disposal systems which treat only
domestic wastes.
      5.   It is not applied to land which has received more than one- fourth
inch (1/4") of rainfall during the twenty four (24) hour period preceding the
intended application time.
      6.   It is not applied to land with water ponded upon it, or is in a
floodplain or wetland.
      7.   It is not applied to land having greater than five percent (5%)
slope.
      8.   It is applied at a rate which does not exceed five thousand (5,000)
gallons of septage per acre per month.
      9.   It is not applied to land within two hundred feet (200') of a water
well, homes, or other water supplies, ponds, wetlands, streams, or within
twenty five feet (25') of property lines.
      10.   It shall be an area covered with vegetation to prevent erosion or
it shall be contour plowed.
      11.   If it is within municipal limits, written approval by corporate
authorities of the municipality is mandatory prior to issuance of a permit.
      12.   The soil type on the site shall have a permeability at least six-
tenths inches (0.6") per hour in the upper twelve inches (12") of the soil to
allow dewatering of the septage without ponding.
      13.   A soil thickness of at least two feet (2') without limiting layers
will be required.
      14.   The soil shall have a pH value ranging between 6.5 and 8.2.
      15.   Pasture or hay ground that has received septage shall not be
harvested for livestock grazing for a period of at least one month after
application.
   B.   Discharge To Municipal Sewer: Discharge to a municipal sewer shall be
only with permission of the sanitary district or municipality which operates or
governs said sewer. (Ord. 97-327, 11-12-1997)
18-42: REGISTRATION AND LICENSURE OF PRIVATE SEWAGE DISPOSAL SYSTEM
INSTALLATION CONTRACTOR AND PUMPING CONTRACTOR:
   A.   Registration And Licensure Required: All private sewage disposal system
installation contractors and pumping contractors shall be registered in
accordance with this chapter, and licensed with the Illinois department of
public health.
   B.   Knowledge Of Laws: Persons who design private sewage disposal in
systems in Kane County shall be knowledgeable of all laws and rules and
regulations of both the state of Illinois and the county of Kane governing such
design, construction, installation, repair, modification and renovation.
   C.   Continuing Education: At least once per year, the private sewage
disposal installation contractor, and/or pumping contractor, shall attend a
workshop, conference and/or complete a course on private sewage treatment and
disposal approved by the county health department. Approved workshops and
conferences shall be reviewed annually by an advisory committee representing
the county health department and private sewage disposal installation and
pumping contractors. Attendance at this workshop, conference and/or course is
mandatory prior to requesting and obtaining a county private sewage disposal
system installation contractor/pumping contractor registration. This course
must contain information specific to their area of licensure. Documentation of
registration must be submitted. Failure to comply with this section will cause
a written notice to be mailed to such person advising that they will not be
registered by the county health department until such time as they have
attended a workshop, conference and/or completed a course in private sewage
treatment and disposal. Such course must first be approved as acceptable by the
county health department.
   D.   Compliance With County Standards: The county health department shall
issue a private sewage disposal system installation contractor/pumping
contractor registration to persons applying for such who comply with the
standards for private sewage disposal system installation contractors/pumping
contractors adopted by Kane County. All such registration shall run from April
1 to March 31 of the following year.
   E.   Issuance Of Registration:
      1.   Pumping Contractors: Registration for private sewage disposal system
pumping contractors or persons who pump portable toilets in the county shall
have a valid registration from the county health department and must comply
with the requirements of this chapter. All registration shall be issued
annually for the period April 1 to March 31 of the following year.
      2.   Installation Contractors: Every private sewage disposal system
installation contractor in the county shall have a valid private sewage
disposal system installation contractors registration from the county health
department and must comply with the requirements of this chapter. (Ord. 97-327,
11-12-1997)
18-43: SUSPENSION OR REVOCATION OF REGISTRATION:
A registration may be suspended or revoked by the county health department for
failure of the registrant to comply with the requirements of this chapter.
Whenever a registrant has failed to comply with any notice issued under this
chapter, the registrant shall be notified in writing that the registration is,
upon service of the notice, immediately suspended or revoked and that an
opportunity for a hearing will be provided if a written request for a hearing
is filed with the county health department by the registrant within five (5)
days from receipt of the notice. Any person to whom such an order is issued
shall comply immediately therewith, but upon written petition to the county
health department, shall be afforded a hearing before the public health
committee within twenty (20) days of receipt of the request for a hearing.
(Ord. 97-327, 11-12-1997)
18-44: INSPECTIONS:
   A.   No private sewage disposal system shall be put into use until it has
been inspected and has written approval from the county health department.
   B.   The county health department is hereby authorized and directed to make
such inspections as are necessary to determine satisfactory compliance with
this chapter.
   C.   It shall be the duty of the owner or occupant of a property to give the
county health department free access to the property at reasonable times for
the purpose of making such inspections as are necessary to determine compliance
with the requirements of this chapter. (Ord. 97-327, 11-12-1997)
