CHAPTER 20
TAXATION
SECTION:
20-1: Retailers' Occupation Tax
20-1-1: Supplementary Retailers' Occupation Tax
20-2: Service Occupation Tax
20-2-1: Supplementary Service Occupation Tax
20-3: Use Tax
20-3-1: Supplementary Use Tax
20-4: Disputes As To Formation Of Multi-Township Assessment Districts
20-5: Real Estate Transfer Tax
20-6: Replacement Vehicle
20-7: Cannabis Retailers’ Occupation Tax
20-1: RETAILERS' OCCUPATION TAX:
A tax is imposed on all persons engaged, in the unincorporated area of the
county, in the business of selling tangible personal property at retail, at the
rate of one percent (1%) of the gross receipts from such sales made in the
course of such business, in accordance with the county retailers' occupation
tax act. (Ord. 69-88, § 1, 9-9-1969)
20-1-1: SUPPLEMENTARY RETAILERS' OCCUPATION TAX:
   A.   That a county supplementary retailers' occupation tax at a rate of one-
fourth of one percent is hereby imposed upon all persons engaged in the
business of selling tangible personal property at retail within the county.
   B.   That such person in administering and accounting for the tax are
subject to the same rights, remedies, privileges, immunities, powers and
duties, and the same conditions, restrictions, limitations, penalties, and
definitions of terms, and the same mode of procedures as found in the
"retailers' occupation tax act" as are now or hereafter amended, unless
otherwise noted or excepted in PA 84-163. (Ord. 86-7, §§ 1, 2, 1-14-1986)
20-2: SERVICE OCCUPATION TAX:
A tax is imposed on all persons engaged, in the unincorporated area of the
county, in the business of making sales of service at the rate of one percent
(1%) of the cost price of all tangible personal property transferred by said
servicemen, either in the form of tangible personal property or in the form of
real estate as an incident to the sale of service in accordance with the county
service occupation tax act. (Ord. 69-87, § 1, 9-9-1969)
20-2-1: SUPPLEMENTARY SERVICE OCCUPATION TAX:
   A.   That a county supplementary service occupation tax is hereby imposed
upon all persons engaged in the business of making sales of service within the
county of Kane, at a rate of one-fourth of one percent of the cost price of all
tangible personal property transferred by such servicemen either in the form of
tangible personal property or in the form of real estate as an incident to a
sale of service.
   B.   That such persons in administering and accounting for the tax are
subject to the same rights, remedies, privileges, immunities, powers and
duties, and the same conditions, restrictions, limitations, penalties, and
definitions of terms, and the same mode of procedures as found in the "service
occupation tax act" and "retailers' occupation tax act", respectively, as are
now or hereafter amended, unless otherwise noted or excepted in PA 84-163.
(Ord. 86-5, §§ 1, 2, 1-14-1986)
20-3: USE TAX:
A tax is hereby imposed upon the privilege of using in the county any item of
tangible personal property which is purchased outside Illinois at retail from a
retailer, and which is titled or registered with any agency of this state's
government, at the rate of one percent (1%) of the selling price of such
tangible personal property, as "selling price" is defined in the Illinois "use
tax act", approved July 14, 1955, as amended. Such tax shall be collected from
persons whose Illinois address for titling or registration purposes is given as
being in the unincorporated areas of the county. (Ord. 1, § 1, 3-11-1975)
20-3-1: SUPPLEMENTARY USE TAX:
   A.   That a county supplementary use tax is hereby imposed upon the
privilege of using in the county of Kane, any item of tangible personal
property which is purchased outside Illinois at retail from a retailer, and
which is titled or registered with an agency of this state's government, at a
rate of one-fourth of one percent of the selling price of such tangible
personal property, as "selling price" is defined in the "use tax act", approved
July 14, 1955, as amended. The tax shall be collected from persons whose
Illinois address for titling or registration purposes is given as being within
the county of Kane.
   B.   That such persons in administering and accounting for the tax are
subject to the same rights, remedies, privileges, immunities, powers and
duties, and the same conditions, restrictions, limitations, penalties, and
definitions of terms, and the same mode of procedures as found in the "use tax
act", as are now or hereafter amended, unless otherwise noted or excepted in PA
84-163. (Ord. 86-6, §§ 1, 2, 1-14-1986)
20-4: DISPUTES AS TO FORMATION OF MULTI-TOWNSHIP ASSESSMENT DISTRICTS:
The county board's executive committee will be responsible for the county
board's duties under hearings conducted pursuant to cases of dispute between
two (2) or more townships as to inclusion or exclusion of a township in any one
multi-township assessment district. Such committee may conduct said hearings in
any manner it sees fit in accordance with public act 81-838 as amended and
other applicable laws. (Res. 80-142, 9-9-1980)
20-5: REAL ESTATE TRANSFER TAX:
   A.   Imposed: A tax is imposed on the privilege of transferring title to
real estate, as represented by the deed that is filed for recordation, and upon
the privilege of transferring a beneficial interest in a land trust holding
legal title to real estate located in such county as represented by the trust
document that is filed for recordation, at the rate of twenty five cents
($0.25) for each five hundred dollars ($500.00) of value or fraction thereof
stated in the declaration provided for in this section. If, however, the real
estate is transferred subject to a mortgage, the amount of the mortgage
remaining outstanding at the time of transfer shall not be included in the
basis of computing the tax.
   B.   Prerequisite To Filing Deed: Except as provided in subsection E of this
section, no deed or trust document shall be accepted for filing by the recorder
unless the tax imposed by subsection A of this section has been paid.
   C.   Indication Of Payment: The recorder may affix stamps whose design,
denominations and form shall be prescribed by the recorder (to every deed or
trust document which represents a transfer subject to the tax imposed by
subsection A of this section). In lieu of the stamps described above, the
recorder may use and affix any other writing or other indication that the tax
imposed by subsection A of this section has been paid.
   D.   Real Estate Transfer Declaration: At such time as the tax levied by
this section is aid, there shall be filed with the recorder a fully executed
and completed copy of the "real estate transfer declaration" required by
provisions of 35 Illinois Compiled Statutes 305/3, as amended.
   E.   Certain Deeds Exempt: The following deeds or trust documents shall be
exempt from the provisions of this section except as hereinafter provided:
      1.   Deeds or trust documents representing real estate transfers made
before January 1, 1968, but recorded after that date.
      2.   Deeds or trust documents to property acquired by any governmental
body or from any governmental body or deeds to property between governmental
bodies, or by or from any corporation, society, association, foundation or
institution organized and operated exclusively for charitable, religious or
educational purposes.
      3.   Deeds or trust documents which secure debt or other obligation.
      4.   Deeds or trust documents which, without additional consideration,
confirm, correct, modify, or supplement a deed previously recorded.
      5.   Deeds or trust documents where the actual consideration is less than
one hundred dollars ($100.00).
      6.   Deeds or trust documents of release of property which is security
for a debt or other obligation.
      7.   Tax deeds.
      8.   Deeds or trust documents of partition.
      9.   Deeds or trust documents made pursuant to mergers, consolidations or
transfers or sales of substantially all of the assets of corporations pursuant
to plans of reorganization.
      10.   Deeds or trust documents made by a subsidiary corporation to its
parent corporation for no consideration other than the cancellation or
surrender of the subsidiary's stock.
      11.   Deeds or trust documents wherein there is an actual exchange of
real estate except that money difference or money's worth paid from one to the
other shall not be exempt from the tax.
      12.   Deeds or trust documents representing transfers subject to the
imposition of a documentary stamp tax imposed by the government of the United
States, except that such deeds shall not be exempt from filing the declaration.
      13.   A deed or trust document issued to a holder of a mortgage, as
defined in section 15-103 of the code of civil procedure, pursuant to a
mortgage foreclosure proceeding or pursuant to a transfer in lieu of
foreclosure.
      14.   Any future exemption enacted by the state of Illinois.
   F.   Proceeds: All proceeds resulting from the collection of the tax imposed
by this section shall be paid to the county treasury on a semimonthly basis.
   G.   Tax Additional To Others: The tax herein imposed shall be in addition
to all other occupation or privilege taxes imposed by the state or by any
municipal corporation or political subdivision thereof. (Ord. 79-94, §§ 1-7, 5-
29-1979; Ord. 85-190, § 1, 12-10-1985)
20-6: REPLACEMENT VEHICLE TAX:
A replacement vehicle tax of fifty dollars ($50.00) is hereby imposed on any
motor vehicle, as defined in sections 1 through 146 of the Illinois vehicle
code and 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes, purchased by or on behalf of an
insurance company to replace a vehicle of an insured person in settlement of a
total loss claim. (Ord. 84-9, § 1, 1-10-1984)
20-7: CANNABIS RETAILERS’ OCCUPATION TAX.
   A.   Tax Imposed; Rate:
      1.   A tax is hereby imposed upon all persons engaged in the business of
selling cannabis, other than cannabis purchased under the compassionate use of
medical cannabis program act, at retail in the county on the gross receipts
from these sales at the following rates:
         a.   3.75% of the gross receipts from these sales made in the course
of that business in unincorporated areas of Kane County.
      2.   The imposition of this tax is in accordance with the provisions of
the county cannabis retailers’ occupation tax law (55 ILCS 5/5-1006.8).
   B.   Collection Of Tax By Retailers:
      1.   The tax imposed by this section shall be remitted by such retailers
to the Illinois department of revenue (the “department”). Any tax required to
be collected pursuant to or as authorized by this section and any such tax
collected by such retailer and required to be remitted to the department shall
constitute a debt owed by the retailer to the state. Retailers may reimburse
themselves for their seller’s tax liability hereunder by separately stating
that tax as an additional charge, which charge may be stated in combination, in
a single amount, with any state tax that sellers are required to collect.
      2.   The taxes hereby imposed, and all civil penalties that may be
assessed as an incident thereto, shall be collected and enforced by the
department. The department shall have full power to administer and enforce the
provisions of this article. (Ord. 21-162, 3-9-2021; Ord. 21-163, 3-9-2021)

21-1: SIGNS, SIGNALS, ETC., RATIFIED:
The location of all signs, signals, markings and devices which guide, regulate
or warn traffic on County maintained highways, in conformance with current
requirements of the Illinois Vehicle Code and the State Manual on Traffic
Control Devices is hereby ratified and confirmed. (Res. 82-15, §§ 1, 3, 1-12-
1982; Ord. 90-280, 12-11-1990)
21-1-1: ADDITIONAL COURT FEES:
The Clerk of the Circuit Court of the County shall charge and collect a fee of
five dollars ($5.00) for all traffic violations where there is an admission of
guilt as well as fees per the following schedule:
 
Felony          $50.00
Misdemeanor:     
Class A         25.00
Class B or C    15.00
Petty offense   10.00
All civil cases 5.00
 
Said fees shall be used for the purpose of supporting the court system in Kane
County. A "traffic violation" for the purpose of this section shall not include
parking tickets or parking violations. Such fees shall be in addition to all
other fines and charges assessed by the Circuit Court and shall be remitted
monthly by the Clerk of the Circuit Court to the County Treasurer for deposit
in the General Fund.
The Clerk of the Circuit Court of the County shall charge and collect a one
hundred dollar ($100.00) fee for the second and subsequent violations of
section 5/11-501 of the Illinois Vehicle Code 1  or violations of similar
provisions, contained in County or municipal ordinances, committed in the
County. The proceeds of this fee shall be placed in the County General Fund and
used to finance education programs related to driving under the influence of
alcohol or drugs. (Ord. 93-170, 6-8-1993)

the intended users of the highways and roadways within the County highway and
roadway system. (Ord. 99-243, 8-10-1999)

21-2-1: ABSOLUTE MAXIMUM SPEED LIMITS:
The absolute maximum speed limit for all Kane County highways and township
roads within Kane County that are not otherwise posted with a lesser speed
limit pursuant to this section
21-2 shall be fifty five (55) miles per hour. Unless otherwise posted, pursuant
to this section
21-2, the maximum speed limit within the following townships and subdivisions
shall be as follows: (Ord. 96-82)

21-2-2: SPEED LIMITS FOR CONSTRUCTION ZONES:
   A.   The members of the Kane County Board hereby authorize the County
Engineer to set and post reduced speed limits for construction or maintenance
zones, as defined in 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-605.1.
   B.   Such reduced speed limits shall be temporary and be in effect and in
full force from the time appropriate signing giving notice of the reduced speed
limits are erected until such time that said signing is removed.
   C.   Construction or maintenance zone speed limit signs shall: 1) be of a
design approved by the Illinois Department of Transportation, 2) give proper
warning that a construction or maintenance speed zone is being approached, 3)
indicate the maximum speed limit in effect, and 4) state the amount of the
minimum fine for a violation as established by 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes
5/11-605.1.
   D.   A record shall be maintained by the Division of Transportation naming
each location, the reduced speed limit set and posted for the construction or
maintenance zone and dates during which the reduced speed limit was in effect.
   E.   Affected jurisdictions shall be notified of the changes in the posted
speed limits so that they may be properly enforced. (Ord. 05-296, 8-9-2005)
21-3: THROUGH STREETS 1 :
The County Board may designate certain highways or parts of highways in the
County to be through streets. The County Superintendent of Highways shall place
signs upon or at the entrance of streets or highways designated as through
streets, giving notice of such through highways, and in the event that two (2)
or more said through highways intersect in the County, the Superintendent of
Highways may determine which highway shall be the through highway. (Res., 9-11-
1940; Res., 12-10-1941; Res., 6-15-1943; Res., 6-13-1950; Res., 9-12-1951;
Res., 12-10-1952; Res., 12-8-1953; Res., 9-15-1954; Res., 9-14-1955; Res., 9-
12-1956; Res., 9-10-1957; Res., 9-15-1958; Res., 12-11-1963; Res. 76-27, 2-10-
1976)
 
Notes
1 1. 625 ILCS 5/11-208(a)(6).
21-4: RESTRICTIONS ON TRAVEL IN WINTER:
   A.   The County Superintendent of Highways is hereby authorized between
February 1 and May 1 of each year to prohibit travel altogether by vehicles on
highways under the jurisdiction of the County, and, especially, on such State
aid roads that are not maintained in entirety by the State when necessary, to
prevent serious damage or destruction of such roads; and he is further
authorized, when necessity demands, to impose restrictions covering the
permissible weights of such vehicles using such highway or highways or sections
thereof in order to protect such roads from serious damage or destruction
during such period of time or during part of such period of time; provided,
however, that when such restrictions are imposed by order of the
Superintendent, such restrictions must be according to the total weight allowed
on any one axle and the total weight per inch per width of tire on any one
wheel, or both, and shall be uniform as to the application thereof to all types
or classification of vehicles using such highway or highways or sections
thereof so restricted.
   B.   The County Superintendent of Highways, when necessary, may prohibit the
operation of trucks or other commercially operated vehicles on highways under
the jurisdiction of the County, and, especially, upon State aid roads not
maintained in entirety by the State and may impose restrictions as to their
permissible weights whenever necessary to protect such road or roads or parts
thereof from serious damage; provided, however, that when such restrictions are
imposed by order of the Superintendent, such restrictions must be according to
the total weight allowed on any one axle and the total weight per inch per
width of tire on any one wheel, or both, and shall be uniform as to the
application thereof to all types or classifications of vehicles using such
highway or highways or sections thereof so restricted.
   C.   The County Superintendent of Highways shall cause to be posted the
requisite signs where use of such highway or highways or section thereof is
prohibited or restricted, and such signs or notices shall contain the
prohibition or restrictions applying to such road or sections thereof and shall
be signed by the Superintendent of Highways as follows:
      BY ORDER OF THE BOARD OF SUPER-
      VISORS OF KANE COUNTY, ILLINOIS
      By                          
      COUNTY SUPERINTENDENT
      OF HIGHWAYS
   D.   The County Superintendent of Highways is hereby designated as the
enforcing officer of this section and shall have full power and authority to
impose restrictions or prohibitions with reference to the use of State aid
roads in the County to vehicle traffic thereon during the period of time from
February 1 to May 1 1  of each calendar year and is further directed,
authorized and empowered to take any and all proceedings necessary to protect
such highway or highways or sections thereof so that they will not be damaged
or destroyed during the period designated in this section.
   E.   The County Superintendent of Highways shall keep a record in his office
of all orders entered by him with reference to prohibiting vehicle traffic or
imposing restrictions as to the use of the same on said highway or highways or
sections thereof and such orders shall be final when posted by the County
Superintendent of Highways.
   F.   No person shall violate any of the provisions of this section or the
lawful orders of the County Superintendent of Highways issued in pursuance
hereto. (Res., §§ 2-7, 3-14-1951)
21-5: NO PARKING 2 :
It shall be unlawful for any person to park or permit to be parked a motor
vehicle at any location designated by the County Board to be a "no parking"
area. The County Superintendent of Highways shall erect and maintain such signs
as are necessary to enforce the "no parking" regulations; provided, however,
that the Township Highway Commissioner in which such road is located shall
erect and maintain appropriate signs to enforce parking which is marked with an
asterisk (*).

ARTICLE II. PARKING, STOPPING, STANDING AND OTHER REGULATIONS
SECTION:
21-10: Speed Limits
21-11: State Traffic Law Adopted
21-12: Traffic Signs, Signals, Etc.
21-13: Kane County Parking Areas
21-14: Parking Violations
21-15: Prohibiting Right Turn On Red
21-10: SPEED LIMITS:
No person shall drive or operate any vehicle within any Kane County facility as
hereinafter described at a speed greater than is reasonable and proper having
regard to the traffic and use of way or so as to endanger the life or limb or
property of any person, nor in excess of fifteen (15) miles per hour. (Ord. 92-
295, 12-8-1992; Ord. 93-4, 1-12-1993)
21-11: STATE TRAFFIC LAW ADOPTED:
There is hereby adopted for the purpose of prescribing regulations for the
operation and parking of vehicles, including disabled persons, that certain law
known as the Illinois traffic law, 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes, as amended,
and the same is hereby adopted and represented as fully as if set out at length
herein, and the provisions thereof shall be controlling within all named county
facilities. (Ord. 92-295, 12-8-1992; Ord. 93-4, 1-12-1993)
21-12: TRAFFIC SIGNS, SIGNALS, ETC.:
All traffic control systems, signs, signals or devices which are in place on
the adoption date hereof within the following described parking areas are
hereby ratified and confirmed except as are or as may be modified by
administrative parking restrictions and regulations, the current restrictions
and regulations being attached hereto and made a part of this article. (Ord.
92-295, 12-8-1992; Ord. 93-4, 1-12-1993)
21-13: KANE COUNTY PARKING AREAS:
The Kane County parking areas which are designated as follows are restricted
parking areas:
   A.   Parking lots contained within the Kane County Government Center
complex;
   B.   Parking lots contained within the Kane County Courthouse complex;
   C.   Parking lots contained within the youth home;
   D.   Parking lots contained within the diagnostic center;
   E.   Parking lots contained within the family court; and
   F.   Parking lots contained within the circuit clerk's premises.
The parking of motor vehicles in the above described areas, whether marked by
color coding or numbered minutes or described as "Restricted Parking",
"Reserved-County Board", "Reserved- Judiciary", shall be restricted and limited
to such Kane County officers, employees, officials and other persons
transacting county business. A schedule of the current parking restrictions and
regulations and assignments of parking promulgated by the county administration
committee of the county board is incorporated by reference as part of this
article. A schedule of said restrictions and regulations shall be filed with
the county clerk for public inspection. (Ord. 92-295, 12-8-1992; Ord. 93-4, 1-
12-1993)
21-14: PARKING VIOLATIONS:
   A.   Any person accused of a violation of a section of this code prohibiting
parking a vehicle in a designated area or restricting the length of time a
vehicle may be parked there may settle and compromise the claim against him for
such illegal parking by paying to the county, within forty eight (48) hours of
the time such alleged offense was committed, the following sums for the
following offenses:
 
1. Overtime parking                      $ 5.00
2. Overtime parking in excess of 8 hours 10.00
3. Prohibited parking                    15.00
 
In the event such fine is not paid within forty eight (48) hours after the
issuance of the citation therefor, the fine for each said offense shall be as
follows:
 
1. Overtime parking                      $10.00
2. Overtime parking in excess of 8 hours 20.00
3. Prohibited parking                    30.00
 
Any person, firm or corporation violating this article shall be subject to
having its vehicle towed from the restricted parking area. The payment of the
towing and storage charges shall be the responsibility and obligation of the
owner.
Such payment of fines shall be made at the office of the circuit clerk, or in
the fine deposit boxes located upon the facilities, and such funds shall be
promptly turned over to the county treasurer to be credited to the general
corporate fund. (Ord. 92-295, 12-8-1992; Ord. 93-4, 1-12-1993)
21-15: PROHIBITING RIGHT TURN ON RED:
The following streets or highways shall be prohibited from right turns on red
as set out in the Illinois vehicle code, 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-
306(c)(3), so as to be reasonable, safe and proper:
   Kane County Highway No. 30 (Huntley Road) at Sleepy Hollow Road.
   Kane County Highway 34 (Randall Road) at Kane County Highway 30 (Huntley
Road).
   Kirk Road at Wilson Street for the eastbound lane of Wilson Street. (Ord.
07-229, 6-12-2007; Ord. 17-55, 2-14-2017; Ord. 19-449, 12-10-2019)
CHAPTER 22
TRAILER COACH AND MOBILE HOME PARKS 1
 
Notes
1 1. 210 ILCS 115/1 et seq.
ARTICLE I. IN GENERAL
SECTION:
22-1: Short Title
22-2: Definitions
22-3: Inspections And Enforcement
22-4: Records Of Zoning Officer
22-5: Certificates Of Use And Occupancy Required
22-6: Application Of Administrative Review Act
22-7: Rules And Regulations
22-8: Exemption
22-9 - 22-25: Reserved
22-1: SHORT TITLE:
This chapter shall be known and referred to as the KANE COUNTY TRAILER COACH
AND MOBILE HOME PARK ORDINANCE. (Ord. 68-25, § 1, 4-9-1968)
22-2: DEFINITIONS 1 :
As used in this chapter the following terms shall mean as indicated:
COMMITTEE: The development committee of the county board.
DEPENDENT TRAILER COACH OR DEPENDENT MOBILE HOME: A trailer coach which does
not have a toilet and bath or shower facilities.
INDEPENDENT TRAILER COACH OR INDEPENDENT MOBILE HOME: A trailer coach with
self-contained toilet and bath or shower facilities.
SCHOOL DISTRICT: Any district created or operated under the provisions of the
"school code", approved May 1, 1945, as amended.
TRAILER COACH OR MOBILE HOME: Any vehicle or similar portable structure used or
so constructed as to permit its being used as a conveyance upon the public
streets or highways and designed to permit the occupancy thereof as a dwelling
place, or any vehicle or similar portable structure designed to be transported
after fabrication, on a flatbed or on another trailer, or on detachable wheels
to a site where it is to be used as a dwelling ready for occupancy, except for
minor or incidental unpacking and assembly operations.
TRAILER COACH PARK OR PARK: An area of land upon which two (2) or more occupied
trailer coaches are harbored, either free of charge or for revenue purposes,
and shall include any building, structure, tent, vehicle, or enclosure used or
intended for use as a part of the equipment of such trailer coach park.
TRAILER COACH SPACE OR TRAILER COACH SITE: Any portion of a trailer coach park
designed for the use or occupancy of one trailer coach. (Ord. 68-25, § 2, 4-9-
1968)
 
Notes
1 2. 210 ILCS 115/2 - 115/2.9.
22-3: INSPECTIONS AND ENFORCEMENT 1 :
The governing body of the school district in which a trailer coach park is
located, by and through its officers, attendance officers and proper employees,
may inspect and visit a trailer coach park for the purposes of examining the
register with reference to children of school age for the purpose of enforcing
attendance of school children housed in the trailer coach park. When a trailer
coach park is located in two (2) or more school districts, the school district
boards of said districts, acting jointly, are hereby authorized to proceed
under the provisions of this chapter. The zoning officer shall enforce the
provisions of this chapter and the zoning officer or his deputies shall
inspect, at least once each year, each trailer coach park and all the
accommodations and facilities therewith. The zoning officer and his deputies
are hereby granted the power and authority to enter upon the premises of such
trailer coach parks at any time for the purposes herein set forth. (Ord. 68-25,
§§ 15, 18, 4-9-1968)
 
Notes
1 1. 210 ILCS 115/21.
22-4: RECORDS OF ZONING OFFICER:
The zoning officer shall keep a record of all trailer coach parks; said records
to show the names and addresses of all trailer coach parks, names and addresses
of the licensees, number of trailer coach lots in each park, source of water
supply; system of sewage and garbage disposal, and any other information deemed
essential by the zoning officer. (Ord. 68-25, § 12, 4-9-1968)
22-5: CERTIFICATES OF USE AND OCCUPANCY REQUIRED:
   A.   No trailer coach park shall be occupied until a certificate of use and
occupancy shall have been issued by the zoning officer to the effect that the
trailer coach park, or the portion thereof for which such certificate is
required, is in compliance with all applicable provisions of this chapter.
   B.   Each trailer coach occupied as a dwelling unit located in the county
after April 9, 1968, shall meet the minimum standards for plumbing, heating and
electrical systems, as defined by the American Standard Association project
A119.1, approved March 12, 1963, as revised periodically. Trailer coaches that
display the official seal and register number of the Mobile Home Manufacturers
Association and the Trailer Coach Association will be considered to comply with
the American Standards Association, standard A119.1. Trailer coaches that do
not meet these minimum standards for plumbing, heating and electrical systems
will not be issued a certificate of use and occupancy permit by the zoning
officer.
   C.   The minimum standards for plumbing, heating and electrical systems as
defined by the American Standards Association project A119.1 (1963), as amended
and revised periodically, are hereby made a part of and incorporated by
reference into this chapter.
   D.   This requirement shall not apply to occupied trailer coaches in the
county prior to April 9, 1968, nor to units built prior to March 12, 1963.
(Ord. 68-25, § 9A(v), 4-9-1968)
22-6: APPLICATION OF ADMINISTRATIVE REVIEW ACT:
The "administrative review act" approved May 8, 1945, and all amendments and
modifications thereof, and the rules adopted pursuant thereto shall apply to
and govern all proceedings for judicial review of final administrative
decisions of the zoning officer and the development committee hereunder. The
term "administrative decision" is defined as in section I of the
"administrative review act". (Ord. 68-25, § 20, 4-9-1968)
22-7: RULES AND REGULATIONS:
The committee may issue rules and regulations to carry out the provisions of
this chapter. (Ord. 68-25, § 18, 4-9-1968)
22-8: EXEMPTION:
   A.   This chapter shall not apply to any trailer coach located in a
recreational camp as defined in the zoning ordinance, the patrons of which have
other permanent residences and reside in trailer coaches within the recreation
camp only during recreational seasons.
   B.   Nothing in this chapter shall be construed to include the state parks
of Illinois and the term "trailer coach park" shall not be construed to include
buildings, tents, or other structures maintained by any person on his own
premises and used exclusively to house his own farm labor, or any real estate
owned by the United States or of this state wherein a trailer coach or coaches
may be located or harbored, or any park on state or county fairgrounds for a
period during, immediately prior to and immediately subsequent to the holding
of the fair not to exceed a total of two (2) weeks in all, or the area or
premises on any farm upon which are harbored trailer coaches occupied by
persons employed upon such farm for not more than ninety (90) days in any
calendar year in the production, harvesting or processing of agricultural or
horticultural products produced on such farm. However, any trailer coach park
owned or operated by any municipality shall meet sanitary and safety provisions
of this chapter, shall be inspected as herein provided, shall pay or cause to
be paid to the zoning officer the respective application and license fees
provided by this chapter, and keep a register and make all reports, as herein
required of a licensee. (Ord. 68-25, §§ 3.1, 17, 4-9-1968)
22-9 - 22-25: RESERVED:
ARTICLE II. LICENSES AND PERMITS 1
SECTION:
22-26: Generally
22-27: Application
22-28: Application Processing And Issuance; Changes In Application Information
22-29: License Fee And Handling Of Funds
22-30: License Revocation Or Suspension
22-31: Records And Forms
22-32: Appeals
22-33 - 22-45: Reserved
 
Notes
1 1. 210 ILCS 115/18, 115/3 - 115/8.
22-26: GENERALLY:
   A.   No person shall construct a trailer coach park without first obtaining
a permit to do so. Each permit to construct, each license to operate, and each
permit to make alterations therein shall be prominently displayed in the office
of the trailer coach park for which the same was issued. Licenses issued
hereunder apply only to the premises described in the application and in the
license issued thereon, and only one location shall be so described in each
license. A license which has been issued to a person, may not be transferred to
any other person, firm or corporation, without the written consent of the
zoning officer. However, the zoning officer may not withhold such consent where
the provisions of this chapter have been met. A license which has been issued
for particular premises may not be removed or made to apply to any other
premises.
   B.   No person, firm, or corporation shall construct, establish, maintain,
conduct or operate a trailer coach park without first obtaining a license
therefor from the zoning officer. Such license shall be issued for one year and
shall expire at midnight on April 30 of each year, and the license shall be
renewed from year to year upon payment of the annual license fee herein
provided. (Ord. 68-25, §§ 3, 8, 4-9-1968)
22-27: APPLICATION:
   A.   In order to obtain a permit to construct, or any original license to
operate a trailer coach park, the applicant shall file with the zoning officer
a written application setting forth:
      1.   The full name and address of the applicant or applicants, or names
and addresses of the partners if the applicant is a partnership, or the names
and addresses of the officers if the applicant is a corporation, and the
present or last occupation of the applicant at the time of the filing of the
application.
      2.   The location and legal description of the tract of land upon which
it is proposed to operate and maintain a trailer coach park.
      3.   The proposed and existing facilities in the park for water supply,
sewage, garbage and waste disposal, fire protection, and for a sanitary
community building, if applicable, which will include a description of toilets,
urinals, sinks, wash basins, showers, drains and laundry facilities, the
proposed alterations therein and the maintenance thereof.
      4.   The proposed method of lighting structures and land upon which the
park is located.
      5.   The calendar month of the year which applicant will operate said
park.
      6.   The plot plans of the park drawn on a scale of one hundred feet to
one inch (100':1"), building plans and specifications for existing buildings
and facilities, and the plans and specifications for new buildings and
facilities, or the proposed alterations in existing facilities, all showing
compliance with the provisions of this chapter. The plot plans shall be drawn
on a scale of one hundred feet to one inch (100':1") and shall contain, among
other things, the following:
         a.   The date on which such plot plans were prepared.
         b.   An arrow indicating north.
         c.   All trailer coach sites shall be properly numbered on plot plans.
         d.   Complete information regarding storm sewers.
         e.   Stormwater runoff shall be shown on a separate plat.
         f.   Contour lines at one foot (1') intervals shall be shown on a
separate plat and United States geological survey data shall be used for the
preparation of such plat.
         g.   Grades of driveways and all ditches shall be shown on a separate
plat.
      7.   A statement of the fire fighting facilities, public or private,
which are available to the trailer coach park.
   B.   An affidavit as to the truth of the matters contained in the
application shall be attached thereto. Where a permit to construct as well as
an original license to operate is sought by the applicant, request therefor
shall be made in the same application. Each application for a permit to
construct or for an original license shall be accompanied by an application fee
amounting to twenty five dollars ($25.00) for each ten (10) acres of land, or a
fraction thereof, proposed to be used as a park. Each application fee shall be
paid to the zoning officer by a separate certified check or United States money
order in the amount of the application fee only, and said application fee, once
paid to the zoning officer, shall not be refunded. (Ord. 68-25, § 4, 4-9-1968)
22-28: APPLICATION PROCESSING AND ISSUANCE; CHANGES IN APPLICATION INFORMATION:
   A.   The committee shall examine the application for a permit to construct a
park or an application for a license to operate and maintain a park, and the
zoning officer shall, if the park is or the proposed park will be in conformity
with this chapter as determined by the committee, issue a permit to construct
or an original license, as the case may be. If the application for a permit to
construct or a license to operate and maintain is declined, the committee shall
give the reasons therefor in writing to the applicant; and if the objections
can be corrected, the applicant may amend his application and resubmit it for
approval.
   B.   No license shall be issued for any trailer coach park which does not
fully comply with at least the minimum requirements of this chapter, regardless
of whether a license is issued for such trailer coach park for any prior
licensing year.
   C.   If a permit to construct a park has been issued, the applicant shall,
upon completion thereof, notify the zoning officer. The zoning officer shall
then inspect the park, and, if completed in accordance with the accepted
application, the zoning officer shall issue a license to operate and maintain
said park.
   D.   No change in any sanitary facilities, methods of water supply, sewer,
drainage, garbage or waste disposal and no change in the plot plan shall be
made without first making a written application to the zoning officer and
receiving a permit therefrom. Such application shall be made in the way and
manner hereinbefore set forth, except that a fee amounting to ten dollars
($10.00) for each ten (10) acres, or a fraction thereof, used to harbor trailer
coaches thereon shall accompany each application for a permit to alter such
trailer coach park. No application fee shall be required to accompany an
application for a permit to alter a park where such alteration involves only a
reduction to the number of trailer spaces to a number less than such park is
currently licensed for. Such change or changes shall comply with such safety
and sanitary code, building code, rules and regulations as are applicable
thereto.
   E.   Such a permit does not relieve the applicant from securing permits or
from complying with the zoning ordinance, the building ordinance or any other
ordinances applicable thereto. No license to operate and maintain a park shall
be issued if such park is in violation of the zoning ordinance and such park
was not in existence at the time of the passage of such zoning ordinance. (Ord.
68-25, §§ 5, 10, 4-9-1968)
22-29: LICENSE FEE AND HANDLING OF FUNDS:
   A.   In addition to the application fee provided for herein, the licensee
shall pay to the zoning officer on or before April 30 of each year an annual
license fee, which shall be fifty dollars ($50.00) plus three dollars ($3.00)
for each trailer coach space in the park. Any applicant for an original license
to operate a new trailer coach park constructed under a permit by the zoning
officer shall only be required to pay one-fourth (1/4) of the annual fee if
such park begins operating after January 31 and before May 1 of such licensing
year; or one-half (1/2) of the annual fee if such trailer coach park begins
operation after October 31 and before February 1 of such licensing year; or
three-fourths (3/4) of the annual fee if such park begins operation after July
31 and before November 1 of such licensing year; but shall be required to pay
the entire annual fee if such trailer coach park begins operation after April
30 and before August 1 of such licensing year.
   B.   Each license fee shall be paid to the zoning officer by a separate
certified check or United States money order in the amount of the license fee
only, and any license fee, or any part thereof, once paid to and accepted by
the zoning officer, shall not be refunded if the license is granted.
   C.   The zoning officer shall deposit all funds received under this chapter
with the county treasurer. (Ord. 68-25, § 6, 4-9-1968)
22-30: LICENSE REVOCATION OR SUSPENSION:
Any license granted hereunder shall be subject to revocation or suspension by
the zoning officer; however, the zoning officer shall first serve, or caused to
be served, upon the licensee, a written notice in which shall be specified the
way or ways in which such licensee has failed to comply with this chapter. Said
notice shall require the licensee to remove or abate such nuisance, unsanitary
or objectional condition specified in such notice within a reasonable time. If
the licensee fails to comply with the terms and conditions of said notice
within a reasonable time, the zoning officer may revoke or suspend such
license. (Ord. 68-25, § 7, 4-9-1968)
22-31: RECORDS AND FORMS:
   A.   When the committee has approved an application for a permit to
construct or make alterations upon a trailer coach park or the appurtenances
thereto or a license to operate and maintain the same, it shall retain the
original and keep a file thereof, and one copy shall be returned to the
applicant or his agent, one copy shall be delivered to the zoning officer.
   B.   The zoning officer shall draft and supply all forms and blanks and
specify the number and detail necessary to obtain permits to construct or make
alterations upon trailer coach parks and for a license to operate and maintain
such a park according to this chapter. (Ord. 68-25, § 11, 4-9-1968)
22-32: APPEALS:
   A.   Any person refused a permit to construct or alter a trailer coach park
or a license, or whose license is suspended or revoked, shall have the right to
a hearing before the committee, which shall have full power to conduct such
hearing, issue subpoenas, administer oaths and affirmations and all other
powers necessary to such hearing.
   B.   All hearings before the committee shall be open to the public, and the
committee shall keep minutes of the proceedings showing its determination and
shall also keep records of other official actions.
   C.   In the performance of its duties under the provisions of this chapter,
the committee may incur such expenditures as shall be authorized by the county
board.
   D.   The committee shall adopt its own rules and procedures not in conflict
with this chapter.
   E.   No hearing shall be held before the committee until notice of the time
and place of the hearing has been published in a newspaper of general
circulation in the county at least fifteen (15) days prior to the hearing date,
said notice to contain the particular location of the trailer coach park and a
brief statement as to the reason the hearing is being held. (Ord. 68-25, § 19,
4-9-1968)
22-33 - 22-45: RESERVED:
